On their way, they saw a muleteer brutally beating a stubborn mule on a bridge until it crossed. Melisso and Giosefo, pitying the beast, advised gentler methods. The muleteer replied, "You know your horses and I know my mule; leave me do with him." He continued beating until the mule obeyed. Giosefo then asked the name of the bridge. It was "Goosebridge." Giosefo realized Solomon's counsel: he needed to beat his wife.
In Antioch, Giosefo's wife, as usual, ignored his instructions for supper. Giosefo, taking a stout stick, beat her severely until she promised to obey. The next morning, she prepared supper exactly as he wished. Melisso, seeing this, understood Solomon's advice: to be loved, one must love sincerely, not for show. Thus, the froward wife was corrected, and the young man, by loving, was loved.

**Story 10: Dom Gianni**
Dioneo tells of Dom Gianni di Barolo, a poor priest in Barletta, who traded merchandise with Pietro da Tresanti, a poor man with a buxom wife, Gemmata. Dom Gianni often stayed with Pietro, sleeping in the stable with his mare.
Dom Gianni once told Gemmata he could turn his mare into a beautiful wench to sleep with, and then back into a mare. Gemmata, believing him, told Pietro. She urged Pietro to learn the charm so he could turn her into a mare, use her for work, and then turn her back. Pietro, dull-witted, importuned Dom Gianni.
Dom Gianni, unable to dissuade him, agreed to teach him. He warned Pietro that the hardest part was "putting on the tail" and that he must not speak during the conjuration.
At dawn, Pietro and Gemmata, eager, arose. Dom Gianni, in his shirt, instructed Pietro to hold a light and remain silent. He stripped Gemmata naked, made her stand on all fours, and began touching her, saying, "Be this a fine mare's head," "Be this a fine mare's mane," "Be these fine mare's legs and feet," and "Be this a fine mare's chest" (as his penis became erect). Finally, he thrust his penis into her vagina, saying, "And be this a fine mare's tail."
Pietro, seeing this, cried out, "Ho there, Dom Gianni, I won't have a tail there, I won't have a tail there!" Dom Gianni withdrew, saying Pietro had ruined the conjuration by speaking, and it could not be redone. Gemmata, furious, scolded Pietro for his folly. She lamented that he had ruined their chance to gain a mare. She dressed. Pietro continued his trade with an ass.

**Day the Ninth - Conclusion**
The company laughed at Dioneo's story. Pamfilo, his reign ending, crowned Lauretta as queen. Lauretta, accepting, announced the theme for the next day: "OF THE TRICKS THAT ALL DAY LONG WOMEN PLAY MEN OR MEN WOMEN OR MEN ONE ANOTHER." She allowed Dioneo to keep his privilege. All approved. They went barefoot in the clear water and enjoyed the garden. Dioneo and Fiammetta sang. After supper, Filomena sang a song about her new love and jealousy. The queen, noting the next day was Friday, declared it and Saturday would be days of rest and prayer, as before. They retired to rest.

**Day the Tenth**
**Introduction**
At dawn on Sunday, King Pamfilo and his company walked in the gardens, discussing their future life. After refreshments, dinner, and a nap, they reassembled by the fountain. Pamfilo bade Neifile begin the day's stories.

**Story 1: A Knight in the King's Service of Spain**
Neifile tells of Messer Ruggieri de' Figiovanni, a rich and high-spirited Florentine gentleman, who sought service with Alfonso, King of Spain, renowned for his valor. Ruggieri was graciously received and quickly gained fame for his deeds of arms. However, he noticed the King bestowed castles and baronies on unworthy individuals, while he, a man of worth, received nothing. Feeling his reputation diminished, he sought leave to depart.
The King granted his request and gave him a fine mule. He secretly sent a discreet servant to ride with Ruggieri, observe his words about the King, and then summon him back. As they rode, Ruggieri's mule refused to urinate when they stopped. Later, at a river, the mule urinated in the stream. Ruggieri exclaimed, "God confound thee, beast, for that thou art made after the same fashion as the prince who gave thee to me!" The servant noted this.
The next morning, the servant revealed the King's command to return. Ruggieri returned to court. The King asked why he likened him to his mule. Ruggieri frankly replied that the mule, like the King, gave where it should not and not where it should. The King explained that it was Ruggieri's misfortune, not his own fault, that he had not been rewarded. To prove this, he showed Ruggieri two locked coffers: one with his crown, sceptre, jewels, and all his treasures; the other full of earth. He bade Ruggieri choose one.
Ruggieri chose a coffer, which, when opened, was found to be full of earth. The King, laughing, said this proved Ruggieri's fortune was to blame. He then declared that, despite fortune, he would give Ruggieri the coffer of treasures, so he could return home and boast of his worth and the King's gifts. Ruggieri, grateful, returned to Tuscany with the treasure.

**Story 2: Ghino di Tacco**
Elisa tells of Ghino di Tacco, a cruel and famous robber, exiled from Siena, who seized Radicofani against the Church of Rome and plundered travelers. Pope Boniface VIII was in Rome. The Abbot of Cluny, a rich prelate, fell ill and was advised to go to the baths of Siena. He traveled with a large retinue, disregarding Ghino's reputation.
Ghino ambushed the Abbot and his company, capturing them all. He sent a messenger to the Abbot, inviting him to his castle. The Abbot, furious, refused. The messenger explained that excommunications were useless there, and the Abbot should comply. Seeing himself surrounded, the Abbot reluctantly went to the castle. Ghino lodged the Abbot alone in a dark, mean room, while his retinue was well accommodated.
Ghino visited the Abbot, asking his destination and purpose. The Abbot, now humbled, told him of his illness and journey to Siena. Ghino resolved to cure him without baths. He kept a fire in the room and, for several days, brought the Abbot only two slices of toasted bread and a beaker of wine each morning, claiming it was a remedy for his stomach.
The Abbot, hungry, ate and drank, but complained and demanded to see Ghino. Ghino, ignoring his demands, continued the regimen. When he saw the Abbot had eaten some dried beans (which Ghino had secretly left), he asked about his stomach. The Abbot replied he felt well, but longed to eat. Ghino then had a magnificent chamber prepared for the Abbot and hosted a grand banquet for him and his retinue.
After some days, Ghino revealed himself to the Abbot, explaining he was a gentleman forced into robbery by poverty and enemies. He offered the Abbot all his possessions, asking him to take what he wished, as a token of his cure. The Abbot, amazed by Ghino's generosity, embraced him, forgiving him and regretting his own past pride. He took only a few necessities and left the rest to Ghino.
The Abbot returned to Rome and told the Pope of his "cure" by a physician "nearer than at the baths." He then magnanimously requested the Pope pardon Ghino di Tacco and restore him to favor, arguing that Ghino's actions were due to misfortune, not evil. The Pope, a great soul, agreed. Ghino came to court, was made a knight of the Hospitallers, and became a loyal servant of the Church.

**Story 3: Mithridanes and Nathan**
Filostrato tells of Nathan, a noble and immensely rich man in Cattajo, who built a magnificent palace by a highway and offered lavish hospitality to all travelers. His fame spread. Mithridanes, a rich young man from a nearby country, grew envious and sought to surpass Nathan's generosity. He built a similar palace and offered even greater hospitality.
One day, an old woman, after receiving alms from Mithridanes, remarked on Nathan's greater generosity, saying she had entered Nathan's palace by all thirty-two gates and received alms each time without being recognized, while Mithridanes recognized her after only thirteen. Mithridanes, enraged by Nathan's superior fame, resolved to kill him.
He rode to Nathan's palace alone. He found Nathan walking unattended and, not recognizing him, asked where Nathan lived. Nathan, cheerfully, offered to guide him and ensured Mithridanes would not be recognized by anyone in the household. He lodged Mithridanes in a fine chamber and entertained him.
Mithridanes, still not knowing his host was Nathan, asked his identity. Nathan replied he was an "unworthy servant" who had grown old with Nathan, receiving little advancement. Mithridanes, emboldened, confessed his true identity and his intention to kill Nathan out of envy. Nathan, though disturbed, calmly advised him to find Nathan walking alone in a coppice nearby the next morning, where he could easily kill him. He also gave him directions for escape.
The next day, Mithridanes went to the coppice. He saw Nathan walking alone. He ran towards him, sword drawn, saying, "Old man, thou art dead." Nathan replied, "Then have I merited it." Mithridanes, recognizing Nathan's voice and face, was overwhelmed with shame. He threw down his sword, fell at Nathan's feet, and confessed his folly, acknowledging Nathan's supreme generosity.
Nathan raised him, embraced him, and pardoned him. He praised Mithridanes' noble ambition, saying that even emperors killed to gain fame. He then explained his willingness to die: he had lived a full life, and it was better to give his life as a gift than to have it taken by nature. He offered his life again. Mithridanes, deeply moved, refused.
Nathan then proposed they exchange identities: Mithridanes would live in Nathan's house as Nathan, and Nathan would live in Mithridanes's house as Mithridanes. Mithridanes declined, saying his actions would diminish Nathan's fame. They returned to Nathan's palace. Nathan entertained Mithridanes for days, encouraging his noble purpose. Mithridanes returned home, having learned he could never surpass Nathan's liberality.

**Story 4: Messer Gentile de' Carisendi**
Lauretta tells of Messer Gentile Carisendi, a noble Bolognese gentleman, who loved Madam Catalina, wife of Niccoluccio Caccianimico. Unrequited, he left for Modona as provost. Meanwhile, Catalina, pregnant, fell gravely ill and was pronounced dead by physicians. Her kinswomen, believing the child not fully formed, buried her in a church vault.
Messer Gentile, hearing of her death, resolved to steal a kiss from her dead body. He secretly rode to the church, opened the sepulchre, and lay beside her, kissing her. Overcome by desire, he touched her breast and felt a faint heartbeat. He realized she was alive. With his servant's help, he carefully removed her from the tomb and took her to his house in Bologna.
His mother, a discreet gentlewoman, revived Catalina with hot baths. Catalina awoke, confused, and saw Messer Gentile. He explained everything. She was distressed but thanked him, begging him not to dishonor her. Gentile promised to treat her as a dear sister but asked a favor: to stay with his mother until he returned from Modona, so he could present her to her husband in public. Catalina, grateful, agreed.
Soon after, Catalina gave birth to a healthy son. Gentile returned to Modona, completed his term, and planned a grand banquet in Bologna, inviting Niccoluccio Caccianimico. At the banquet, Gentile posed a question: if a master abandoned a sick servant, and a stranger revived him, did the first master have a right to reclaim the servant? Niccoluccio and all the guests agreed the servant justly belonged to the second master.
Gentile then called for Catalina, magnificently dressed, carrying her son. He presented her to the guests, asking if he had reason to hold her dear. Many recognized her but believed her dead. Niccoluccio, captivated, asked who she was. Gentile, after ensuring everyone's attention, revealed that she was the "loyal and faithful servant" he had found abandoned and restored to life. He recounted the entire story of her "death" and revival.
He then presented Catalina and her son to Niccoluccio, saying, "Rise up, gossip; I do not restore thee thy wife, whom thy kinsfolk and hers cast away; nay, but I will well bestow on thee this lady my gossip, with this her little son, who I am assured, was begotten of thee and whom I held at baptism and named Gentile." He swore she had lived chastely in his house. Niccoluccio, overjoyed, received his wife and son, thanking Gentile. The Bolognese were astonished. Catalina returned home, received with great rejoicing, and Gentile remained a friend to both families.

**Story 5: Madam Dianora**
Emilia tells of Madam Dianora, a noble and fair lady in Udine, Friuli, wife of Gilberto. Messer Ansaldo Gradense, a noble and valiant baron, loved her passionately. Dianora, tired of his importunities, set an impossible condition: she would grant him her love if he could provide a garden full of green grass, flowers, and trees in full leaf in January, as if it were May.
Ansaldo, though despairing, found a necromancer who, for a great sum, agreed to create such a garden. In January, when everything was covered in snow, the necromancer used his arts to create a beautiful garden. Ansaldo presented its fruits and flowers to Dianora, reminding her of her promise.
Dianora, seeing the miraculous garden, regretted her oath. Her husband, Gilberto, noticed her distress. She confessed everything. Gilberto, though initially angry, understood her pure intent. Fearing the necromancer, he magnanimously told her to go to Ansaldo and fulfill her promise, but to preserve her chastity if possible. If not, she should yield her body but not her soul.
Dianora, weeping, went to Ansaldo's house. Ansaldo, hearing her story and moved by Gilberto's generosity, declared he would not dishonor a man who had shown such compassion. He treated her as a sister and released her from her promise. Dianora, overjoyed, returned to Gilberto. A strong friendship formed between Gilberto and Ansaldo. The necromancer, seeing such generosity, refused his payment, saying he would also be liberal. Ansaldo, having his lustful love extinguished, retained an honorable affection for Dianora.

**Story 6: King Charles the Old**
Fiammetta tells of King Charles the Old (Charles I), who expelled the Ghibellines from Florence. Messer Neri degli Uberti, a Ghibelline, fled to Castellamare di Stabia, building a fine house and garden with a fishpond. King Charles, resting at Castellamare, heard of the garden's beauty. He sent word to Messer Neri that he would sup privately in his garden with four companions. Messer Neri, though an enemy, prepared a magnificent supper.
During supper, two beautiful young daughters of Messer Neri, Ginevra the Fair and Isotta the Blonde, entered the garden. They wore light linen garments and chaplets of periwinkle. One carried nets and a pole, the other a frying-pan, wood, trivet, oil, and a torch. They caught fish from the pond, and the servant cooked them. They served the fish to the King, who was captivated by their beauty and grace. After serving, they sang a sweet canzonet.
The King, ravished, felt a fervent desire for them, realizing he was in danger of falling in love. He asked Messer Neri who they were. Neri revealed they were his twin daughters. The King greatly commended them.
Later, unable to forget Ginevra's beauty, King Charles, feigning other reasons, frequently visited Messer Neri's garden. He confided his passion and his intent to abduct both daughters to Count Guy de Montfort. Count Guy, an honorable man, rebuked the King, reminding him of his age, his new kingdom, and the dishonor of such an act, especially against a host who had shown such faith. He reminded the King that Manfred's violence against women had opened the kingdom to him. He urged the King to conquer himself.
The King, stung by the truth, vowed to overcome his appetite. He returned to Naples and, to prevent dishonorable actions and reward Messer Neri, decided to marry the two girls, not as Neri's daughters, but as his own. He dowered them magnificently and gave Ginevra to Messer Maffeo da Palizzi and Isotta to Messer Guglielmo della Magna, both noble cavaliers. With great chagrin, he consigned them to their husbands and then went to Apulia, where he mortified his desire and lived free of such passion.

**Story 7: King Pedro of Arragon**
Pampinea tells of Lisa, daughter of Bernardo Puccini, a rich Florentine apothecary in Palermo. Lisa fell passionately in love with King Pedro of Arragon, whom she saw tilting at a festival. She despaired due to her low birth and his high status. Her unrequited love made her gravely ill.
Her father, offering to do anything, asked what she desired. She asked for Minuccio d'Arezzo, a skilled singer and player, to visit her. Minuccio, thinking she wanted music, played and sang. Lisa then privately confessed her secret love for King Pedro, her despair, and her wish to die, but only after the King knew of her love. She asked Minuccio to convey this.
Minuccio, moved, promised to help. He commissioned a poet, Mico da Siena, to write a canzonet expressing Lisa's love and longing for the King. Minuccio set it to a plaintive air. Three days later, he sang it to King Pedro, who was dining. The King, captivated, asked for whom the song was made. Minuccio privately revealed Lisa's story.
King Pedro, pleased by Lisa's noble spirit, promised to visit her that evening. Minuccio, overjoyed, brought the news to Lisa, who showed immediate signs of recovery.
Towards vespers, King Pedro, feigning diversion, visited Bernardo's house. He entered Lisa's chamber, took her hand, and encouraged her to recover. Lisa, feeling his touch, was in paradise and replied that her illness was due to her "little strength" to bear "grievous burdens," but she would recover. The King understood her veiled words.
Later, the King, having consulted the Queen, returned to Bernardo's house with many barons. He called Lisa and declared that her great love had earned her great honor. He offered to marry her to a noble young gentleman, Perdicone, and promised to remain her "knight" forever, asking only for a kiss. Lisa, blushing, accepted, saying she would gladly obey him, even if it meant fire. She thanked him and the Queen.
The King married Lisa to Perdicone, bestowing on them rich fiefs and jewels. He then kissed Lisa on the brow, declaring himself her knight. Lisa and Perdicone lived happily. The King faithfully kept his promise, always wearing her favor in deeds of arms.

**Story 8: Sophronia, Gisippus, and Titus**
Fiammetta tells of Titus Quintius Fulvus, a Roman gentleman's son, sent to Athens to study. He lodged with Chremes, his father's friend, and studied with Chremes' son, Gisippus. They became inseparable friends. Chremes died.
Gisippus's kin urged him to marry. They found Sophronia, a beautiful and noble Athenian lady. Gisippus took Titus to see her. Titus, seeing Sophronia, fell passionately in love. He struggled with his love, torn between friendship and desire. He fell ill.
Gisippus, concerned, pressed Titus for the cause of his illness. Titus, weeping, confessed his love for Sophronia and his despair, resolving to die. Gisippus, though also attracted to Sophronia, valued Titus's life more. He rebuked Titus for hiding his pain and then magnanimously offered Sophronia to him. He argued that he could easily find another wife, but not another friend.
Titus, ashamed but drawn by love, finally accepted. Gisippus proposed that he would proceed with the wedding, bring Sophronia home as his wife, and then Titus would secretly lie with her. Later, they would reveal the truth. Titus agreed.
Gisippus married Sophronia. That night, Gisippus, in the dark, sent Titus to Sophronia's bed. Titus, after some hesitation, lay with her, asked her if she would be his wife (she, thinking him Gisippus, said yes), and placed a ring on her finger. They consummated their marriage.
Titus's father died, and he had to return to Rome. He and Gisippus decided to tell Sophronia the truth. She was enraged by Gisippus's deception and returned to her father, revealing she was Titus's wife. Sophronia's and Gisippus's families were furious, condemning Gisippus.
Titus, knowing the Greeks' tendency to clamor but then humble themselves, assembled both families in a temple. He argued that Sophronia's marriage was foreordained by the gods. He then compared himself to Gisippus: both young philosophers, but he was Roman (citizen of a free, world-ruling city, illustrious in arms and letters), while Gisippus was Athenian (of a tributary city). He was of nobler birth and richer. He argued that Gisippus had acted wisely in giving her to a better man. He also defended the secrecy, saying necessity often dictated such actions. He warned them that if they did not accept the marriage and treat Gisippus as a friend, he would take Gisippus to Rome and become their enemy, making them suffer Roman wrath.
The families, swayed by his reasoning and threats, agreed. Sophronia, making a virtue of necessity, accepted Titus and went with him to Rome.
Later, Gisippus, exiled and impoverished from Athens, came to Rome to seek Titus's help. Titus, passing by, did not recognize him in his wretched state. Gisippus, despairing, wandered to a deserted part of the city. He witnessed a thief murder another. Wishing to die without suicide, he remained there. The watch found him and, believing him the murderer, arrested him. Gisippus confessed, hoping for death.
Titus, by chance at the praetorium, recognized Gisippus. To save his friend, he falsely confessed to the murder. Gisippus, seeing Titus's sacrifice, then insisted he was the murderer. The true murderer, Publius Ambustus, moved by their friendship, confessed. Octavianus, hearing their stories, released all three.
Titus took Gisippus home, reproaching him for his diffidence. Sophronia received Gisippus as a brother. Titus restored Gisippus to wealth, shared all his possessions, and gave him his sister, Fulvia, in marriage. Gisippus and Fulvia, and Titus and Sophronia, lived long and happily in Rome, sharing one house and growing in friendship.

**Story 9: Saladin**
The king tells of Saladin, Soldan of Babylon, who, before a crusade, disguised himself as a merchant to observe Christian preparations. In Lombardy, he and his two officers met Messer Torello d'Istria, a gentleman of Pavia, who was going to his country seat. Torello, recognizing them as gentlemen, invited them to stay, subtly leading them to his house so they couldn't refuse. He entertained them magnificently.
Torello, impressed by his guests, sent a servant to his discreet wife in Pavia, instructing her to prepare a grand banquet for the next day. Saladin and his companions, speaking Latin, were greatly impressed by Torello's hospitality.
The next morning, Torello took his guests hawking, then led them to Pavia, not to an inn, but to his own house, where many noble citizens awaited them. Saladin, realizing the extent of Torello's hospitality, was deeply impressed. They were treated like royalty.
After dinner, Torello brought his beautiful wife and two young sons to meet them. She courteously greeted them and, after Torello left briefly, asked them about their journey. She then presented each of them with two magnificent gowns, three doublets, and linen breeches, claiming they were small gifts from a woman. Saladin and his companions, astonished, realized they had been recognized. They thanked her.
The next morning, Torello provided them with fine palfreys and horses. Saladin, deeply moved, realized the immense worth of Christian gentlemen. He departed, resolving to repay Torello's generosity.
Meanwhile, a Provençal gentleman named Messer Torello de Dignes died in the Christian camp. Due to the confusion of the crusade, many believed it was Messer Torello d'Istria. News reached Pavia that he was dead. His wife, Madam Adalieta, after months of mourning, was pressured by her family to remarry. She reluctantly agreed, on condition she could wait a year, a month, and a day from Torello's departure.
In Alexandria, Messer Torello (the Christian) learned from a traveler that the Genoese galley, on which he had sent letters to his uncle, had been shipwrecked, and all on board perished. Believing his letters lost and his wife remarried, he fell ill with despair, resolving to die. Saladin, learning the cause of his grief, promised to transport him to Pavia by magic before the deadline.
Saladin instructed a necromancer to put Torello to sleep and transport him on a magnificent bed with rich gifts (a crown, a carbuncle ring, a sword, pearls, gold basins of doubloons) to the church of San Pietro in Ciel d'Oro in Pavia.
Torello awoke in the church, surrounded by the gifts. The sacristan and monks, terrified, fled, believing him a ghost. Torello called out to the abbot, his uncle, who, after much fear, recognized him. The abbot told him his wife was to remarry that very morning.
Torello, dressed in Saracen attire, went with his uncle to the wedding feast. He sat opposite his wife, who, due to his beard and foreign dress, did not recognize him. Torello, to test her memory, sent her a cup of wine, asking her to drink from it according to a foreign custom. He secretly dropped the ring she had given him into the cup.
Madam Adalieta, drinking, found the ring, recognized it, and, realizing it was Torello, overturned the table and rushed to embrace him, crying, "It is my lord, it is indeed Messer Torello!" She refused to let go. Torello recounted his adventures. The new bridegroom, though mortified, accepted his fate. Adalieta put on Torello's ring and the Soldan's crown. They returned to Torello's house, where they celebrated with great joy. Torello shared his jewels with the new groom and others, and lived long and happily, continuing his hospitality.

**Story 10: The Marquess of Saluzzo**
Dioneo tells of Gualtieri, Marquess of Saluzzo, who, having no wife or children, spent his time hunting. His vassals urged him to marry. He reluctantly agreed but insisted on choosing his own wife, warning them they must honor whomever he chose. He had long admired Griselda, a poor peasant girl from a nearby village, and decided to marry her.
He arranged with her father, Giannucolo, and announced a magnificent wedding. On the wedding day, Gualtieri rode to the village with his company. He found Griselda returning from the spring. He dismounted, entered her poor house, and asked her father for her. He then asked Griselda if she would always obey him and never take offense at his actions. She agreed. He led her out, had her stripped naked, and clothed her in rich apparel, crowning her. He then married her in front of everyone and took her to his mansion.
Griselda, with her new clothes, also seemed to change her mind and manners. She became graceful, discreet, and so obedient and diligent that Gualtieri was delighted. His vassals, who had initially mocked his choice, now praised his wisdom.
Griselda bore a daughter. Gualtieri, to test her patience, pretended his vassals were discontent with her low birth and the child. Griselda calmly replied she would accept whatever pleased him. He then sent a servant to take the child, feigning to have her killed. Griselda, heartbroken but composed, handed over her daughter, asking only that she not be devoured by beasts. Gualtieri sent the child to a kinswoman in Bologna to be raised secretly.
Griselda bore a son. Gualtieri repeated the test, claiming his vassals would not accept a peasant's grandson as lord. Griselda again submitted patiently. He sent the son away, feigning his death, also to Bologna. The vassals condemned Gualtieri's cruelty but pitied Griselda, who always said she accepted her husband's will.
Years passed. Gualtieri, deciding on a final test, announced he could no longer endure Griselda and would seek a papal dispensation to divorce her and marry another. Many noblemen criticized him, but he remained firm. He produced forged papal letters and told Griselda she was dismissed, to return to her father with only the dowry she brought (nothing).
Griselda, containing her tears, replied she had always known her low estate. She returned his ring. She reminded him he took her naked and asked if she might keep one shift, as she brought no dowry. Gualtieri, with a stern face, agreed. She left his house in her shift, barefoot, and returned to her father, to the lamentation of all who saw her. Giannucolo, who had kept her old clothes, dressed her. She resumed her humble life.
Gualtieri then announced he was marrying a daughter of the Counts of Panago and made grand preparations. He sent for Griselda, ordering her to prepare the mansion for the new bride, inviting ladies, and receiving them as mistress of the house. Griselda, though heartbroken, obeyed. In her coarse clothes, she cleaned and decorated the palace, serving diligently.
Gualtieri had his two children (the girl now twelve, the boy six) brought from Bologna, presenting the girl as his new bride. All admired the girl's beauty. Griselda, too, praised her. Gualtieri, seeing Griselda's unwavering patience, revealed the truth. He embraced her, telling her these were their children, whom he had feigned to kill.
Griselda wept with joy, embracing her children. The ladies, overjoyed, reclothed her in magnificent attire. They celebrated for days. Gualtieri was deemed wise, though his trials were harsh. Griselda was praised for her wisdom. Giannucolo was elevated. Gualtieri and Griselda lived long and happily. Dioneo concludes that divine spirits can be found in poor cottages, and some in palaces are only fit to tend swine. He praises Griselda's patience.

**Day the Tenth - Conclusion**
Dioneo's story concluded, sparking much debate among the ladies. Pamfilo, seeing the sun setting, acknowledged their successful sojourn. He praised their decorum, concord, and fraternal familiarity. To avoid tediousness and prevent others from intruding, he proposed they return to Florence the next morning. All agreed. He gave instructions to the seneschal. After supper, Lauretta led a dance, and Fiammetta sang a song about her love and jealousy. The king dismissed them to rest.
The next day, they returned to Florence. The three young men took leave of the seven ladies at Santa Maria Novella, and the ladies returned to their homes.

**Conclusion of the Author**
The author addresses the noble damsels, stating he has completed his promised work. He thanks God and them. He anticipates objections to his "overmuch license" in the stories, particularly for modest women. He denies this, saying unseemly things can be expressed seemly. He argues that the nature of the stories required their content, and if some words are "freer" than hypocritical prudes like, it is no more forbidden than common speech or a painter depicting Adam and Eve naked. He emphasizes that the stories were told in a garden, for diversion, among mature individuals, not in church or schools.
He states that stories, like all things, can be harmful or profitable depending on the listener. Wine, though good for the healthy, harms the fevered. Fire is useful but can burn. Arms protect but can kill. Corrupt minds twist good words, but unseemly words cannot contaminate well-disposed minds. He asserts his stories are useful and seemly if read at the right times and by the right persons. Those who pray or make tarts can ignore them.
He acknowledges some might find stories "better away" or "overlong." He states he only wrote what was told and that no craftsman (except God) does everything perfectly. He reminds readers that he wrote for idle women, for passing time, not for students. He defends his use of "quips and cranks" as suitable for easing melancholy, like friars' sermons.
Finally, he addresses those who might call his tongue "venomous" for writing the truth about friars. He admits the world is constantly changing, and his tongue might be too. He concludes by thanking God and wishing the ladies peace and favor, hoping his stories have been profitable.

The narrative begins with the speaker, in the midway of his mortal life, finding himself lost in a gloomy, savage wood, having strayed from the direct path. The memory of this terrifying forest, with its robust and rough growth, renews his dismay. He eventually reaches the foot of a mountain, which had previously filled him with dread, and sees its shoulders illuminated by the sun, which he believes guides all wanderers.

A brief respite from fear allows him to attempt the ascent. However, a nimble, speckled panther appears and blocks his way, making him frequently turn to retrace his steps. Though the morning hour and the sweet season initially fill him with hope, this joy is replaced by new dread when a hunger-mad lion with its head held aloft appears, striking fear into the air. Following the lion is a lean she-wolf, seemingly full of all wants and responsible for desolating many lands. This she-wolf overwhelms the speaker with such fear that he loses all hope of ascending the mountain and is gradually driven backward towards a lower, silent space.

In this desolate place, he discerns the form of a man whose voice seems faint from long disuse. The speaker cries out for mercy, asking if the figure is a spirit or a living man. The figure replies that he was once a man, born of Lombard parents in Mantua, during the time of Julius Caesar and Augustus. He identifies himself as a bard who made Anchises' upright son (Aeneas) the subject of his song, recounting Aeneas's journey from Troy after its burning. The bard questions why the speaker is returning to perils instead of ascending the pleasant mountain, the source of delight. The speaker, abashed, recognizes him as Virgil, the well-spring of eloquence, and praises him as his master and guide, from whom he derived his famous style. He implores Virgil to save him from the she-wolf.

Virgil explains that the she-wolf is so savage and accursed that she allows no one to pass, hindering like death, and her ravenous will is never sated. She will continue to afflict many until a "greyhound" comes to destroy her. This greyhound will not live by earthly means but by love, wisdom, and virtue, and will bring safety to Italia. For the speaker's benefit, Virgil devises a plan: he will guide the speaker through an "eternal space" where he will hear despairing shrieks and see tormented spirits who invoke a second death. Next, they will view those who dwell content in fire, hoping to eventually join the blessed. However, Virgil states that if the speaker desires to ascend to the regions of the blessed, a spirit worthier than himself must lead, as the Almighty King, whose law Virgil rebelled against, has decreed that none should enter His city through him. The speaker, wishing to escape his current and future ills, beseeches Virgil to lead him to Saint Peter's gate and to see those in dismal plight. Virgil moves onward, and the speaker follows.

As day departs and shadows darken the air, the speaker prepares for the perilous journey. He expresses doubt to Virgil about his worthiness for such a high enterprise, noting that figures like Aeneas and Paul, who had divine favor, undertook similar journeys for significant purposes (founding Rome, establishing faith). He feels he is neither of these and fears his venture will end in folly. Virgil perceives his fear and reveals its origin: a blessed and lovely dame named Beatrice called him from among the spirits "suspended" (in Limbo). Beatrice, with eyes brighter than the sun and an angelic voice, told Virgil that her friend (the speaker) had met great hindrance in the desert and turned back through fear. She dreaded he might be lost and she had risen too late for his relief, having heard of him in heaven. She urged Virgil to assist the speaker with his eloquent tongue and all suitable means, promising to tell her Master (God) of Virgil's praise.

The speaker asks Beatrice why she is not loath to leave her ample space (heaven) for the center beneath. Beatrice explains that God's grace has framed her so that earthly misery or fierce fire do not touch her. She also mentions another blessed dame in high heaven who mourns the speaker's hindrance so effectively that God's stern judgment inclines to her will. This dame called Lucia and commended the faithful servant (the speaker) to Beatrice. Lucia, foe of all cruelty, found Beatrice seated with Rachel and urged her to succor the speaker, who loved her so much. Beatrice then came down from her blessed seat, trusting in Virgil's eloquence, and saved the speaker from the beast. Virgil concludes by urging the speaker to cast off vile fear and embrace courage, as three blessed maids (Beatrice, the blessed dame, Lucia) plan his safety in heaven, and Virgil's words forebode much good. The speaker's vigor is restored, and he feels courageous, declaring his purpose resumed and accepting Virgil as his guide, master, and lord. They then enter the deep and woody way.

They arrive at a portal inscribed with dim characters: "Through me you pass into the city of woe: Through me you pass into eternal pain: Through me among the people lost for aye. Justice the founder of my fabric mov'd: To rear me was the task of power divine, Supremest wisdom, and primeval love. Before me things create were none, save things Eternal, and eternal I endure. All hope abandon ye who enter here." The speaker finds these words to have a "hard meaning," but Virgil tells him to leave all distrust and fear behind, as they are about to see souls doomed to misery who have lost "intellectual good." Virgil takes his hand and leads him into this secret place.

They are assailed by sighs, lamentations, loud moans, horrible languages, outcries of woe, accents of anger, deep and hoarse voices, and hands smiting together, creating a tumult that whirls in air stained with solid darkness, like sand in a whirlwind. The speaker asks what this is. Virgil explains these are the wretched souls of those who lived without praise or blame, mixed with a band of angels who were neither rebellious nor true to God, but only for themselves. Heaven drove them out to preserve its lustre, and Hell does not receive them lest they glory in vain. The speaker asks what aggrieves them so much. Virgil explains they have no hope of death, their blind life is so mean that they envy all other lots, and the world has no fame of them. Mercy and justice scorn them. He tells the speaker to look and pass them by without speaking.

The speaker sees a rapidly whirling flag, followed by a long train of spirits, so many that he never thought death had despoiled so many. He recognizes some, including the shade of one who yielded to base fear and abjured his high estate. He understands this is the tribe displeasing to both God and His foes. These naked wretches are stung by wasps and hornets, which make blood mix with their tears and drop to their feet, where disgustful worms gather it.

Further on, he sees a throng on the shore of a great stream and asks who they are and why they are eager to cross. Virgil says he will know when they reach the "woeful tide of Acheron." The speaker, feeling shame, abstains from speech until they reach the river. An old man, hoary white with age, approaches in a bark, crying, "Woe to you wicked spirits! hope not Ever to see the sky again. I come To take you to the other shore across, Into eternal darkness, there to dwell In fierce heat and in ice." The old man tells the speaker, a "live spirit," to get hence and leave the dead. When he sees the speaker doesn't leave, he says the speaker must come to shore by another way and a nimbler boat. Virgil tells the boatman, Charon, not to torment himself, as it is willed "where will and power are one." Charon, with shaggy cheeks and eyes glaring with wheeling flames, falls silent. The faint, naked spirits change color and gnash their teeth upon hearing the cruel words. They blaspheme God, their parents, mankind, the place, time, and their birth. Wailing, they draw to the cursed strand. Charon, a demoniac form with eyes of burning coal, collects them, beckoning and striking any who linger with his oar. They cast themselves down from the shore one by one, like leaves falling in autumn. They go over the dark wave, and another throng gathers on the opposing bank. Virgil explains that those who die subject to God's wrath all come here from every clime and are eager to cross, as heaven's justice goads them. No good spirit has ever passed here, so Charon's complaint about the speaker confirms he is not among the damned. The gloomy region shakes terribly, chilling the speaker with fear. The earth gives a blast, shooting forth a vermilion flame, which conquers his senses, and he drops down as if seized by sudden slumber.

A crash of heavy thunder breaks the speaker's deep slumber, rousing him. He looks around to discern his location and finds himself on the brink of a lamentable valley, a dread abyss with innumerable plaints. It is dark, deep, and thick with clouds, and he cannot see its bottom. Virgil, pale, proposes they descend into the "blind world beneath," leading the way. The speaker, seeing Virgil's altered hue, asks how he can proceed if his guide yields to dread. Virgil explains that the anguish of the race below stains his cheek with pity, which the speaker mistakes for fear. He urges haste. They enter the bounds of the first circle, where only sighs are heard, trembling the eternal air, not from tortures but from grief of vast multitudes of men, women, and infants. Virgil explains these spirits are blameless of sin, but their merit profits not, as they lacked baptism, the portal to faith. If they lived before the Gospel, they did not serve God aright. Virgil is among them. Their affliction is only that they live "desiring without hope." The speaker is grieved, knowing many souls of mighty worth are in this Limbo. He asks if anyone, through their own or others' merit, ever came forth from here to be blessed. Virgil, understanding the question about holy faith, replies that he was new to that state when he saw a "puissant one" (Christ) arrive, crowned with victorious trophy. This powerful figure drew forth the shades of Adam, Abel, Noah, Moses, Abraham, King David, Israel with his family, Rachel, and many others, exalting them to bliss. Before these, no human spirit was saved.

They continue through the "wood" (the thick-set spirits). Near the summit, the speaker sees a flame shining through the darkened hemisphere, indicating a tribe of high honor. He asks who these honored people are, separate from the rest. Virgil explains their renown in the upper world earns them favor in heaven and this advanced place. A voice cries, "Honour the bard Sublime! his shade returns that left us late!" Four mighty spirits, neither sorrowful nor glad, approach them. Virgil identifies them: Homer (bearing a keen falchion), Flaccus (Horace, excelling in satire), Naso (Ovid), and Lucan. They greet Virgil with honor. The speaker is made the sixth of this learned band. They pass by a luminous beacon, speaking of matters now left untold. They arrive at a magnificent castle, seven times begirt with lofty walls and defended by a pleasant stream, which they cross as if on dry land. Through seven gates, the speaker enters with the sages into a mead of lively verdure. There dwells a race who move their eyes majestically, bearing eminent authority, speaking seldom but sweetly. In an open, bright, and lofty place, the speaker sees great spirits: Electra, Hector, Aeneas, Caesar, Camilla, Penthesilea, old King Latinus with his child Lavinia, Brutus, Lucretia, Cato's wife Marcia, Julia, Cornelia, and the fierce Soldan. He then sees the "master of the sapient throng" (Aristotle) seated amidst philosophers, admired and revered by all, including Socrates, Plato, Democritus, Diogenes, Heraclitus, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, Thales, Zeno, Dioscorides, Orpheus, Linus, Tully, Seneca, Euclid, Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Galenus, and Averroes. Virgil then leads the speaker away from this serene air into a storm-vexed climate where no light shines.

They descend from the first circle to the second, a lesser space but containing more bitter grief. Minos stands there, grinning ghastly, examining crimes and sentencing souls by encircling himself with his tail as many times as the degrees beneath the soul must descend. Souls confess their crimes before him. Minos sees the speaker and cries out, warning him to look how he enters, beware in whom he trusts, and not be deceived by the broad entrance. Virgil silences Minos, stating the speaker's way is appointed by destiny, willed "where will and power are one." Rueful wailings are heard, and many plaining voices strike the speaker's ear. They enter a place where light is silent, and a noise like a sea in tempest torn by warring winds bellows. The stormy blast of hell drives spirits with restless fury, whirling and dashing them. At the "ruinous sweep," shrieks, lamentations, moans, and blasphemies against God are heard. The speaker understands these are carnal sinners, whose reason is swayed by lust. These evil souls are borne by the gust like starlings in winter, driven on all sides, with no hope of rest or milder pang. Like cranes, they come loud wailing. The speaker asks who these spirits are, scourged by the black air. Virgil identifies the first as Semiramis, empress over many tongues, so shameless in luxury that she made liking lawful to clear her own blame. Next is Dido, who slew herself for love and broke faith with Sicheus. Then Cleopatra, a lustful queen. The speaker also sees Helen, Achilles (who fought for love), Paris, and Tristan, and a thousand more named by Virgil, all bereft of life by love.

Overpowered by pity, the speaker's mind is almost lost. He wishes to speak to two spirits coming together, who seem light before the wind. Virgil tells him to entreat them by the love that carries them, and they will come. When the wind sways them closer, the speaker addresses them as "wearied spirits" and asks them to discourse. They come like doves invited by desire to their nest. One spirit (Francesca) thanks the speaker for his pity and offers to speak freely while the wind is mute. She says her birthplace is on the coast where the Po descends to the ocean. She explains that "Love, that in gentle heart is quickly learnt," entangled her beloved by her fair form, taken cruelly, which still grieves her. "Love, that denial takes from none belov’d," caught her with pleasing him so well that he still doesn't desert her. She states, "Love brought us to one death: Caina waits The soul, who spilt our life." The speaker looks down, pondering. Virgil asks what he is thinking. The speaker laments how sweet thoughts and fond desire led them to such an ill pass. He asks Francesca how love granted them to know their uncertain wishes during their sweet sighs. Francesca replies that there is no greater grief than remembering joy in misery. She tells how one day, for their delight, they read of Lancelot being enthralled by love. They were alone, without suspicion. The reading often drew their eyes together and made their cheeks pale. At one point, when they read of the wished smile rapturously kissed by one so deep in love, her companion (who will never separate from her) kissed her lips, trembling. She states the book and writer were "love's purveyors" and they read no more that day. While one spirit spoke, the other wailed so sorely that the speaker, heartstruck with compassion, faints and falls to the ground like a corpse.

The speaker revives, having been overcome with pity for the kindred shades. He sees new torments and tormented souls in the third circle. This circle is characterized by ceaseless, accursed, heavy, and cold showers of large hail, discolored water, and sleety flaw in the dun midnight air. The land stinks. Cerberus, a cruel, fierce, and strange monster, barks like a dog through his wide threefold throat over the immersed multitude. His eyes glare crimson, his beard is black and unctuous, his belly large, and his clawed hands tear, flay, and dismember the spirits. The spirits howl like curs, screening themselves with one side and rolling around under the deluge. When Cerberus sees the speaker and Virgil, he opens his jaws, shows his fangs, and trembles. Virgil fills his palms with earth and casts it into Cerberus's ravenous maw. Cerberus, like a dog baying for food, lets fall his fury to swallow the morsel. They pass over the prostrate shades, their feet treading on their emptiness, which seemed substance. All lay extended except one, who suddenly sits up and asks the speaker to recognize him. The speaker says the anguish has changed his form, so he doesn't recognize him, and asks who he is. The spirit replies that the speaker's city, "heap'd with envy to the brim," held him in brighter days. Citizens named him Ciacco. He is worn with fatigue under the rain for the sin of gluttony, and all the others suffer the same punishment for the same crime.

The speaker asks Ciacco what will befall the citizens of the divided city, if any just one lives there, and the cause of their discord. Ciacco foretells that after long striving, they will come to blood. The "wild party from the woods" will chase the other with injury. Then, within three solar circles, the wild party will fall, and the other will rise by borrowed force of one who now rests "under shore." This other party will oppress the first for a long time. The just are two in number but neglected. Avarice, envy, and pride are the three fatal sparks that set all hearts on fire. The speaker asks about Farinata, Tegghiaio, Giacopo, Arrigo, Mosca, and others who worked good, wanting to know if they are in heaven or hell. Ciacco replies these are "blacker spirits" sunk deeper for various crimes, and the speaker may see them if he descends further. He asks the speaker to mention him when he returns to the "pleasant world." He then says no more, turns his eyes askance, bows his head, and falls among his blind companions. Virgil explains that Ciacco will not leave his bed until the last angel-trumpet blows, when the "Power Adverse" will come in glory, and each spirit will resume its flesh and form to hear the eternal doom. They pass through the foul mixture of spirits and rain. The speaker asks if the tortures will increase, mitigate, or remain severe after the great sentence. Virgil replies that as things grow to more perfection, they feel more sensibly both good and pain. Though this accursed race will never reach true perfection, they will approach it more then than now. They journey on, discussing more, until they reach the point where steps lead below, and find Plutus.

Plutus cries out, "Ah me! O Satan! Satan!" in a hoarse, wild alarm. Virgil comforts the speaker, assuring him Plutus has no power to hinder their descent. Virgil then silences Plutus, telling him to consume himself with fury, as the speaker passes through the dark profound with divine will, as willed on high where the Archangel poured vengeance on the "first adulterer proud." Plutus drops to the ground like sails collapsing when a mast splits. They descend to the fourth steep ledge, the dismal shore that hems in the woe of the universe. The speaker observes new pains and troubles, lamenting human fault. He sees a numerous race, more than elsewhere, leading a "dance" like waves clashing at Charybdis. They roll weights with their breasts, smite together, then roll back, exclaiming, "Why holdest thou so fast?" and "And why castest thou away?" They traverse the horrid circle, meeting again in the middle. The speaker asks who this race is and if those with shorn heads on their left were "separate to the church." Virgil replies these are souls who, in life, were so distorted in mind that they made no proper use of their wealth. Their words confirm this. Those "separate to the church," Popes and Cardinals, are crowned with no hairy cowls, and Avarice maintains absolute dominion over them. The speaker asks if he will recognize any stained with these foul sins. Virgil says it's a vain thought; their ignoble life makes them dark and indiscernible. They will forever meet in this rude shock, some rising from the tomb with clenched grasp, others with close-shaven locks. Their ill-giving and ill-keeping deprived them of the beautiful world and set them at this strife. Virgil emphasizes the brief and vain nature of fortune's goods, for which humanity struggles. Not all the gold in the world could purchase rest for one of these souls.

The speaker asks what this "Fortune" is, whose talons grasp the world's blessings. Virgil explains that God, with transcendent wisdom, created the heavens with ruling powers and similarly ordained a "guiding hand" and "general minister" (Fortune) to rule over the world's bright images. Fortune changes life's empty advantages from race to race, beyond human wisdom's prevention. One nation rises, another languishes, as her concealed will decrees. She plans, judges, and reigns like other divine powers, with incessant changes. She is swift due to the frequent claims for her favors. She is execrated by those who owe her praise, but she is blessed and rolls on her sphere, exulting in bliss. Virgil says they must pass on to heavier woe, as the stars indicate it's time to move. They cross the circle to the next steep, arriving at a well that boils and pours itself down to a foss. The water is murkier than the darkest grain. They journey beside the inky waters, entering beneath by a different track. The dismal stream expands into a lake called the Stygian. The speaker sees a miry tribe, naked and raging, sunk in the marsh. They strike each other not only with hands but with heads, breasts, and feet, tearing each other with fangs. Virgil explains these are souls overcome by anger. He also reveals that underneath the water dwells a multitude whose sighs make the surface heave with bubbles. Fixed in the slime, they say they were sad in the sweet air, carrying a foul and lazy mist within, and now are sad in these murky settlings. They gurgle this dolorous strain, unable to utter distinct words. They continue their route, looking down at those who gulp the muddy lees, until they reach a tower's low base.

Before reaching the tower's base, they see two cressets (lights) on its height and another light returning the signal from afar. The speaker asks Virgil what this means. Virgil replies that they will soon see what awaits them on the filthy waters, if the marsh fog doesn't conceal it. A small bark speeds across the waves, ferried by one who cries, "Art thou arriv'd, fell spirit?" Virgil replies, "Phlegyas, Phlegyas, This time thou criest in vain; No longer shalt thou have us, but while o'er The slimy pool we pass." Phlegyas pines in fierce ire, like one who hears of a great wrong. Virgil steps into the skiff and bids the speaker enter. The vessel seems freighted only after the speaker's entrance. The ancient prow cuts the waves more deeply than usual. While crossing the dead channel, one spirit drenched in mire comes before the speaker and asks who he is, coming before his hour. The speaker replies he comes but tarries not, and asks who the foul spirit is. The spirit says he is "one, as thou seest, who mourn." The speaker recognizes him, even in filth, and tells him to tarry in mourning and woe. The spirit stretches hands to the bark, but Virgil thrusts him back, saying, "Away! down there, To the other dogs!" Virgil then embraces the speaker, kisses his cheek, and praises his "justly disdainful" soul. He identifies the spirit as one noted for arrogance in the world, whose shadow is furious here. He notes how many who are mighty kings above will wallow like swine here. The speaker wishes to see the spirit (Filippo Argenti) whelmed in the dregs before they leave the lake. Virgil assures him his wish will be satisfied. Immediately, the miry tribes set upon Filippo Argenti with such violence that the speaker thanks God. They cry, "To Filippo Argenti!" and the moody Florentine turns his avenging fangs on himself. They leave him. A sudden sound of lamentation strikes the speaker's ear. Virgil tells him the city named Dis, with its grave denizens, draws near. The speaker sees vermilion minarets in the valley, gleaming as if from fire. Virgil explains that eternal fire burning inward illuminates them. They arrive within the deep fosses that moat this comfortless region. The walls appear made of iron. After a wide circuit, they reach a place where the mariner (Phlegyas) cries, "Go forth! The entrance is here!" On the gates, the speaker sees more than a thousand spirits, hurled from heaven of old. With ireful gestures, they demand to know who the speaker is, passing through the regions of the dead without having felt death. Virgil signals he wishes for secret parley. Their anger abating, they tell Virgil to come alone and let the speaker go back by his "witless way." They say the speaker must tarry there as Virgil's escort. The speaker is dismayed, believing he will never return. He cries to Virgil not to desert him in this extreme, and if they cannot go onward, to trace back their steps together. Virgil replies not to fear, as no one can disappoint their passage, permitted by high authority. He tells the speaker to wait, comfort his spirit with hope, and be assured Virgil will not leave him. Virgil departs, leaving the speaker hesitant and conflicted. The speaker cannot hear the terms Virgil offers, but the adversaries confer not long and flee within, closing the gates against Virgil. Virgil returns with tardy steps, eyes bent to the ground, confidence erased, sighing, "Who hath denied me these abodes of woe?" He tells the speaker not to fear his anger, as he will vanquish this trial. He explains this insolence is not new, displayed before at a less secret gate (the entrance to Hell itself) which is still without bolt, and on whose arch the speaker saw the deadly scroll. He adds that even now, one whose strong might can open this land is coming unescorted down the steep, passing the circles.

The speaker's pale cheeks, imprinted with coward dread, cause Virgil's newly worn hue to change. Virgil stands attentive, listening, as his eye cannot penetrate the sable air and thick clouds. Virgil begins, "It yet behooves We win this fight—if not—Such aid to us is offer’d.—Oh, how long Me seems it, ere the promis’d help arrive!" The speaker notes the contradiction in Virgil's words, his fear increasing due to the "mutilated speech." He asks if anyone ever descends to this depth from the first degree (Limbo), where pain is only deprivation of sweet hope. Virgil replies it rarely happens that anyone makes this journey. He recounts that once, the sorceress Erictho compelled him to enter these walls to draw forth a spirit from "Judas' circle" (the lowest place, most obscure, farthest from heaven). He knows the road well. He adds that the noisome lake encompasses the "city of grief," which they cannot enter without rage. The speaker is distracted by the lofty tower, on whose burning top he suddenly sees three hellish furies, stained with blood, feminine in limb and motion. Green hydras twist around them, and adders and cerastes creep instead of hair. Virgil identifies them: Megaera (left), Alecto (right, wailing), and Tisiphone (middle). The furies claw their breasts, smite themselves, and raise a shrill clamor. The speaker clings to Virgil. They cry, "Hasten Medusa: so to adamant Him shall we change!" They recall that even when Theseus assailed them, they took no ill revenge. Virgil tells the speaker to turn around and hide his face, for if he views the Gorgon, his return upwards would be lost forever. Virgil turns him around and covers him with his own hands. The speaker urges readers of intellect to mark the concealed lore. A loud-crashing, terrible sound comes over the waves, making both shores tremble, like an impetuous wind that plucks branches from a forest. Virgil loosens the speaker's eyes and tells him to look along the ancient foam where the smoke is thickest. More than a thousand destroyed spirits flee before one who passes with unwet feet over the Stygian sound, like frogs fleeing a serpent. The figure, removing the gross air from his face, often stretches forth his left hand, appearing wearied only by that annoyance. The speaker perceives he is sent from heaven and turns to Virgil, who signals him to stand quiet and bow to the figure. The figure, full of noble anger, comes to the gate and touches it with his wand, and it flies open without impediment. He addresses the "Outcasts of heav'n! O abject race and scorn'd!" asking why they show such insolence and kick against God's will, which has often enforced their pains. He reminds them of Cerberus, whose throat and maw are still peeled of hair from a past encounter. He turns back without speaking, appearing beset by other cares. They move toward the territory, secure after the hallowed words, and enter unopposed. The speaker looks around and sees wide-stretching space replete with bitter pain and torment. The place is thick with sepulchres, like Arles or Pola, but here flames are scattered amidst the graves, burning intensely, hotter than iron for any craft. Their lids hang suspended, and lamentable moans issue from beneath. The speaker asks who is interred in these vaults. Virgil replies these are "arch-heretics," accompanied by their followers. More tombs are freighted than the speaker believes, with like buried with like, and monuments differing in degrees of heat. They turn to the right and pass between the afflicted and the high ramparts.

They proceed by a secret pathway between the walls and the tormented souls. The speaker asks Virgil if those in the sepulchres can be seen, as their lids are raised. Virgil replies the lids will be closed when the spirits return from Josaphat with their bodies. He explains that this part of the cemetery holds Epicurus and his followers, who believe the spirit dies with the body. Virgil says the speaker's question and silent wish will soon be satisfied. The speaker clarifies he doesn't hide his heart from Virgil but avoids vain words, a lesson Virgil taught him. A voice from a vault addresses the speaker, recognizing his Tuscan speech and asking him to stay. The voice says it dealt too severely with the speaker's noble land. The speaker, startled, moves closer to Virgil. Virgil tells him to turn and behold Farinata, who has uplifted himself from the girdle upwards. The speaker's eyes are fixed on Farinata, who seems to hold hell in scorn. Virgil pushes the speaker towards Farinata, warning him to speak clearly. Farinata eyes the speaker, then disdainfully asks his ancestors' names. The speaker reveals his lineage. Farinata, lifting his brow, cries that they were fiercely adverse to him, his party, and his blood, and he scattered them twice. The speaker retorts that though driven out, his ancestors returned each time, an art Farinata's party has not learned. Another shade, high as the chin, rises from Farinata's side, leaning on its knees. It looks for others with the speaker, then, seeing its hope quenched, weeps and asks, "Where is my son? and wherefore not with thee?" The speaker replies he comes not of himself but is conducted by Virgil, whom "Guido thy son Had in contempt." The spirit, hearing "HAD," exclaims, "How! said'st thou he HAD? No longer lives he? Strikes not on his eye The blessed daylight?" The speaker's delay in replying makes the spirit fall supine, and he appears no more. Farinata, great of soul, does not change his stern countenance. He continues his discourse, saying that if the speaker's kin have shown small skill in returning, that torments him more than his fiery bed. He predicts that within fifty cycles of the Queen of this realm, the speaker will know the full weight of that art (exile). He asks why the people are so fell against his kin. The speaker attributes it to the slaughter and havoc at Arbia, which stained the flood crimson. Farinata sighs, shakes his head, and says he did not stand singly in that affray, but he alone openly forbade Florence from being razed to the ground when all others consented. The speaker adjures him to solve a knot in his mind: if they (the damned) view beforehand what time leads, but are uninformed of the present. Farinata answers that they view remote objects plainly, "as one who hath an evil sight," by the Almighty Ruler's splendor. But when things approach or exist actually, their intellect fails, and they know nothing of human state except what others bring them. Therefore, all their knowledge will expire when the portals of futurity close. The speaker, conscious of his fault and smitten with remorse, tells Farinata to inform the fallen spirit that his offspring is still living and that his silence was due to his thoughts being occupied by the error Farinata just solved. Virgil calls the speaker back. The speaker asks Farinata who else partakes of his lot. Farinata replies that more than a thousand are laid there, including Frederick II and the Lord Cardinal. He then withdraws. The speaker ruminates on the words foreboding ill for him. Virgil asks about his amazement. The speaker explains. Virgil tells him to store what he heard importing harm and notes that when he stands before the "gracious beam" (Beatrice), she will unfold the future tenor of his life. They turn left, leave the wall, and go by a path to a valley that exhales noisome steam.

They reach the utmost verge of a high bank, environed by craggy rocks, where more cruel woes are stored. To avoid the fetid exhalation from the profound abyss, they stand retired behind the lid of a great monument. On the monument, the speaker reads: "I have in charge Pope Anastasius, whom Photinus drew From the right path." Virgil explains they must delay their descent to accustom the senses to the dire breath. The speaker asks for some compensation for the lost time. Virgil says his thoughts align with the speaker's wishes. He explains that within these rocks are three close circles, each full of accursed spirits. He will explain how and why they abide in durance. Virgil states that all malicious acts abhorred in heaven aim at injury, either by force or fraud. Fraud, being peculiar to man, is more displeasing to God and incurs severer pangs. The violent occupy the first circle, framed in three rounds because force can be offered to three persons: God, one's neighbor, and oneself. Violence against one's neighbor includes death, painful wounds, devastation, pillage, and flames. Slayers, smiters in malice, plunderers, and robbers undergo torment in the first round in different herds. Violence against oneself and one's possessions means depriving oneself of life and light, wasting talent, and sorrowing where one should joy. These are in the second round. Violence against God means denying and blaspheming His power in the heart, and contemning nature and her law. The inmost round marks Sodom, Cahors, and those who speak contemptuously of God. Fraud, which stings every conscience, can be employed on one whose trust is won, or on another who withholds strict confidence. The latter (breaking the bond of love Nature makes) includes dissimulation, witchcraft, flatteries, theft, falsehood, simony, seduction to lust, and pawning honesty. These are in the second circle (of fraud). The former (forgetting Nature's general love and special faith) is for the traitor, eternally consumed in the lesser circle, the "point of the universe, dread seat of Dis." The speaker praises Virgil's clear discourse. He then asks why those in the "dull, fat pool" (the wrathful and sullen), those beaten by rain (gluttons), or driven by tempest (lustful) are not punished within the "city fire-illum'd" (Dis), if God's wrath is on them. And if not, why are they condemned? Virgil asks why his mind wanders. He reminds the speaker of the "ethic page" (Aristotle) describing three dispositions adverse to Heaven's will: incontinence, malice, and mad brutishness. Incontinence offends God least and incurs least guilt. If the speaker notes this judgment and remembers who those outside these walls are (doomed to vain repentance), he will discern why they are placed apart and receive less wreakful divine justice. The speaker, satisfied, then asks Virgil to explain why usury offends celestial Goodness. Virgil explains that philosophy shows how imitative nature takes its course from the celestial mind and its art. The Stagyrite (Aristotle) shows that human art follows nature, making art "second in descent from God." Both nature and art were the right source of life and excellence for humankind. But the usurer walks another path, setting nature and her follower at nought, placing his hope elsewhere. Virgil urges them to continue, as the Pisces are playing, and the Wain (Ursa Major) is over the north-west, indicating it's time to descend the rocky height.

They arrive at a precipice, rough as an Alp, with an object on its verge that every eye would shun. The descent is like a shattered rock face, similar to a ruin caused by the Adige river near Trento. On the disparted ridge lies the "infamy of Crete," the Minotaur, gnawing itself in rage. Virgil addresses the Minotaur, saying the King of Athens (Theseus) is not here, and the speaker comes not by his sister's art (Ariadne's thread) but to behold torments. The Minotaur plunges like a struck bull. Virgil tells the speaker to run to the passage while the monster storms. They descend through dilapidated crags that move under the speaker's feet. The speaker ponders, and Virgil explains that when he first descended to nether hell, this rock was not yet fallen. He believes that not long before Christ (who carried off the "mighty spoil" from Dis), an earthquake seized the deep concave, toppling this old rock. Virgil tells the speaker to look beneath, as the "river of blood" approaches, where those who injured by violence are steeped. The speaker laments blind lust and foolish wrath. He sees an ample foss bent in a bow, circling the plain. Centaurs, armed with keen arrows, run along the trail between the foss and the rampart's base. Three Centaurs advance. One cries, asking what pain they are condemned to and to speak from where they stand, or he will draw his bow. Virgil replies their answer will be made to Chiron when they are nearer. He chides the Centaur for being quick and rash. Virgil identifies the Centaur who spoke as Nessus, who died for Deianira and avenged his own fate. The one in the middle, looking down, is Chiron, who nursed Achilles. The other is Pholus, prone to wrath. Thousands of Centaurs go around the foss, aiming shafts at any spirit that emerges from the blood more than its guilt allows. They approach the Centaurs. Chiron pushes back his beard with an arrow and exclaims to his fellows that the speaker moves what he touches, which the feet of the dead are not wont to do. Virgil, standing near Chiron's breast, explains the speaker is alive and must be shown the gloomy vale by necessity, not delight. He says a joyful harper in the sky (Beatrice) consigned this new office to him. He states he is no robber, nor a dark spirit. He asks Chiron to grant one of his band to guide them to the ford and convey the speaker across on his back, as he is not a spirit who can walk the air. Chiron tells Nessus to return and be their guide, and to command any other troop to keep aloof. They move along the border of the crimson-seething flood with Nessus as their escort. Loud shrieks arise from those steeped within. The speaker sees some immersed up to their brow. Nessus identifies them as tyrants given to blood and rapine, wailing their merciless wrongs. He points out Alexander, and Dionysius. He identifies Azzolino and Obizzo of Este. Virgil tells the speaker to let Nessus be his first leader now. Nessus pauses near some spirits extant from the wave at their throat and points out one apart, exclaiming he "in God's bosom smote the heart, Which yet is honour'd on the bank of Thames." The speaker sees a race holding their heads and busts above the stream, recognizing many faces. The blood becomes shallower, eventually only imbruing their feet, where their passage lies. Nessus explains that as the boiling wave diminishes on this side, it sinks lower on the other, until it rejoins where tyranny mourns. There, Heaven's justice chastises Attila, Sextus, Pyrrhus, and the Rinieri, who filled ways with violence. Nessus turns and repasses the ford alone.

Before Nessus reaches the other bank, they enter a trackless forest. The foliage is dusky, the boughs gnarled and thick, with thorns instead of fruits, filled with venom. The Harpies (human-faced, keen-taloned, huge-bellied, winged) make their nest here, wailing. Virgil explains they are in the second round (of the violent against self) and will be until they reach the horrid sand. He tells the speaker to look around. The speaker hears sad plainings but sees no one. He is amazed. Virgil, thinking the speaker believes the voices come from concealed figures, tells him to lop off a twig from an ill plant, and his thought will vanish. The speaker plucks a branch from a wilding, and the trunk exclaims, "Why pluck'st thou me?" Dark blood trickles down its side, and it adds, "Wherefore tear'st me thus? Is there no touch of mercy in thy breast? Men once were we, that now are rooted here. Thy hand might well have spar'd us, had we been The souls of serpents." Words and blood burst from the broken splinter like a green brand hissing. The speaker drops the bough, terror-stricken. Virgil apologizes to the injured spirit, explaining he prompted the speaker because the thing surpassed belief, and he now rues the deed. He asks the spirit to reveal who he was so the speaker can revive his fame in the upper world. The trunk replies that Virgil's "pleasant word" has inveigled him to speak. He identifies himself as the one who held both keys to Frederick's heart, opening and shutting with such skill that few others could gain admittance. His faith to his charge cost him his life-blood. The "harlot" (Envy), common vice of courts, inflamed minds against him, leading Augustus to spread the flame, changing his honors to woes. His soul, disdainful and disgusted, sought refuge in death from scorn, becoming unjust to himself. He swears by his new roots that he never broke faith with his liege lord and asks the speaker to clear his memory from envy's cruel blow in the world above. Virgil tells the speaker to ask more if he wishes. The speaker, filled with pity, asks Virgil to question the spirit about how the soul is tied in these gnarled joints and if any are ever loosened from such a frame. The trunk breathes hard, and the wind changes into articulate sounds. It explains that when the fierce soul departs the body, torn asunder, it is doomed by Minos to the seventh gulf (this wood). It falls wherever chance hurls it, sprouting like a grain of spelt, growing into a savage plant. Harpies feed on its leaves, causing pain and a vent for grief. They (the suicides) will come for their own spoils (bodies) but will not be clad in them, as it is not just to have what one takes from oneself. Their bodies will be hung on the wild thorns of their shades. While they listen, a noise like a wild boar and hunt approaches. Two naked spirits, torn with briers, flee headlong, breaking through the wood. The foremost cries, "Haste now, now haste thee death!" The other, impatient, exclaims, "Lano! not so bent for speed Thy sinews, in the lists of Toppo's field." He then makes one group of himself and a bush, perhaps from lack of breath. Behind them, the wood is full of black female mastiffs, gaunt and fleet, who stick their fangs into the squatted spirit, rend him piecemeal, and bear away the tortured limbs. Virgil leads the speaker to the thicket, which mourns through its bleeding wounds, crying, "O Giacomo Of Sant’ Andrea! what avails it thee, That of me thou hast made thy screen? For thy ill life what blame on me recoils?" Virgil asks the thicket who he was. The thicket replies, asking the spirits (speaker and Virgil) to gather his severed leaves and lay them at the foot of his parent-tree. He says he dwelt in the city (Florence) that changed its patron from the Baptist, who will ceaselessly work woe on it. If not for a faint glimpse of him on Arno's passage, the citizens who rebuilt its walls after Attila would have toiled in vain. He concludes, "I slung the fatal noose from my own roof."

The speaker, moved by charity for his native land, collects the scattered leaves and restores them to the now hoarse trunk. They reach the limit dividing the second and third rounds, where horrible justice is displayed. They arrive at a wide plain of arid, thick sand, resembling the soil trod by Cato. The mournful wood waves around it, and the sad foss spreads around the wood. The speaker expresses fear of Heaven's vengeance. He sees many flocks of naked spirits, weeping piteously, subjected to different laws: some supine, some crouching, others pacing incessantly. The pacers are more numerous, the supine fewer but louder in grief. Slowly, dilated flakes of fire fall over all the sand, like snow. The eternal fiery flood makes the marble glow underneath, augmenting the pain. Wretched hands unceasingly shake off the falling heat. The speaker asks Virgil about a huge spirit who seems to heed not the burning, but lies writhen in proud scorn. The spirit himself, aware of the question, exclaims he is "Such as I was When living, dead such now I am." He defiantly states that even if Jove wearies out his workmen and launches bolts at him with all his might, he will never enjoy sweet revenge. Virgil, in a raised accent, tells the spirit (Capaneus) he is more punished because his pride lives unquenched, and no torment but his rage could be proportionate. Virgil then tells the speaker that Capaneus was one of the seven kings who besieged Thebes and still holds God in disdain. His despiteful mood suits him. Virgil warns the speaker not to set foot in the hot sand but to keep close to the wood. They pass silently to a little brook gushing from the forest's bound, whose crimsoned wave lifts the speaker's hair with horror. The brook runs through the sand, with stone-built bottom and banks, where their passage lies. Virgil says this river is the most worthy of regard of all they've seen since entering Hell, as the flaming volley is quenched over it. The speaker asks for more knowledge about it. Virgil explains that in the midst of the ocean lies Crete, where in old times the world lived pure. A mountain called Ida rises there, once joyous, now deserted. Rhea chose it for Saturn's son's secret cradle, drowning his cries in shouts. Within the mount, an ancient, huge form stands upright, turning its shoulders towards Damiata and looking at Rome as in a mirror. Its head is finest gold, breast and arms pure silver, middle brass, and downward well-tempered steel, except the right foot of potter's clay, on which it stands more erect. Each part except the gold is rent, and tears distil from the fissure, joining to penetrate a cave. These tears, precipitated down the rock, form Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon. Then, passing beneath through a straitened channel, they form Cocytus, of whose lake Virgil will give no account yet. The speaker asks why, if this sluice is derived from their world, it appears only now.
