Virgil replies the place is round, and though they've passed much, they haven't completed the circuit descending to the nethermost. So, new appearances shouldn't cause wonder. The speaker asks where Phlegethon and Lethe flow, as Virgil mentioned one but not the other as formed from the shower. Virgil says the red seething wave (Phlegethon) could have resolved one question. Lethe will be seen, but not in this hollow, in the place where spirits go to lave themselves after penitence removes their blame. Virgil says it's time to quit the wood and follow his steps, as the margins give safe passage, unimpeded by flames, because all vapor is extinct over them.

They walk on one of the solid margins, enveloped in mist from the stream, which saves both piers and water from fire. The mounds are compared to those built by Flemings or Paduans to keep back the ocean or defend towns. They meet a troop of spirits coming beside the pier, who eye them keenly like an old tailor. One spirit recognizes the speaker by his garb, catches him by the skirt, and cries, "What wonder have we here!" The speaker fixes his gaze on the spirit's parched, fire-smirched looks and recognizes him as Brunetto Latini. He asks, "And art thou here?" Brunetto asks if it would displease the speaker if he turns back a little to speak with him. The speaker eagerly agrees and asks if he can sit with him, if Virgil permits. Brunetto says that whoever stops for an instant in this throng lies for a hundred years without ventilation from the fire. He tells the speaker to pass on, and he will walk close by his garments and then rejoin his troop. The speaker, walking in reverence, keeps his head bent down. Brunetto asks what chance or destiny brings the speaker here before his last day, and who guides him. The speaker replies that in the serene life above, he wandered lost in a valley before his age reached fullness. He met Virgil yesterday morning and is now being led back home by this path. Brunetto says if the speaker follows his star, he will reach a glorious haven, unless Brunetto's judgment erred in fairer days. He would have gladly comforted the speaker if his fate hadn't chanced so early. He warns the speaker that the ungrateful and malignant race from Fesole (Florentines) will show enmity for his good deeds. He advises the speaker to cleanse himself of their ways, as his fortune holds such honor that both parties will crave him. He uses the metaphor of a sweet fig-tree among ill-savored crabs and a fresh herb from a goat's tooth, implying the speaker should avoid the corrupt Florentines. He mentions the "holy seed" (true Romans) remaining in Florence. The speaker replies that if his wish were fulfilled, Brunetto would not have been driven from human nature. He recalls Brunetto's dear, benign, paternal image and how he taught him the way to win eternity, valuing the lesson. He writes down what Brunetto tells him of his fate, keeping it for the "celestial dame" (Beatrice) who will know all. He states his conscience has no plea against him, and he is prepared for whatever fortune brings, letting her speed her wheel as she likes. Virgil turns back, looks at the speaker, and says, "He listens to good purpose who takes note." The speaker continues discoursing with Brunetto, asking who are most known among his tribe. Brunetto says it's good to know some, but silence is best for the rest due to time constraints. He briefly states they were all clerks, learned and renowned, polluted by the same sin. He mentions Priscian and Francesco d'Accorso. He also mentions one who was transferred from Arno's seat to Bacchiglione by the "servants' servant" (Pope Boniface VIII moving Andrea de' Mozzi, Bishop of Florence, to Vicenza). Brunetto says he would add more but must desist, as a new mist rises on the sandy plain, and a company he cannot join approaches. He commends his "TREASURE" (his book, "Tesoretto") to the speaker, his sole request. Brunetto turns and speeds away, seeming like one who gains the prize in a race.

The speaker reaches a place where the water's din is heard falling into the next round, like swarming bees. Three spirits run swiftly from a troop beneath the tormenting storm, crying, "Oh do thou stay! Whom by the fashion of thy garb we deem To be some inmate of our evil land." The speaker sees recent and old wounds on their limbs from the flames, which still grieve him. Virgil pauses and tells the speaker to wait, as these spirits deserve courtesy, and haste would be better for the speaker than for them. When they stop, the three spirits resume their wail, then whirl around in a restless wheel, like naked champions watching for a hold. Each directs his countenance at the speaker. One spirit asks the speaker who he is, walking unharmed through Hell, if their misery calls forth scorn. He identifies his companion as Guidoguerra, grandchild of Gualdrada, a noble man in life. The next is Aldobrandi. He identifies himself as Rusticucci, brought to this evil by his savage wife. The speaker says not scorn, but grief, fixes their doom deep within him. He is a countryman of theirs and has heard of their deeds and names. He is leaving the "gall" for the "sweet fruit" (salvation) guided by Virgil, but must first descend to the center. The spirit asks if courtesy and valor still dwell in Florence, as one recently condemned, Borsiere, brings sad news. The speaker cries out that "An upstart multitude and sudden gains, Pride and excess, O Florence! have in thee Engender'd, so that now in tears thou mourn'st!" The three spirits look at each other, as if hearing truth. They say if he so easily satisfies questioners, he is happy with his words. They ask him to speak of them among mankind if he escapes this dark clime and returns to see the stars. They break the circle and flee swiftly. Virgil pursues his track, and the speaker follows. The sound of water is so near and loud they can barely hear each other. The water falls from a craggy steep, roaring loud, like the Acquacheta river over Saint Benedict, stunning the ear. The speaker had a cord around his girdle, which he once thought to use to bind the "painted leopard." At Virgil's command, he unlooses it, gathers it up, and stretches it to Virgil. Virgil turns right, stands a few paces from the brink, and casts the cord into the deep abyss. The speaker wonders about this strange signal. He reflects on the caution needed with those who spy into thoughts. Virgil says what he expects will come quickly, and the speaker's eye will discover what he is dreaming of. The speaker, despite his earlier reflection on truth and falsehood, swears by his notes that he spied a shape swimming up through the murky air, a sight that might quell the stoutest heart. It comes like someone returning from loosing an anchor, drawing in his feet.

Virgil points out the "fell monster with the deadly sting," who passes mountains, breaks walls, and taints the world with his filth. He beckons it to shore. The vile image of fraud appears, its head and upper part on land, but its bestial train not on shore. Its face resembles a just man's, kind and gracious. The rest is serpent. Two shaggy claws reach to the armpits, and its back, breast, and sides are painted with nodes and orbits, more variegated than any embroidery. It sits perched on the rim of rock, like a skiff or a beaver watching prey. Its tail is upturned in the void, armed with a scorpion's sting. Virgil says they must turn a few steps towards the beast (Geryon). They shape their course to the right, proceeding ten paces on the verge to escape the flame and burning marl. The speaker sees a tribe of spirits seated on the sand near the chasm. Virgil tells the speaker to go and mark their mien but not to hold long discourse, as he will parley with Geryon to vouchsafe the aid of his strong shoulders. The speaker walks alone on the extremity of the seventh circle. Their pangs gush forth at their eyes. They ply their shifting hands against the vapors and torrid soil, like dogs fighting gnats. He notes their visages but recognizes none. He perceives each bears a pouch with various colors and emblems hanging from his neck, on which their eye seems to feed. He sees a yellow purse with azure, bearing a lion's countenance. Another, redder than blood, displays a goose with white wings. One, bearing a fat, azure swine on his white scrip, asks the speaker what he is doing in this deep. He tells the speaker to know that his neighbor Vitaliano will sit on his left, and he is a Paduan among Florentines. He says they often thunder in his ears, exclaiming, "O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch With the three beaks will bring!" The spirit then writhes his mouth and lolls his tongue like an ox. The speaker turns back from these sad spirits. He finds Virgil already seated on Geryon's haunch. Virgil encourages him to be stout and bold for the steep descent. He tells the speaker to mount before him, so he will be in the middle to prevent the tail from harming him. The speaker quivers with fear, like one with an ague fit. But shame makes him bold. He settles on Geryon's huge shoulders, wishing to say, "Look thou clasp me firm!" but the words fail. Virgil, whose succor he has proved before, embraces him and holds him up. Virgil commands Geryon to move, with ample wheeling gyres and easy descent, mindful of the unusual burden. Geryon loosens like a small vessel backing from land, then turns his forked tail where his breast had been. He steers like an eel, gathering air with retractile claws. The speaker's dread is compared to Phaeton losing the reins or Icarus's wings melting. He sees only air and the beast. Geryon slowly wheels downward, unobserved by the speaker except for the wind rising to his face from below. The speaker hears the cataract beneath them with a hideous crash. Bending to explore, he conceives new terror at the steep plunge, seeing flames and hearing wailings. He realizes they are winding downward. Geryon descends like a weary falcon, landing them at the base of the deep-furrowed rock. Discharged of his burden, Geryon springs away like an arrow.

They are in Malebolge, a place of rock stained ferruginous, circling around a spacious, profound gulf. The circle forms ten trenches (bolge) between the gulf and the high craggy banks, like fosses around a castle. Flinty paths (bridges) advance from the rock's base, crossing the moles and dikes to the gulf. They are dislodged from Geryon's back. Virgil goes left, and the speaker follows. On their right, the speaker sees new misery, pains, and executioners in the first chasm, swarming with naked sinners. They come meeting their faces from the middle point, with a larger stride beyond. This movement is compared to Romans during Jubilee, with crowds passing a bridge, some facing the castle, others the mount. Horned demons with huge lashes smite the sinners' backs, making them bound at the first stripe, none waiting for a second or third. The speaker sees one sinner and exclaims he hasn't had his fill of him. Virgil pauses, allowing the speaker to walk backward and scan him. The tormented spirit tries to hide his face, but the speaker exclaims, "Venedico art thou. But what brings thee Into this bitter seas’ning?" Venedico replies unwillingly, constrained by the speaker's clear speech. He confesses he led fair Ghisola to do the Marquis's will. He says Bologna sends many like him, all barterers except Bonturo, quickly making "aye" for lucre. He offers their craving thirst for gold as proof. A demon strikes Venedico with his thong, crying, "Away! corrupter! here Women are none for sale." The speaker rejoins Virgil, and they come to a rock issuing from the bank. They ascend it and turn right, departing from those eternal barriers. They arrive where the gaping arch lets pass the scourged souls. Virgil tells the speaker to pause and look at other miserable faces not yet seen, who have walked with them. From the old bridge, they eye the pack coming from the other side, excoriated from the lash. Virgil, unasked, points out a lofty shade, woe-begone but retaining a regal aspect. This is Jason, who won the ram from Colchos. He beguiled Hypsipyle on Lemnos, leaving her pregnant and forlorn. Medea's injuries are also avenged here. All who practiced similar deceit bear him company. They cross to the next pier, where the path bestrides its shoulders to another arch. In the second chasm, they hear ghosts jibbering in low melancholy sounds, snorting with wide-stretched nostrils, and smiting themselves with their palms. A scurf from foul steam hangs encrusting on the banks, combating sight and smell. The depth is so hollow the speaker can distinguish nothing except from the summit of the rocky span. He sees a crowd immersed in ordure, appearing like human draff. He marks one with his head grimed, hard to deem if clerk or layman. The spirit cries, "Why greedily thus bendest more on me, Than on these other filthy ones, thy ken?" The speaker replies he saw him with dry locks before and recognizes him as Alessio of Lucca. Alessio beats his brain, saying his flatteries sank him here, where he could never glut his tongue enough. Virgil tells the speaker to stretch his face a little further to note the visage of a "besotted, sluttish courtezan" who rends herself with defiled nails. This is Thais, the harlot, whose false lip answered her doting paramour, "Say rather wondrously," when he asked, "Thankest me much!" Virgil says this sight is enough.

The speaker cries "Woe to thee, Simon Magus! woe to you, His wretched followers!" for prostituting God's things for gold and silver. This is the third chasm. They mount the following vault, where the rock impends directly over the center of the foss. The speaker praises Supreme Wisdom's art in allotting just meed. He sees livid stone full of apertures, equal in width and circular, like baptismal fonts in Saint John's dome. He mentions breaking one such font years ago to save a drowning infant, and this serves as proof of his motive. From each aperture, a sinner's feet and legs up to the calf emerge, the rest hidden beneath. The soles of their feet are burning, causing their flexile joints to glance with violent motion. Flames glide from heel to point. The speaker asks who is glancing in fiercer agony, preyed on by a ruddier flame. Virgil offers to carry him down where the slope is least, so the spirit can tell his wrongs himself. The speaker agrees, trusting Virgil. They descend to the depth of the fourth pier, a narrow, perforated strait. Virgil sets the speaker down near the orifice of the quivering limb. The speaker addresses the "sad spirit! thus revers'd, and as a stake Driv'n in the soil!" asking him to utter his voice. The speaker feels like a friar shriving a condemned murderer. The spirit shouts, "Ha! already standest there? Already standest there, O Boniface! By many a year the writing play'd me false. So early dost thou surfeit with the wealth, For which thou fearedst not in guile to take The lovely lady, and then mangle her?" The speaker is bewildered, not understanding the drift of the answer. Virgil admonishes him to quickly say, "I am not he, not he, whom thou believ'st." The speaker replies as enjoined. The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs, asking what the speaker requires. He says if it imports so much to know who he is, he was robed in the "mighty mantle" (papal vestments) and was the son of a she-bear (Orsini family), eager to advance his "whelps" (nephews). He stowed his wealth above and himself here. He says his predecessors in simony are dragged beneath his head, lying along an opening in the rock. He will fall low when the one for whom he mistook the speaker comes. He states that more time has passed since his soul kindled here than the one for whom he waits is doomed to stand. After him, one of "deeds more ugly" will arrive from the west, a "shepherd without law," fated to cover both his form and the speaker's. This new Jason will be shown favor by France's monarch. The speaker, perhaps presuming too far, replies by asking what treasures Christ demanded from St. Peter when giving him the keys. He says Christ asked only "Follow me!" and Peter and the others took no gold or silver for Matthias's place. He tells the spirit his punishment is merited for his ill-gotten coin. He says if not for reverence for the keys, he would use severer speech. He blames avarice for casting the world in mourning, treading good, and raising bad men. He alludes to the Evangelist's vision of the harlot on the waves, saying they made gold and silver their god, differing from idolaters only in worshipping many instead of one. He exclaims, "Ah, Constantine! to how much ill gave birth, Not thy conversion, but that plenteous dower, Which the first wealthy Father gain’d from thee!" As the speaker speaks, the spirit, smitten by wrath or conscience, violently springs up, spinning on his soles. Virgil is pleased, listening with a composed lip. He catches the speaker in his arms and lifts him, retracing their descent. Virgil carries him without weariness to the summit of the rock, their passage from the fourth to the fifth pier. He gently places the speaker on the rugged rock, a path not easy for a goat. Another vale appears to the speaker's view.

The verse proceeds to new torments in the twentieth canto, recording spirits whelmed in woe. The speaker looks into the depth, moistened with tears of anguish, and sees a tribe weeping in silence, walking with backward gait. Each one is wondrously reversed at the neck-bone, so the countenance is averted from the reins, compelling them to advance backward. The speaker says he never saw or believed such a transposition by palsy. The speaker weeps at seeing their distorted form, with tears streaming down their hinder parts. He leans against a rock and weeps. Virgil exclaims, "What, and art thou too witless as the rest? Here pity most doth show herself alive, When she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, Who with Heaven’s judgment in his passion strives?" Virgil tells him to raise his head and see Amphiaraus, for whom earth gaped at Thebes, who fell to Minos. He makes his breast his shoulders, and who once wished to see too far before him, now looks backward and treads his path in reverse. Virgil points out Tiresias, who changed from male to female and back by striking entwining serpents. Next comes Aruns, with more of his belly facing forward, who dwelt in a cavern on Luni's mountains and held boundless view of stars and sea. The next is Manto, whose loosened tresses overspread her bosom. She searched many regions and fixed her seat in Virgil's native land (Mantua). Virgil recounts the origin of Mantua: After Manto's father died, she wandered. A lake, Benacus, lies at the foot of an Alp, watered by many rills. A spot in the middle of the lake is where bishops from Trento, Brescia, and Verona might give benediction. Peschiera stands as a garrison. What Benacus doesn't hold falls down and winds a river, the Mincius, until it falls into the Po. This river finds a wide flat, covering it as a marsh, often pestilent. Manto, the savage maiden, saw this waste, naked territory and remained there with her slaves, practicing her arts, shunning human converse. After her death, tribes gathered there and built a city on her dead bones, calling it Mantua. Virgil warns against other origins. The speaker accepts Virgil's words as certain. He asks if any other spirits here merit especial note. Virgil points out Eurypilus, whose beard sweeps over his shoulders, the seer in Aulis who gave the sign to cut the cable when Greece was emptied of males. Next is Michael Scot, slender in shape, practiced in magic wile. Then Guido Bonatti and Asdente, who now repent not having tended to thread and cordwain. Finally, the wretches who left needle, shuttle, and spindle to become diviners, working baneful witcheries with images and herbs. Virgil says they must move on, as Cain (the moon) now confines on either hemisphere, touching the wave beneath Seville's towers. The moon was round yesternight and served them well in the gloomy wood. They move onward.

They pass from bridge to bridge, reaching the summit to view another gap in Malebolge, with other bootless pangs. Marvelous darkness shadows the place. A glutinous thick mass boils here, not by fire but divine art, like pitch in the Venetian arsenal, liming all the shore beneath. The speaker sees only the surge of the boiling. Virgil exclaims, "Mark! mark!" and draws the speaker towards him. The speaker turns and sees a black devil running up the rock, fierce and cruel, with buoyant wings and nimble feet, proudly bearing a sinner on his shoulder, gripping his foot's sinew. The devil cries to "keen-taloned fiends" of their bridge, "Lo! one of Santa Zita’s elders! Him Whelm ye beneath, while I return for more. That land hath store of such. All men are there, Except Bonturo, barterers: of ‘no’ For lucre there an ‘aye’ is quickly made." The devil dashes the sinner down and turns back. The sinner writhes to the surface. Dark demons shrouded by the bridge cry that the hallowed visage saves not here, and warn the sinner not to mount over the pitch if he doesn't want to be torn. They grapple him with over a hundred hooks, shouting, "Cover’d thou must sport thee here; So, if thou canst, in secret mayst thou filch." This is compared to a cook thrusting flesh into a cauldron. Virgil tells the speaker to bend low and screen himself behind a craggy rock, and not to fear any force or insult offered to him, as Virgil has been in such a fray before. Virgil passes beyond the bridge's head to the sixth pier, needing a terror-proof forehead. The demons rush forth from beneath the arch like dogs, pointing their weapons at Virgil. Virgil tells them not to be outrageous, and asks one to come forth and decide if he shall tear his limbs after hearing his words. They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One advances, asking what this turn will avail Virgil. Virgil replies he would not have come so far without divine will and destiny. He says Heaven's pleasure is that he leads another through this wilderness. Malacoda's pride falls, and he drops his instrument of torture, telling the others they have no power to strike Virgil. Virgil tells the speaker, crouching on the bridge, to return safely. The speaker rises and moves with speed, fearing the fiends might break their compact. He compares it to infantry dreading a foe breaking covenant at Caprona. He adheres to Virgil's side, watching their unkindly visage. The fiends protrude their hooks, one asking another if he should touch the speaker's hip. The other replies, "Even so; nor miss thy aim." Malacoda, in conference with Virgil, turns rapidly and stops Scarmiglione. He tells Virgil and the speaker that the rock provides no further footing, being shivered to the base of the sixth arch. But if they wish to proceed, they can go up by a cavern, where another rock will yield safe passage. He states that yesterday, five hours later than now, 1266 years had passed since the way was broken. He dispatches ten of his scouts (Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo, Barbariccia as leader, Libicocco, Draghinazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane, Farfarello, Rubicant) to espy if any bask on the surface and to lead Virgil and the speaker safely to the other crag. The speaker expresses fear of traveling without escort, seeing them gnarl and threaten. Virgil tells him not to fear, as their gnarls are only signs of spite against the tormented souls. The demons turn left over the pier, each pressing his tongue between his teeth, looking to their leader, who gives an obscene signal.

The speaker describes seeing various military formations in the upper world, but never such a strange movement as the ten demons. He notes the fearful company, comparing it to saints in church and gluttons at a tavern. He gazes at the pitch, marking its contents. Sinners show their backs to ease pain, then hide more nimbly than lightning, like dolphins warning mariners. They stand at the brink like frogs with only their jaws out, but retreat under the wave when Barbariccia approaches. One sinner remains, and Graffiacan seizes his clotted locks, dragging him up like an otter. The speaker knows their names from when they were chosen. The crew shouts for Rubicant to flay the sinner's hide. The speaker asks Virgil who this wretched soul is. Virgil approaches and asks the sinner where he came from. The sinner replies he was born in Navarre, his mother placed him in a lord's retinue, as she bore him to a vile spendthrift. He served King Thibault and turned to peculating, for which he gives account in this heat. Ciriatto, with tusks like a boar, rips him. Barbariccia stops him, seizing the sinner, and tells the others to stand apart while he fixes him on his prong. He tells Virgil to inquire further before the sinner is rent again. Virgil asks about his partners in guilt, if he knows any Latian souls under the tar. The sinner replies he just parted from one not far thence, wishing he were under shelter with him. Libicocco cries, "Too long we suffer," and seizes the sinner's arm with a prong, mangling the sinewy part. Draghinazzo tries to catch his thighs, but Barbariccia restrains them. Virgil asks who the spirit was from whom he parted. The sinner replies it was Friar Gomita of Gallura, a vessel of guile, who had his master's enemies in hand, took money, and dismissed them. He played the part of barterer to the height in other charges. Michel Zanche, chief of Logodoro, herds with him. Sardinia is their constant theme. The sinner points out another, grinning, and says he would say more but fears being mauled. Barbariccia rebukes Farfarello, who rolls his moony eyes, "Off! cursed bird! Avaunt!" The quaking sinner resumes, offering to cause Tuscan or Lombard spirits to appear if the fiends abate their fury. He says he will make seven appear with his whistle. Cagnazzo grins deridingly, wagging his head, saying it's a mischievous device to plunge him down. The sinner replies it's mischief meant only to procure himself more woe. Alichino, gainsaying the rest, says if the sinner casts himself down, he will pursue him with wings above the pitch. He suggests they quit the vantage ground and let the bank be a shield to see if the sinner can prevail singly. The speaker anticipates new sport. The fiends turn their eyes to the other shore. The spirit of Navarre chooses his time, plants his feet on land, and escapes in one leap, disappointing them. Resentment stings the fiends, especially Alichino, who pursues, crying, "Thou art caught." But terror outstrips him. The sinner plunges beneath the pitch, and Alichino raises his breast with upward pinion, like a falcon whose prey dives. Calcabrina, enraged, flies after Alichino, turning his talons on his comrade for the barterer's escape. They grapple over the dyke and fall into the boiling lake. The heat becomes umpire, gluing their pennons. Barbariccia dispatches four others (armed) from the other coast to their posts to stretch hooks toward the struggling fiends. The speaker and Virgil depart, leaving them to the broil.

They go in silence and solitude, like minor friars. The fray makes the speaker muse on Aesop's fable of the mouse and frog. He fears the fiends, foiled and mocked, will pursue them more fellly. His hair stands on end, and he looks back. He tells Virgil to hide them quickly from the "evil talons," as he already feels them. Virgil replies that his thoughts came to him with similar act and countenance, so he has formed one design. If the right coast inclines enough, they can descend into the other chasm and escape. Before Virgil finishes, the speaker sees the fiends approaching with spread wings. Virgil catches him like a mother snatching her babe from climbing fires, and casts himself supine down from the jutting beach to a pendent rock that closes on the other chasm. Virgil runs along the edge, carrying the speaker in his bosom, faster than water turning a mill wheel. They reach the lowest bed beneath just as the fiends reach the steep above them. But the fiends have no power to depart from the fifth foss, as high Providence placed them there. In the depth, they see a "painted tribe" pacing slowly, weeping, faint and toiled. They wear caps with hoods like Cologne monks, overlaid with dazzling gold outside, but leaden within and so heavy that Frederick's cloaks were straw by comparison. They turn left with the hypocrites. The people move so slowly that their company changes with every step. The speaker asks Virgil to find a spirit known by his deeds. One spirit, hearing the Tuscan voice, cries for them to stop, saying the speaker might obtain his wish from him. Virgil tells the speaker to pause and then proceed at their pace. The speaker waits and sees two spirits eager to overtake him, but their load and the narrow path slow them. They eye him askance, then confer, noting he seems alive and asking what privilege allows him to walk unmantled. They ask the speaker, a Tuscan visiting the "college of mourning hypocrites," to tell them who he is. The speaker replies he was bred in Florence by the Arno and wears the body he has always worn. He asks who they are and what torment causes their grief. One replies their bonnets, gleaming bright with orange, are so leaden gross they crack balances. They were "joyous friars," natives of Bologna, Catalano (the speaker) and Loderingo, taken by Florence as arbiters to reconcile strifes. Gardingo's vicinage can declare how they sped. The speaker begins to speak of their miseries but stops, seeing a spirit fixed to a cross with three stakes on the ground. This spirit writhes and sighs. Catalano explains that this pierced spirit gave the Pharisees counsel that it was fitting for one man to suffer for the people. He lies transverse, and everyone must make trial of his weight. The father of his consort and other partakers in that council are placed in similar straits. The speaker notes Virgil's wonder at Caiaphas. Virgil asks the friar if there is an opening in the rock on their right to exit without constraint from the dark angels. Catalano replies that nearer than Virgil hopes, a rock from the next circle oversteps each vale of horror, but its cope is shattered here. They can mount by the ruin, as it slants and rises below. Virgil stands with head bent, then says, "He warn’d us ill, Who yonder hangs the sinners on his hook" (referring to Malacoda). Catalano replies that at Bologna, he heard many vices of the devil, including that "He is a liar, And the father of lies!" Virgil proceeds with large strides, disturbed with anger. The speaker leaves the heavy-laden spirits and follows Virgil's footsteps.

The speaker describes his guide's initial troubled forehead and quick recovery, comparing it to a peasant disheartened by winter then finding new hope. They arrive at the fallen bridge. Virgil turns to him with a sweet look, like the one at the mountain's foot. Virgil, after considering the ruin, takes the speaker up. He lifts him to the summit of one peak, then fixes his eye on another, telling him to grapple it and test its strength. The speaker notes this is no easy journey even for light people, and his strength would have failed if the precinct were not less ample. Malebolge inclines towards the mouth of the nethermost abyss, so each valley slopes upward on one side and falls on the other. They reach the point of descent from the last flag. The speaker is exhausted and sits down. Virgil urges him to use his "best of man," as fame is not won by resting. He tells him to rise, vanquish weariness by mind's effort, as a longer ladder remains to scale, and escaping these suffices not. The speaker rises, showing less exhaustion than he felt, crying, "On, For I am stout and fearless." They hold their way up the rock, more rugged, narrower, and steeper. The speaker talks to seem less faint. A voice from the other foss issues forth, ill-suited for utterance. The speaker, standing on the arch, doesn't know the words but perceives anger. He stoops to look but cannot see due to darkness. He asks Virgil to bend their steps to the next circle and dismount, as he hears but understands not, and sees nothing. Virgil replies he will answer by deed, as silent performance is best return to fair request. They descend from the bridge's head to the eighth mound. The chasm opens to view, and the speaker sees a crowd of terrible, strange, and hideous serpents. He says Libya cannot boast of such a brood. Naked spirits run among this "dread exuberance of woe," winged with horrid fear, with no hope of hiding. Their hands are bound behind them with serpents, which twist their tails and heads in folds before their reins. An adder darts up and transpierces one spirit near them at the neck. More quickly than pen writes O or I, he kindles, burns, and changes to ashes. The dust spontaneously re-rolls and instantly resumes the self-same form, like the Arabian Phoenix. The sinner stands aghast when he rises. The speaker laments God's severe judgment. Virgil asks who he is. He answers, "Vanni Fucci am I call’d, Not long since rained down from Tuscany To this dire gullet. Me the beastial life And not the human pleas’d, mule that I was, Who in Pistoia found my worthy den." The speaker asks Virgil to bid him stay and ask his crime, as he knew him as choleric and bloody. Vanni Fucci, hearing, directs his mind and face (depicting dismal shame) to the speaker. He says it grieves him more to be caught in this sad plight by the speaker than when he was taken from the other life. He cannot deny what is inquired. He is doomed here for rifling the sacristy of its ornaments and falsely charging another. To prevent the speaker from rejoicing, he forebodes: Pistoia will first pine, reft of the Neri. Then Florence will change citizens and laws. A vapor from Valdimagra, drawn by Mars, will rise, wrapped in mists, driving a storm with arrows over Piceno's field, bursting to strike helpless Biancos to the ground. He tells this to rend the speaker's heart.

After Vanni Fucci speaks, he raises his hands in mockery, crying, "Take them, God! I level them at thee!" From that day, the serpents are the speaker's friends. One twists around Vanni Fucci's neck, as if saying, "Be silent, tongue!" Another glides up his arms, riveting itself to take away their power to move. The speaker laments Pistoia's evil. He saw no spirit swell so proudly against God, not even the one who fell headlong from Thebes. Vanni Fucci flees without uttering more. A centaur full of fury comes after him, shouting, "Where Where is the caitiff?" Serpents swarm on his haunch up to his human face, more than on Maremma's marsh. Behind his head, on his shoulders, lies a dragon with open wings, breathing fire on whomever he meets. Virgil identifies him as Cacus, who spread a lake of blood under Aventine rock. He is here for his fraudful theft of the great herd, and his felon deeds ended beneath Alcides' mace, which struck him a hundred blows. The centaur speeds away. Three spirits come up under them, unnoticed until they exclaim, "Say who are ye?" The speaker and Virgil break off discourse. The speaker doesn't know them, but one names another, "Where doth Cianfa lurk?" The speaker signals Virgil to be attentive. He tells the reader not to marvel if he doesn't credit what follows, as he himself barely believes his eyes. A six-footed serpent springs onto one spirit, fastening upon him: its middle grasps the belly, forefeet seize arms, fangs flesh cheeks, hinder feet spread on thighs, and tail curls on the reins. The monster intertwines with the spirit like ivy on an oak. Both melt into each other like burning wax, mingling hues until neither is seen. This is compared to shrinking paper turning brown before burning. The other two spirits exclaim, "Ah, how dost thou change, Agnello! See! Thou art nor double now, Nor only one." The two heads now become one, and two figures blend into one form, where both are lost. Two arms are made from four lengths. The belly, chest, thighs, and legs change into members never seen. All trace of former shape vanishes. The miscreated image passes on with tardy steps. Another adder, all on fire, livid and swart like a dark pepper-grain, approaches the entrails of the other two, like a lizard flashing across a road. It transpierces one where life is nourished first. The pierced spirit falls, looks on the serpent, motionless and yawning as if by sleep or fever. The serpent eyes the spirit, and the spirit the serpent. One breathes thick smoke from the wound, the other from the mouth, their vapory columns joining. The speaker says Lucan and Ovid cannot describe such a transmutation. The serpent splits its train into a fork, and the pierced spirit draws his steps together, legs and thighs compacted. The tail takes the spirit's lost figure, its skin softening, his indurating to a rind. The shoulders join the monster's armpits. The monster's two shorter feet lengthen as the other's shrink. The feet behind twist up to become the part man conceals, which in the wretch is cleft in twain. Shadowy smoke veils both with new color, generating an excrescent pile on one, peeling it off the other. One rises upright, the other falls prone. Their eyes are not yet shifted, though features change. The standing one's face retreats towards the temples, superfluous matter shoots out as ears, the rest shapes the nose, and lips swell. The one on the earth extends his sharpened visage, draws down his ears like a slug's horns. His continuous tongue severs, and the other's fork closes. The smoke is laid. The soul transformed into the brute glides off, hissing. The other, talking, sputters, then turns his new-grown shoulders and tells another, "Along this path Crawling, as I have done, speed Buoso now!" The speaker saw the "unsteady ballast of the seventh hold" fluctuate in change. He notes his confusion and amazement. He marks Sciancato, who alone of the first three did not change. He alludes to Gaville still ruing the other's fate.

The speaker exults Florence, but then expresses shame that three of its citizens were found among the plunderers, bringing no honor. He forebodes ill for Florence, wishing it would come sooner to lessen his future grief. They depart the depth, Virgil scaling the flinty steps, drawing the speaker up. They use hands and feet among the crags. Sorrow seizes the speaker as he recalls what he saw, curbing his natural powers lest they run where Virtue guides not. He sees the eighth chasm shining with numberless flames, like fire-flies in a valley at dusk. Each flame envelops a sinner so closely that none exhibits token of the theft. The speaker bends forward on the bridge, grasping a flinty mass to avoid falling. The guide, who marked how he gazed, explains that within these ardors are spirits "Swath'd in confining fire." The speaker says Virgil's words assure him, but he already suspected and wished to ask who is in the flame that comes so parted at the summit, like the Theban brothers' funeral pile. Virgil replies that Ulysses and Diomede endure penal tortures there, hasting to vengeance as they once did to wrath. They deplore the ambush of the horse that opened a portal for Rome's seed, the guile that reft Achilles from Deidamia (who still complains in death), and the stratagem that spoiled Troy of its Palladium. The speaker asks Virgil to pause the flame so he can speak to them. Virgil praises his prayer but tells him to refrain his tongue, as Virgil will question them, divining his wish, and they, being Greeks, might shun discourse with the speaker. When the flame arrives, Virgil asks the two spirits in one fire to speak, if he merited anything from them in life by his lofty strain, and unfold how death overtook them. The greater horn of the old flame rolls, murmuring like fire in wind, then wags its top like a tongue and speaks. He (Ulysses) recounts escaping Circe, who held him for over a year. Neither fondness for his son, reverence for his father, nor love for Penelope could overcome his zeal to explore the world and search the ways of life, man's evil and virtue. He sailed into the deep illimitable main with one bark and a small faithful band, seeing shores from Iberia to Morocco, and islands. Old and weary, they reached the strait where Hercules ordained boundaries not to be overstepped. He left Seville's walls to his right and passed Ceuta. He addressed his brothers, urging them not to refuse proof of the unpeopled world, following Phoebus, reminding them they were not formed to live like brutes but to pursue virtue and high knowledge. These words sharpened his associates' minds. They turned their poop to the dawn, making oars their wings, gaining on the left. They saw stars of the other pole, and their own so low it rose not from the ocean. Five times the moon's light vanished since they entered the deep way, when a dim, lofty mountain appeared. Joy seized them, but soon changed to mourning. A whirlwind sprung from the new land, striking the vessel's foremost side. It whirled the bark thrice, then lifted the poop and sank the prow, and the booming billow closed over them.

The flame (Ulysses and Diomede) rises and stills its light, then passes on. Another flame comes, from whose top a confused sound issues. The sound turns into dismal words, like the Sicilian bull rebellowing with the voice of the tormented. As the words win passage forth from the flame's vibrating point, they hear: "O thou! to whom I now direct my voice! That lately didst exclaim in Lombard phrase, ‘Depart thou, I solicit thee no more,’ Though somewhat tardy I perchance arrive Let it not irk thee here to pause awhile, And with me parley: lo! it irks not me And yet I burn." The spirit asks about the state of Romagna (peace or war), as he is from the mountains between Urbino and the source of the Tiber. Virgil tells the speaker to speak, as the spirit is a Latian. The speaker replies that Romagna has never been without war in its tyrants' bosoms, nor is now, but he left no open war. Ravenna's state is steadfast under Polenta's eagle, overshadowing Cervia. The "green talons" (Malatesta family) grasp the land that resisted the French. He mentions the "old mastiff of Verruchio and the young" (Malatesta da Verrucchio and his son Malatestino), who tore Montagna, still making an auger of their fangs. Lamone's city (Faenza) and Santerno's range (Imola) are under the "lion of the snowy lair" (Maghinardo Pagani), an inconstant partisan. The city washed by Savio's wave (Cesena) lives between tyrant power and liberty. The speaker asks the spirit to identify himself. The fire roars, its sharpened point waving. It replies that if it thought its answer were to one who could return to the world, the flame would rest unshaken. But since no one from this depth has found an upward way, it answers without fear of infamy. The spirit says he was a man of arms, then clothed himself in Saint Francis's girdle, hoping to make amends. His hope would not have failed, but the "high priest" (Pope Boniface VIII) seduced him back to sin. He explains that while alive, his deeds were more like a fox than a lion, full of winding subtlety, his fame reaching the world's limit. When he reached the part of life where one lowers sails, he rued his past and turned to repentance and confession. The "chief of the new Pharisees" (Boniface VIII), waging war near the Lateran, not against Saracens or Jews but Christians, neither revered his charge nor the Franciscan cord. This man (Boniface VIII) sought the spirit's counsel to cure the fever of his pride, asking how to make Penestrino (Palestrina) cumber earth no more. The spirit was silent, finding Boniface's words drunken. But Boniface resumed, telling him to banish fear, absolving him of all offense, in return for counsel on how to execute his purpose. Boniface claimed power to shut and open heaven, holding two keys. Yielding to the arguments, and deeming silence more perilous, the spirit answered, "Father! since thou washest me Clear of that guilt wherein I now must fall, Large promise with performance scant, be sure, Shall make thee triumph in thy lofty seat." When he died, Saint Francis came for him, but a dark cherub met him, crying, "Wrong me not; he is mine, And must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave." The cherub explained that the impenitent cannot be absolved, and to repent and will at once are contradictory. The spirit shook himself as the cherub seized him, who then said, "Thou haply thought’st me not A disputant in logic so exact." The cherub bore him to Minos, who twined his tail eight times around his back, biting it in rage, saying, "This is a guilty soul, that in the fire Must vanish." Hence, the spirit roves, a prey to rankling sorrow in this garb. When he had thus fulfilled his words, the flame in dolour parted, beating to and fro, and writhing its sharp horn. The speaker and Virgil go up along the rock to another arch overhanging the foss where those who load themselves with committed sin pay penalty.

The speaker describes the impossibility of fully telling of the wounds and blood he now saw in the ninth chasm, comparing it to the vast numbers of slain in Apulia or at Tagliacozzo. He saw one torn from chin to hinder passage, his entrails dangling, midriff and ventricle open. This spirit (Mohammed), eyeing the speaker, lays his breast bare and cries, "Now mark how I do rip me! lo! How is Mohammed mangled! before me Walks Ali weeping, from the chin his face Cleft to the forelock; and the others all Whom here thou seest, while they liv’d, did sow Scandal and schism, and therefore thus are rent." A fiend behind hacks them cruelly with a sword, slivering them again after their gashes close as they complete the dismal way and repass before him. Mohammed asks who the speaker is, lingering to delay pain. Virgil replies that death has not overtaken him, nor does sin lead him to torment. He is dead and must conduct the living speaker through hell to make full trial of their state. More than a hundred spirits stand amazed, forgetting their pangs. Mohammed, with foot upraised, warns the speaker to bear tidings to Dolcino: if he doesn't wish to follow him soon, he should arm himself with food, lest imprisoning snows make him a victim to Novara's power. Mohammed fixes his foot to depart. Another shade, pierced in the throat, mutilated nostrils, and one ear lopt off, advances. He bares his windpipe, smeared with crimson. He asks the speaker to recall Piero of Medicina if he returns to the pleasant land from Vercelli to Mercabo. He instructs the speaker to tell Guido and Angelo, Fano's worthiest sons, that if the future can be scanned here, they will be cast forth from life and whelmed under waves near Cattolica through a fell tyrant's perfidy. Neptune never saw such foul injury by pirates. That one-eyed traitor will bring them to conference, then shape their end so they won't need to pray against Focara's wind. The speaker asks who the one-eyed traitor is, whose sight wakes such sad remembrance. Piero lays his hand on another spirit's cheek-bone, expanding his jaws, and cries, "Lo! this is he I wot of; He speaks not for himself: the outcast this Who overwhelm’d the doubt in Caesar’s mind, Affirming that delay to men prepar’d Was ever harmful." Another, maimed of each hand, lifts his bleeding stumps, staining his face, and cries, "Remember thee Of Mosca, too, I who, alas! exclaim’d, “The deed once done there is an end,” that prov’d A seed of sorrow to the Tuscan race." The speaker adds, "Ay, and death to thine own tribe." Mosca hurries off, grief-stung to madness. The speaker lingers to behold the troop. He sees a headless trunk, pacing onward, bearing its severed head lantern-wise in hand, which looks at them and says, "Woe's me!" The spirit lights himself thus, being two in one and one in two. At the bridge's foot, he rears his arm, thrusting the head into view, and says, "Now behold This grievous torment, thou, who breathing go’st To spy the dead; behold if any else Be terrible as this. And that on earth Thou mayst bear tidings of me, know that I Am Bertrand, he of Born, who gave King John The counsel mischievous. Father and son I set at mutual war. For Absalom And David more did not Ahitophel, Spurring them on maliciously to strife. For parting those so closely knit, my brain Parted, alas! I carry from its source, That in this trunk inhabits. Thus the law Of retribution fiercely works in me."

The speaker's eyes are inebriated with the view of the vast multitude, disfigured by wounds, making him long to stay and weep. Virgil rouses him, asking why he gazes below at the maimed and miserable shades, noting he hasn't shown this weakness before. He reminds him the valley winds twenty-two miles, the moon is beneath their feet, time is short, and more remains to be seen. The speaker replies that if Virgil had weighed the cause for his looking, he would have excused his tarrying. He adds that in a cave where he fixed his ken, a spirit of his blood dwells, wailing a crime that costs him dear. Virgil tells him not to afflict his soul for him, but to direct his thought elsewhere. He says he marked the spirit (Geri of Bello) pointing menacingly at the speaker at the bridge's foot, but the speaker was too busy with the spirit who once ruled Hautefort (Bertrand de Born) to notice. The speaker explains that Geri's violent, unavenged death made him contemptuous, which is why he passed speechless, making the speaker more compassionate. They discourse until the rock shows the other valley, which would have more light if it weren't for the depth. They come over the last cloister of Malebolge, and a volley of lamentations, headed with thrilling pity, assails the speaker, making him close his ears. The torment is compared to all the maladies of Valdichiana, Sardinia, and Maremma's fen heaped in one foss. The stench is dire. They descend to the left on the utmost shore of the long rock. The speaker's sight is livelier to explore the depth where Justice punishes forgers. He compares the sight to the nation of Aegina drooping from malice in the air (from which the people were restored from emmet seed, as bards told), but finds this worse. Spirits languish, piled on stacks, confusedly lying one over another, or crawling sideling. They journey in silence, looking and listening to the diseased, who strive in vain to lift their forms. He marks two sitting propped against each other like brazen pans. From head to foot, a tetter barks them round. They ply their keen nails quickly due to furious, unabated pruriency, drawing crust in flakes like fish scales. Virgil asks one, who is rending off his "coat of proof" with his fingers, if any Latian-born are among them. The weeping spirit replies both are of Latium and asks who the speaker is. Virgil replies he is one descending with a living man to show him hell's abyss. The spirits start asunder, trembling. Virgil tells the speaker to speak to them. The speaker asks them to identify themselves and their race, hoping their remembrance will not be lost in the upper world. One answers he dwelt in Arezzo and was brought to die by fire by Albero of Sienna. But his death's cause is not why he is here. He told Albero in sport he learned to fly, and Albero, void of wisdom, wanted to know his art. Because he didn't make him a Daedalus, Albero prevailed on his supposed father to burn him. Minos doomed him to this chasm, the last of the ten, for practicing alchemy on earth. The speaker asks if any race is as light (frivolous) as Sienna's. The other leprous spirit (Capocchio) overhears and replies, exempting Stricca (who used fortune's gifts temperately) and Niccolo (who discovered spice luxury in a garden where such seed roots deepest). He also exempts Caccia of Asciano (who lavished vineyards and woods) and Abbagliato (who showed rare wisdom). He tells the speaker to look closely to see he is Capocchio's ghost, who forged transmuted metals by alchemy, and if he scans him right, he must remember how he aped creative nature.

The speaker describes the frenzies of Athamas (who killed his son Learchus, and his wife Ino plunged to death) and Hecuba (who barked like a dog after seeing Polyxena and Polydorus slain), comparing them to the Furies. He sees two pale, naked ghosts scampering wildly, gnarling like swine. One reaches Capocchio and, sticking deep his fangs in the neck-joint, drags him, rubbing his belly prone on the pavement. The other shape, the one from Arezzo, left trembling, says, "That sprite of air is Schicchi; in like mood Of random mischief vents he still his spite." The speaker asks the spirit to identify the other before it speeds hence. The spirit replies that it is the ancient soul of wretched Myrrha, who burned with unholy flame for her father and assumed a false shape to commit sin. The other (Schicchi) dared to counterfeit Donati's features to affix a seal to a feigned testament to gain the "lady of the herd" (a mare). When the two furious shades vanish, the speaker turns to view other cursed spirits. He sees one shaped like a lute, if the groin were severed, disproportionate with dropsy, his paunch not suiting his visage. He gasps with open lips, one curled towards the chin, the other upward. The dropsied spirit, Adamo, addresses the speaker, asking him to regard his woe. He says he never lacked what he coveted in life, but now craves one drop of water. The rills of Casentino are always in his view, and their pictured semblance dries him more than the disease. Justice quickens his sighs from the place where he transgressed. He says he falsified metal with the Baptist's form (Florentine florins) at Romena, for which his body was burnt on earth. He would not change Branda's limpid spring for the sight of Guido, Alessandro, or their brother (the Counts Guidi) if they were here. He says one is within, if mad spirits tell truly, but his limbs are fettered. If he could move one inch every hundred years, he would seek them out. They brought him down here, inducing him to stamp florins with three carats of alloy. The speaker asks about two abject spirits smoking beside Adamo. Adamo replies he found them here when he dropped into this gulf, and they have not turned since. One is the false accuser of the Hebrew youth, the other is Sinon, the false Greek from Troy. Sharp fever drains their moistness, steaming up in a cloud. Sinon, galled by being named, smites Adamo on the paunch, which resounds like a drum. Adamo returns the blow to Sinon's face. Adamo says though his limbs are heavy, he has an arm for such employ. Sinon replies he didn't have it so ready when he went to the fire, but readier when he coined impostor gold. Adamo retorts that Sinon didn't give true testimony when questioned at Troy. Sinon says if he spoke false, Adamo falsely stamped the coin, and he is here for one fault, Adamo for more than any imp. Adamo reminds Sinon of the horse that teemed with death, and calls the world witness to his guilt. Sinon returns, calling the thirst that cracks Adamo's tongue witness to his guilt, and the fluid mound of his belly. Adamo says Sinon's mouth gapes wide for evil saying, and though Adamo has thirst, he is stuffed with moisture, while Sinon is parched and racked with head pains, needing no urging to lap Narcissus' mirror. The speaker is fixed on listening. Virgil admonishes him, "Now beware: a little more, And I do quarrel with thee." The speaker, ashamed, wishes to excuse himself but cannot speak. Virgil says less shame might expiate a more grievous fault than the speaker's. He tells him to cast all sorrow from his soul, and if chance brings him to such a conference again, to remember Virgil is at his side, as such wrangling is a joy for vulgar minds.

The tongue that wounded the speaker now cures him, like Achilles' javelin. They turn their back on the vale of woe, crossing the mound in silence. In the dim twilight, the speaker hears a horn sounded aloud, its peal making thunder feeble. He strains his eyes towards the sound, comparing it to Orlando's blast at Charlemagne's rout. He sees many lofty towers. He asks Virgil what land this is. Virgil replies his eye has too long a space of darkness to traverse, so he erred. He will see how distance deludes the sense. Virgil tenderly catches his hand and explains these are not towers but giants, immersed from their navel downward around the bank. As fog disperses, the speaker's error flees, and fear comes over him. The shore is turreted with giants, half their length rearing, horrible, whom Jove still threatens. He discerns the face, shoulders, breast, great part of the belly, and both arms of one giant. Nature displayed wisdom in framing these monsters, taking them as slaves for mad War. She is wiser for the elephant and whale, for when brute force and evil will are backed with subtlety, no resistance avails. The giant's face is as long and bulky as Saint Peter's pine. His stature from the bank is so high that three Friezelanders couldn't reach his hair. He is exposed thirty palms downward from where a man loops his garments. The giant shouts, "Raphel bai ameth sabi almi." Virgil addresses the giant (Nimrod) as a senseless spirit, telling him to interpret with his horn and vent his rage. He points out the belt on his neck and the baldric on his breast. Virgil tells the speaker Nimrod accuses himself, and through his ill counsel, one tongue no longer prevails in the world. They must pass on, as his language is understood by none, like his to others. They turn left and find another, fiercer, huger shade at a sling's throw. This giant (Ephialtes) is fettered behind his right arm and before with a chain from neck down, meeting five times around his form. Virgil says this proud one tried his strength against Jove, and is thus requited. He was great in prowess when giants brought fear on gods, but now moves his arms never. The speaker wishes to see Briareus. Virgil replies they will see Antaeus not far hence, who speaks and is unfettered, and will place them where guilt is at its depth. Briareus stands further on, in chains, like Ephialtes but more fell. Ephialtes shakes like a tower rocked by earthquake. The speaker fears death, but the cords hold him fast. They journey to Antaeus, who issues five ells complete without the head from the cave. Virgil addresses Antaeus, recalling his strength in the fortunate vale (Africa) where Scipio defeated Hannibal, and how he carried a hundred lions as spoil. He suggests that if Antaeus had fought with his giant brethren, men might believe they would have conquered. Virgil asks Antaeus to place them down where cold locks up Cocytus, not forcing them to crave Tityus' or Typhon's help. He says the speaker can bestow renown on Antaeus in the upper world, as he lives and hopes for longer life. Antaeus stretches his hands and catches Virgil. Virgil catches the speaker, making them one burden. Antaeus stoops like the leaning tower of Carisenda. The speaker wishes he could have passed another way. Antaeus lightly places them in the abyss, where Lucifer ingulfs Judas, then rises like a stately mast.

The speaker wishes for rough rhymes to suit this "hole of sorrow," the depth of the universe, a mighty theme. He invokes the Muses who helped Amphion wall Thebes. He laments the wretched folk who abide in such a mansion. They stand in the dark pit beneath the giants' feet, but lower. A voice warns the speaker, "Look how thou walkest. Take Good heed, thy soles do tread not on the heads Of thy poor brethren." The speaker turns and sees a lake of frozen surface, like glass, thicker than the Danube or Tanais in winter. If Tabernich or Pietrapana fell on it, not even its rim would creak. Spirits stand low, blue-pinched and shrined in ice, moving their teeth like storks, with faces downward, their mouths expressing cold, their eyes dolour. He sees two so strictly joined their hair is mingled. He asks who they are. They bend their necks, lift their looks, and their moist eyes distill tears onto their lips, which the frost binds. They clash together like enraged goats. One, whose ears are reft by cold, asks why the speaker speculates so long. He identifies the two as sons of Alberto, master of the valley where Bisenzio slopes, issued from one body. He says Caina holds no shade more worthy of congealment, not him whose breast and shadow Arthur's land dissevered, nor Focaccia, nor the spirit whose head obstructs his view (Mascheroni). He identifies himself as Camiccione. He awaits his kinsman Carlino, whose deep guilt will wash out his own. The speaker marks a thousand visages shaped into a doggish grin by the cold, causing shivering horror. As they journey towards the middle, the speaker's foot strikes the face of one spirit. The spirit weeps, "Wherefore dost bruise me? Unless thy errand be some fresh revenge For Montaperto, wherefore troublest me?" The speaker asks Virgil to wait so he can rid himself of doubt. Virgil pauses. The speaker asks the spirit, who curses him, who he is. The spirit asks who the speaker is, roaming Antenora and striking others' cheeks with such force. The speaker replies he is living, to the spirit's joy perhaps, if fame is dear, that he may enroll his name. The spirit says the speaker offers the contrary of what he covets most and tells him to vex him no more. The speaker seizes his hinder scalp and demands his name, threatening to pull out his hair. The spirit replies he will not tell, though plucked a thousand times. The speaker grasps his tresses and strips off more than one tuft. The spirit barks, eyes drawn in. Another cries, "What ails thee, Bocca? Sound not loud enough Thy chatt’ring teeth, but thou must bark outright? What devil wrings thee?" The speaker tells Bocca he will bear true tidings of his shame. Bocca replies to tell what he lists, but to speak of "Him of Duera" (Buoso da Duera), who wails for the Frenchman's gold, and Beccaria, whose gorge was stained by Florence's axe. Further on are Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello (who opened Faenza). They leave Bocca. The speaker sees two spirits pent in one hollow by the ice, the head of one a cowl to the other. The uppermost gnaws the other's brain where the spine joins it, more furiously than Tydeus gnawed Menalippus. The speaker asks the gnawing spirit the cause of his hate, promising to repay him in the world above if his grievance is warranted.

The gnawing sinner lifts his jaws from his repast, wipes them on the hair of the mangled head, and begins to speak. He says recounting his sorrow past cure wrings his heart, but if his words bring eternal infamy to the traitor he gnaws at, the narrator will see him speak and weep. He doesn't know who the speaker is or how he came, but he seems Florentine. He identifies himself as Count Ugolino and the other as Archbishop Ruggieri. He explains he trusted Ruggieri's ill thoughts, was taken, and murdered. He will tell the speaker the cruel murder, which he cannot have heard. A small grate in the "mew" (tower), named Famine for his sake, where others must pine, had shown him several moons. He slept an evil sleep that tore the curtain from the future. He dreamt Ruggieri, as master of the sport, rode to chase a gaunt wolf and its whelps (Ugolino and his sons) to the mountain that forbids Lucca to Pisa. Lanfranchi, Sismondi, and Gualandi were with him. After a short course, the father and sons seemed tired, and he saw sharp tusks gore their sides. He awoke before dawn and heard his sons (who were with him) weeping and asking for bread. He addresses the speaker, saying he is cruel if he feels no pang at this. The hour they usually brought food drew near. Each son misgave him through his dream. Ugolino heard the horrible tower locked up. He looked at his sons' visages, not weeping, feeling all stone within. His sons wept. Little Anslem cried, "Thou lookest so! Father what ails thee?" Ugolino shed no tear, nor answered that day or the next night. When a faint beam entered their prison on the third day, he saw his own image in his sons' four countenances. In agony, he bit his hands. His sons, thinking he did it from hunger, rose and cried, "Father, we should grieve Far less, if thou wouldst eat of us: thou gav’st These weeds of miserable flesh we wear, And do thou strip them off from us again." To avoid making them sadder, he kept his spirit still. That day and the next, they were silent. He laments the earth not opening. On the fourth day, Geddo flung himself at Ugolino's feet, crying, "Hast no help For me, my father!" There he died. Ugolino saw the other three fall one by one between the fifth and sixth day. Then, grown blind, he groped over them all for three days, calling on them. "Then fasting got The mastery of grief." Having spoken, he fastens his teeth once more on the wretched skull. The speaker then laments Pisa, calling it a shame to its region, and wishes Capraia and Gorgona would rise and dam the Arno's mouth so all in Pisa might perish. He argues that even if Ugolino betrayed castles, Pisa had no right to rack his children (Brigata, Ugaccione, and the two gentle ones), whose tender years made them incapable of guilt. They pass on to where others are "skarf'd in rugged folds of ice," reversed, not on their feet. Here, weeping suffers not to weep, as grief finds impediment at their eyes, rolling inward to increase anguish. The first tears hang clustered like crystal vizors. Though the cold has dislodged feeling from his face, the speaker feels a breath of wind. He asks Virgil its source, thinking all vapor is quenched. Virgil replies he will soon be where his eye will tell him the cause of this "airy shower." One spirit in the chill crust cries out, asking the cruel souls to remove the hardened veil from his face so he can vent his grief before it congeals again. The speaker asks who he was, promising aid, and if he fails, he will descend to the lowest ice. The spirit answers, "The friar Alberigo am I, who from the evil garden pluck’d Its fruitage, and am here repaid, the date More luscious for my fig." The speaker exclaims, "Hah! Art thou too dead!" Alberigo replies he is ignorant of his body's state in the world above. He explains that Ptolomea has the privilege that the soul often drops here before Atropos divorces it. To make the speaker wipe his glazed tear-drops more willingly, he reveals that the moment a soul betrays, as he did, it yields its body to a fiend who moves and governs it until its time is rounded, and the soul falls headlong to this cistern. He adds that perhaps the body of a ghost who winters behind him still appears above. The speaker would know him if he just arrived below. Many years have passed since Branca Doria came to this fastness. The speaker replies he thinks Alberigo mocks him, as Branca Doria is not dead but performs all natural functions. Alberigo says that Michael Zanche had not yet reached the upper foss where pitch boils when Branca Doria left a demon in his stead in his own body, and one of his kin who wrought treachery with him did the same. Alberigo asks the speaker to put forth his hand and open his eyes. The speaker refuses, deeming ill manners best courtesy to him. The speaker then laments the Genoese, calling them perverse and stained with foulness, asking why they are not canceled from earth. He found one of them (Branca Doria) with Romagna's darkest spirit (Alberigo), whose soul is plunged in Cocytus even while his body seems alive on earth.

Virgil tells the speaker to look for the "banners of Hell's Monarch" approaching. The speaker sees what he thinks is a windmill in the distance, stirred briskly by a blast, like a heavy cloud or night shades. He draws behind Virgil for shelter from the wind. He arrives where souls are whelmed underneath, transparent like frail stems through glass. Some are prone, others upright, some on soles, some on heads, a third arched like a bow. Virgil pauses and tells the speaker to behold "Dis!" (Lucifer) and arm his heart with strength. The speaker is frozen and faint, unable to describe his state. He was neither dead nor living. The "emperor, who sways the realm of sorrow," stands mid-breast from the ice. The speaker is more like a giant compared to Lucifer than the giants are to him. Lucifer, once beautiful, is now hideous, and his scowl upon his Maker is the source of all misery. He has three faces on his head: one vermilion in front, the other two joined at each shoulder and crest. The right face is wan and yellow, the left like those from where the Nile stoops to lowlands. Under each face shoot forth two mighty wings, enormous, like a bat's, without plumes. He flaps them, creating three winds that freeze Cocytus to its depth. He weeps from six eyes, and tears distill down three chins with bloody foam. At each mouth, his teeth champ a sinner, bruised as with a ponderous engine. Three are tormented this way. The foremost sinner is more pained by the fierce rending than the gnawing, his back often stripped of skin. Virgil identifies the upper spirit, with his head within and feet without, as Judas, who has the worst punishment. Of the other two, whose heads are under, the one hanging from the murky jaw is Brutus, who writhes and speaks not. The other is Cassius, large of limb. Virgil says night re-ascends, and it's time for parting. All is seen. The speaker clips Virgil around the neck. Virgil, when the wings are open enough, catches Lucifer's shaggy sides and descends from pile to pile between the thick fur and jagged ice. When Virgil reaches the point where the thigh turns on the haunches, he turns his head around, where his feet stood before, and grapples at the fur as one who mounts. The speaker thinks they are turning back into hell. Virgil, panting, explains they must depart from such extreme evil by such stairs. They issue forth at a rocky opening. Virgil places the speaker on a brink to sit, then joins him. The speaker raises his eyes, expecting to see Lucifer where he was, but sees him with legs held upward. He reflects on his toil. Virgil cries, "Arise, upon thy feet. The way is long, and much uncouth the road; And now within one hour and half of noon The sun returns." They are not in a palace but a natural dungeon with ill footing and scant light. The speaker asks Virgil to free him from error: where is the ice now? How is Lucifer reversed? How has the sun made its transit from eve to morn so quickly? Virgil explains the speaker thought he was still on the other side of the center where Virgil grasped the "abhorred worm" (Lucifer). The speaker was on the other side as long as Virgil descended. When Virgil turned, the speaker passed the point to which all heavy substance is dragged. They are now under the hemisphere opposed to the great continent, where the sinless Man (Christ) expired. The speaker's feet are planted on the smallest sphere, whose other aspect is Judecca. Morn rises here when evening sets there. Lucifer, whose shaggy pile was scaled, stands fixed as at first. He fell down from heaven on this part, and the earth, prominent before, veiled herself with the sea through fear of him, retiring to their hemisphere. Perhaps the vacant space here was left by the firm land springing aloof to shun him. There is a place beneath, as distant from Beelzebub as the vaulted tomb, discovered not by sight but by the sound of a brooklet descending along the hollow of a rock, which the wave has eaten. By that hidden way, Virgil and the speaker enter to return to the "fair world." Heedless of repose, they climb, Virgil first, the speaker following, until the "beautiful lights of heav'n Dawn'd through a circular opening in the cave." Thus issuing, they again behold the stars.

Nick Carraway, the narrator, begins by recounting advice his father gave him about reserving judgments, a habit he generally maintains, except for Jay Gatsby, the man who gives his name to the book. Nick describes Gatsby as having an "extraordinary gift for hope" and "romantic readiness."

In the spring of 1922, Nick, a graduate of New Haven and a veteran of the Great War, moves East from the Middle West to learn the bond business. He rents a small, weather-beaten bungalow in West Egg, Long Island, situated between two enormous mansions. One of these belongs to Jay Gatsby. Across the bay, in the more fashionable East Egg, live his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, former football player husband, Tom Buchanan, whom Nick knew from college.

Nick visits the Buchanans for dinner. Tom is a physically imposing and arrogant man who expresses racist views about "The Rise of the Coloured Empires" and the "Nordic race." Daisy is charming but seems restless and cynical. Also present is Jordan Baker, a professional golfer, whom Nick finds intriguing. During dinner, the telephone rings for Tom, and Jordan reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy, aware of Tom's infidelity, expresses a desire for her young daughter to be a "beautiful little fool." After dinner, Nick observes Tom and Daisy in a moment of strained intimacy. Upon returning home, Nick sees Gatsby for the first time, standing alone on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a distant green light across the bay.

Some time later, Nick travels with Tom to New York. On the way, they stop in the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial wasteland. There, Tom forces Nick to meet his mistress, Myrtle Wilson, the wife of George B. Wilson, a "spiritless" garage owner. Tom treats George dismissively while arranging to meet Myrtle in the city. Myrtle, a sensuous woman in her mid-thirties, joins them on the train (in a separate car to maintain discretion). In New York, they go to an apartment Tom keeps. Myrtle insists on buying a dog, which Tom buys. Nick gets drunk at the apartment as Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and a couple named McKee arrive. Myrtle's personality becomes more affected as she changes into an elaborate dress. Catherine tells Nick that Gatsby is rumored to be a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm and that Tom and Myrtle despise their spouses and wish to marry, but Daisy, she claims, is Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce. Myrtle recounts her first meeting with Tom. Later, Tom and Myrtle argue violently when Myrtle repeatedly shouts Daisy's name, and Tom breaks her nose with his open hand. The party descends into chaos, and Nick leaves.

Nick then describes Gatsby's lavish parties, which are open to all and attract hundreds of uninvited guests. Nick receives a formal invitation and attends one such party. He feels out of place and struggles to find his host. He reconnects with Jordan Baker, and they hear various rumors about Gatsby – that he killed a man, was a German spy, or was in the American army. In Gatsby's library, they meet a man with "owl-eyed spectacles" who is surprised to find the books are real. Later, Nick meets Gatsby himself, who is younger and more formal than Nick expected. Gatsby is called away by a phone call. Jordan reveals Gatsby claimed to be an "Oxford man" but she doesn't believe it. Gatsby later asks Jordan to speak to Nick about a "big request." As Nick leaves the party, he witnesses a car crash caused by a drunken guest.

Gatsby picks Nick up for lunch and attempts to dispel the rumors about himself by sharing his life story: he claims to be from wealthy, deceased Middle Western parents, educated at Oxford, and to have lived like a "young rajah" in Europe. Nick is skeptical, especially when Gatsby says he's from "San Francisco." Gatsby then produces a medal from Montenegro and an Oxford photograph, which temporarily convinces Nick. Gatsby reveals his "big request" involves Daisy and will be relayed by Jordan. On their way to New York, Gatsby is stopped for speeding but produces a white card that allows them to proceed. In New York, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler who fixed the 1919 World's Series and claims to have "made" Gatsby. Tom Buchanan unexpectedly appears, and Gatsby quickly disappears before a proper introduction can be made.

Later that afternoon, Jordan tells Nick Gatsby's story: In 1917, Gatsby, then a penniless army lieutenant, fell in love with Daisy Fay in Louisville. Daisy, after a period of waiting for Gatsby to return from the war, married the wealthy Tom Buchanan in 1919, despite a last-minute drunken attempt to call off the wedding after receiving a letter (presumably from Gatsby). After their honeymoon, Tom was involved in a car accident with a chambermaid, which made the papers. Jordan reveals that Gatsby bought his mansion in West Egg specifically to be across the bay from Daisy. Gatsby's "big request" is for Nick to invite Daisy to his house for tea, so Gatsby can "come over" and show her his house. Nick agrees, and he and Jordan share a moment of intimacy.

Nick invites Daisy to tea at his house, explicitly telling her not to bring Tom. On the day of the tea, Gatsby, extremely nervous, sends a man to cut Nick's grass and a greenhouse full of flowers. Gatsby arrives, pale and dressed in an elaborate suit. Daisy arrives shortly after. Their initial reunion is awkward and silent, with Gatsby even knocking over a clock. However, their embarrassment soon gives way to joy, and Gatsby "literally glowed." He takes Daisy and Nick to his mansion, where he shows Daisy his vast possessions, including his expensive shirts, which make Daisy cry, saying they are "beautiful." Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, acknowledging that its "colossal significance" has now vanished. He has Klipspringer, the "boarder," play the piano. As Nick prepares to leave, he realizes that Daisy, in person, "tumbled short of his dreams" due to the "colossal vitality of his illusion." Gatsby and Daisy are absorbed in each other, and Nick leaves them alone.

Gatsby stops holding his lavish parties. Nick learns that Gatsby fired his servants and replaced them with people connected to Wolfshiem to prevent gossip, as Daisy now visits "quite often—in the afternoons." Daisy invites Nick to lunch at her house. On a sweltering day, Nick arrives at the Buchanans' house. Daisy kisses Gatsby in front of Nick and Jordan, declaring her love. Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, is brought in, and Gatsby looks at her with surprise, as if he "had never really believed in its existence before." Daisy tells Gatsby he looks "so cool," and Tom realizes their affair. Tom, furious, insists they all go to town.

On the way to town, Tom insists on driving Gatsby's yellow car, while Gatsby and Daisy follow in Tom's blue coupé. In Gatsby's car, Tom expresses his suspicions about Gatsby, revealing he has investigated his past. He challenges Gatsby's claim of being an "Oxford man" and suggests he's a bootlegger. They stop for gas at Wilson's garage in the valley of ashes. George Wilson is sick and distraught, revealing he has discovered Myrtle's infidelity and plans to move West with her. Myrtle, from an upstairs window, sees Tom and mistakes Jordan Baker for Tom's wife, her eyes wide with "jealous terror."

In a stifling suite at the Plaza Hotel, Tom confronts Gatsby directly. Tom challenges Gatsby's "Oxford man" story, which Gatsby clarifies was a five-month program for officers after the armistice. Tom then exposes Gatsby's illegal activities, revealing he sold grain alcohol through a chain of drugstores, and accuses Gatsby of leaving a business associate, Walter Chase, to go to jail.
