Gatsby counters that Chase was glad to make money. Tom insists Daisy loves him and never loved Gatsby. Daisy, under pressure, admits she "did love him once—but I loved you too" (referring to Gatsby). Gatsby pushes her to say she never loved Tom, but she tearfully confesses, "I can't say I never loved Tom. It wouldn't be true." Tom, regaining control, tells Gatsby that Daisy is not leaving him for a "common swindler." Daisy, frightened, begs to leave. Tom, with "magnanimous scorn," tells Daisy and Gatsby to drive home in Gatsby's car. They leave. Nick realizes it is his 30th birthday.

Tom, Jordan, and Nick drive back to Long Island in Tom's car. As they pass the valley of ashes, they discover a fatal car accident. Myrtle Wilson has been hit and killed by a "yellow car." George Wilson is inconsolable, repeatedly crying "Oh, my God!" Michaelis, a coffee shop owner, tells the policeman that a yellow car was involved. Tom, realizing it was Gatsby's car, quickly tells Wilson and the policeman that the yellow car he was driving earlier wasn't his, but a blue coupé, and that he hasn't seen the yellow car all afternoon. Nick corroborates this. Tom then carries the distraught Wilson into his office and tells Nick to leave. Tom drives away, sobbing and calling the driver a "God damned coward."

Back at the Buchanan house, Nick sees Gatsby hiding in the bushes. Gatsby reveals that Daisy was driving his yellow car. She was nervous and thought driving would steady her. Myrtle rushed out, possibly thinking it was Tom, and Daisy swerved away from an oncoming car, hitting Myrtle. Gatsby says he will take the blame. He waits outside the Buchanan house to ensure Tom doesn't bother Daisy. Nick goes to the kitchen window and sees Tom and Daisy sitting intimately at the kitchen table, appearing to conspire. They are not happy or unhappy, but share an "unmistakable air of natural intimacy." Nick tells Gatsby it's "all quiet" and urges him to go home, but Gatsby refuses, wanting to wait until Daisy goes to bed, watching over nothing.

Nick cannot sleep. He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn. Gatsby tells him Daisy came to her window at 4 AM, stood for a minute, then turned out the light. Nick urges Gatsby to go away, as his car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses to leave Daisy until he knows what she will do. Gatsby then tells Nick the full story of his past: his real name was James Gatz, and he was a penniless young man who fell in love with Daisy. He took her under false pretenses, letting her believe he was wealthy. He felt "married to her." He went to war, and while he was at Oxford, Daisy, feeling the pressure of the world, married Tom Buchanan for his "wholesome bulkiness" and "unquestionable practicality." Gatsby returned to Louisville, penniless, and felt he had lost the "freshest and the best" part of his dream forever. Gatsby still insists Daisy never loved Tom.

Gatsby's gardener asks if he should drain the pool, but Gatsby tells him not to, as he hasn't used it all summer. Nick, feeling he shouldn't leave Gatsby, misses two trains. He shouts to Gatsby, "They’re a rotten crowd. You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together." Gatsby smiles radiantly. Nick then leaves for the city.

Jordan Baker calls Nick, saying she has left Daisy's house. She accuses Nick of having "thrown her over" and reminds him of their conversation about bad drivers, implying he was a bad driver and she met another bad driver (him). Nick, now thirty, admits he is too old to lie to himself. Nick tries to call Gatsby, but the line is busy, held for a long-distance call from Detroit.

Nick then recounts the events at Wilson's garage after he and Tom left. Michaelis stayed with the distraught George Wilson through the night. Wilson, in his grief, began to talk about the yellow car and revealed that Myrtle had come home bruised a couple of months ago. He found an expensive dog-leash, which confirmed his suspicions about Myrtle's secret life. Wilson concluded that the man in the yellow car "murdered her" by not stopping when she ran out to speak to him. Wilson, looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, declares, "God sees everything." By morning, Wilson was gone. His movements are traced to West Egg, where he asked for Gatsby's house.

At 2 PM, Gatsby goes to his pool on a pneumatic mattress, having told his butler to bring any phone calls there. He also instructs that his yellow car is not to be taken out. No phone call arrives. The chauffeur hears shots. Nick arrives at Gatsby's house and rushes to the pool with the chauffeur, butler, and gardener. They find Gatsby dead, floating in the pool. The gardener then discovers Wilson's body in the grass nearby. The "holocaust was complete."

After Gatsby's death, police, photographers, and newspaper reporters swarm his house. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, lies at the inquest, swearing her sister never knew Gatsby and was happy with her husband, to simplify the case. Nick feels responsible for Gatsby because no one else seems to care. He tries to contact Daisy, but she and Tom have left early that afternoon with their baggage, leaving no forwarding address. Nick tries to reach Meyer Wolfshiem, who expresses shock but refuses to get "mixed up in this thing now," citing "important business." Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, a solemn old man who is both dismayed and proud of his son. He shows Nick a childhood book, "Hopalong Cassidy," containing Gatsby's youthful "General Resolves" for self-improvement. Nick tries to arrange a funeral, but only Gatsby's father, the Lutheran minister, a few servants, the postman, and the "owl-eyed man" attend. No one else comes.

Nick decides to return West. He has a final, awkward conversation with Jordan Baker, who confirms her engagement to another man and again accuses Nick of being a "bad driver" in their relationship. Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, claiming Wilson was "crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car." Tom justifies his actions, saying Gatsby "had it coming to him" and that Gatsby "ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car." Nick realizes Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness," leaving others to clean up their mess. Nick shakes Tom's hand, feeling as though he's talking to a child.

Gatsby's house remains empty. Nick reflects on Gatsby's dream and the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, realizing Gatsby's dream was already behind him. The book concludes with Nick's final thought: "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

This detailed summary is based solely on the provided text of "The Iliad," without external knowledge.

**Book I: The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon**
The narrative begins in the tenth year of the Trojan War. The Greeks, having sacked neighboring towns, took two beautiful captives: Chryseïs, allotted to Agamemnon, and Briseïs, allotted to Achilles. Chryses, a priest of Apollo and father of Chryseïs, arrived at the Greek camp with gifts to ransom his daughter. Agamemnon insolently refused and dismissed the priest. Chryses then prayed to Apollo for vengeance, and the god inflicted a pestilence on the Greeks for nine days.

Achilles called a council, where the prophet Chalcas declared the plague was due to Agamemnon's refusal to return Chryseïs. Agamemnon, though furious, was forced to send her back. In revenge, he seized Briseïs from Achilles, leading to a fierce quarrel between the two leaders. Nestor attempted to pacify them, but Achilles, in discontent, withdrew himself and his Myrmidon forces from the Greek army.

Achilles complained to his mother, Thetis, who then ascended to Olympus to supplicate Jupiter. She asked Jupiter to honor her son by granting victory to the Trojans, making the Greeks realize their mistake. Jupiter granted her request, which angered Juno. A heated debate ensued between Jupiter and Juno, eventually reconciled by Vulcan, who reminded Juno of Jupiter's supreme power.

Meanwhile, Ulysses returned Chryseïs to her father in Chrysa and offered sacrifices to Apollo, appeasing the god. The Greeks returned to their camp.

**Book II: The Trial of the Army, and Catalogue of the Forces**
Jupiter, to fulfill Thetis's request, sent a deceitful dream to Agamemnon, disguised as Nestor, urging him to lead the army to battle, promising Troy's immediate fall. Agamemnon, believing he could conquer Troy without Achilles, decided to test his army's morale by proposing a return to Greece, expecting the chiefs to stop them.

When Agamemnon made his proposal, the soldiers enthusiastically agreed and rushed to prepare their ships for departure. Juno, dismayed, sent Minerva to intervene. Minerva found Ulysses and urged him to rally the Greeks. Ulysses, wielding Agamemnon's sceptre, persuaded the chiefs and chastised the common soldiers, including the insolent Thersites, whom he struck.

The assembly was recalled. Ulysses reminded the Greeks of the prophecy at Aulis concerning the nine years of war and Troy's eventual fall. Nestor then advised a general muster and division of troops by nation. Agamemnon agreed, offered a sacrifice to Jove (which was refused), and Minerva inspired the Greeks. The text then provides a detailed catalogue of the Greek forces, noting Achilles' Myrmidons were inactive. Iris, sent by Jove, warned the Trojans (disguised as Polites) of the Greek advance, and Hector rallied his forces, followed by a catalogue of Trojan and auxiliary troops.

**Book III: The Duel of Menelaus and Paris**
The armies advanced, the Trojans with shouts, the Greeks in silence. Paris, in the Trojan vanguard, challenged the bravest Greek. Menelaus eagerly stepped forward. Paris, seeing Menelaus, recoiled in fear. Hector fiercely reproached Paris for his cowardice. Paris, accepting the rebuke, proposed a single combat with Menelaus for Helen and her treasures, to end the war.

Hector announced the challenge to both armies, and Menelaus agreed, requesting Priam to oversee the oaths due to his sons' faithlessness. Heralds were sent for Priam and to fetch a lamb for sacrifice. Iris, disguised as Laodice, called Helen from her loom to the Scaean Gate to witness the duel. Priam and the Trojan elders, on the walls, acknowledged Helen's beauty but wished her gone. Helen identified Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Ajax for Priam, and lamented the absence of her brothers, Castor and Pollux, unaware they were dead.

Priam and Menelaus swore solemn oaths over sacrificed lambs. Priam then returned to Troy, unable to watch. Paris and Menelaus armed. Paris threw his spear first, which struck Menelaus's shield but did not pierce it. Menelaus's spear pierced Paris's shield and corslet, but Paris dodged the fatal blow. Menelaus then struck Paris's helmet with his sword, which broke. Menelaus seized Paris by the helmet, dragging him. Venus intervened, breaking the strap and rescuing Paris in a cloud, transporting him to his chamber.

Venus, disguised as an old woman, summoned Helen to Paris. Helen, angry at Venus, initially refused, but Venus threatened her, compelling her to obey. Helen found Paris in his chamber, reproached him, but then embraced him. Agamemnon, unable to find Paris, declared Menelaus the victor and demanded Helen's return and the fine. The Greeks applauded.

**Book IV: The Breach of the Truce, and the First Battle**
In a council of the gods, Jupiter provoked Juno by suggesting peace. Juno, insistent on Troy's destruction, received Jupiter's reluctant consent, with a warning against future interference with his favored cities. Jupiter sent Minerva to break the truce. Minerva, disguised as Laodocus, persuaded Pandarus to shoot an arrow at Menelaus. The arrow wounded Menelaus in the shoulder, drawing blood, but Minerva deflected it from being fatal.

Agamemnon expressed sorrow and fear for Menelaus, foretelling Troy's doom. Machaon tended to Menelaus's wound. The Trojans, seeing the truce broken, rushed to attack. Agamemnon rallied his troops, praising the brave and shaming the fearful. Nestor organized his forces. Diomed and Ulysses, initially reproved, affirmed their readiness to fight.

The battle began with great clamor, inspired by Discord, Mars, and Minerva. Antilochus, Meges, Idomeneus, Menelaus, Merion, and Eurypylus each slew Trojan chiefs. Diomed raged across the field, killing Astynous, Hypenor, Xanthus, Thoon, and two sons of Priam. Pandarus shot Diomed, wounding him, but Minerva strengthened Diomed and granted him the ability to distinguish gods from mortals, allowing him to fight any god except Venus.

Æneas joined Pandarus in a chariot to confront Diomed. Pandarus's spear failed to wound Diomed, but Diomed's spear, guided by Pallas, killed Pandarus. Æneas tried to defend the body, but Diomed struck him with a stone, felling him. Venus rescued Æneas in a cloud. Diomed pursued Venus and wounded her hand. Venus, shrieking, dropped Æneas, who was then carried by Apollo to his temple in Troy for healing. Diomed insulted Venus. Venus, aided by Iris, fled to Mars, who lent her his chariot to return to Olympus. Dione comforted Venus, reminding her that gods also suffer.

Jupiter, seeing Venus's complaint, told her to stick to love. Apollo, from Troy, urged Mars to rally the Trojans, creating a phantom of Æneas to inspire them. Mars, disguised as Acamas, and Sarpedon rallied the Trojans. Æneas, healed, returned to battle. The fighting continued with many deaths on both sides. Diomed, seeing Mars, ordered a slow retreat. Ajax killed Amphius. Tlepolemus challenged Sarpedon; Sarpedon killed Tlepolemus, but was himself wounded. Ulysses killed several Lycians. Hector rallied the Trojans, aided by Mars and Bellona.

Juno and Minerva descended to aid the Greeks, but Jupiter sent Iris to warn them, threatening punishment if they interfered. They reluctantly obeyed. Jupiter reaffirmed his plan for Hector to conquer until Achilles returned after Patroclus's death. Night fell, and the Trojans, victorious, camped on the plain, lighting fires to prevent the Greeks from escaping.

**Book IX: The Embassy to Achilles**
The Greeks were filled with despair. Agamemnon, weeping, proposed abandoning the siege. Diomed vehemently opposed this, vowing to fight on. Nestor praised Diomed and advised Agamemnon to strengthen the guards and call a council of elders. Agamemnon followed this, and Nestor then proposed sending an embassy to Achilles to appease him.

Agamemnon agreed, acknowledging his fault, and offered immense gifts: gold, vases, tripods, horses, seven Lesbian captives (including Briseïs, whom he swore he had not touched), and if Troy fell, twenty Trojan women and one of his daughters in marriage with seven rich cities as dowry. Ulysses, Ajax, and Phoenix, accompanied by heralds, were chosen as ambassadors.

They found Achilles playing the harp with Patroclus. Achilles welcomed them. After a feast, Ulysses presented Agamemnon's offer, reminding Achilles of his father's advice to control his anger and appealing to his duty to save Greece. Achilles rejected the offer, expressing his deep hatred for Agamemnon's deceit and announcing his intention to return home on the third day. He advised the Greeks to do the same, stating he would only fight if Hector's flames threatened his own ships.

Phoenix then recounted his history of raising Achilles and urged him to temper his rage, telling the story of Meleager, who fought only after his city was in dire straits and received no reward. Achilles refused to be swayed, but invited Phoenix to stay. Ajax, impatient, reproached Achilles for his stubbornness over a single woman. Achilles reiterated his refusal to fight until his own ships were threatened. The ambassadors returned to the Greek camp and reported Achilles' rejection. Diomed advised the Greeks to prepare for battle without Achilles.

**Book X: The Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses**
Agamemnon, sleepless with anxiety, met Menelaus, also sleepless. Agamemnon sent Menelaus to wake Ajax and Idomeneus, while he went to Nestor. Nestor, awake and armed, advised waking Ulysses and Diomed. The chiefs met and Nestor proposed sending a spy into the Trojan camp. Diomed volunteered, choosing Ulysses as his companion.

Diomed and Ulysses armed themselves. Minerva sent a heron as an omen, and they prayed to her. Meanwhile, Hector offered Achilles' chariot and horses as a reward to any Trojan who would spy on the Greek camp. Dolon, a swift but vain Trojan, volunteered, asking for Achilles' horses. Hector swore an oath (in vain) to grant him the prize. Dolon set out, dressed in a wolf's hide.

Diomed and Ulysses spotted Dolon, let him pass, then pursued and captured him. Dolon, terrified, begged for his life and revealed Hector's offer and the disposition of the Trojan and auxiliary forces, particularly mentioning Rhesus and his white horses. Diomed then killed Dolon, saying he could not be allowed to spy again. Ulysses dedicated Dolon's spoils to Pallas and marked the spot.

The two heroes proceeded to the Thracian camp, found Rhesus and his men sleeping, and Diomed slaughtered Rhesus and twelve of his warriors. Ulysses gathered Rhesus's magnificent white horses. Pallas appeared, urging them to return. They rode the horses back to the Greek camp, where Nestor greeted them. Ulysses recounted their success. The horses were taken to Diomed's stalls, and Dolon's armor was dedicated to Minerva. The heroes cleansed themselves and feasted.

**Book XI: The Third Battle, and the Acts of Agamemnon**
At dawn, Eris, sent by Jove, descended to the Greek fleet, inspiring them to battle. Agamemnon armed himself in splendid, divine armor and led the charge. Jove sent drops of blood, foretelling slaughter. The Trojans, led by Hector, Polydamas, and Æneas, met the Greeks. Agamemnon raged, killing Bienor, Oileus, two sons of Priam (Isus and Antiphus), and the sons of Antimachus (Pisander and his brother).

Jupiter, from Ida, sent Iris to Hector, commanding him to retreat while Agamemnon was in his fury, but to return to battle once Agamemnon was wounded and withdrew. Hector obeyed. Agamemnon continued his slaughter, killing Iphidamas and Coön (who wounded Agamemnon in the arm). Agamemnon, in pain from his wound, withdrew from the battle.

Hector, seeing Agamemnon's retreat, rallied the Trojans and led a fierce charge, killing many Greeks. Ulysses and Diomed rallied, checking Hector. Diomed killed several Trojan chiefs, including the sons of Merops and Agastrophus. Paris then shot Diomed in the foot with an arrow, forcing him to withdraw. Ulysses was left alone, surrounded, but fought valiantly, killing several Trojans, including Socus, who wounded him. Menelaus and Ajax rescued Ulysses.

Ajax killed Doryclus, Pandocus, and Lysander. Hector raged on the left wing. Paris wounded Machaon with an arrow. Idomeneus told Nestor to take Machaon to the ships for healing. Nestor departed with Machaon. Hector then drove his chariot to the right wing, scattering the Greeks. Jove filled Ajax with terror, causing him to retreat slowly. Eurypylus aided Ajax but was wounded by Paris. Patroclus, seeing Nestor with Machaon, was sent by Achilles to inquire about the wounded. Patroclus found Nestor, who recounted the Greek losses and urged Patroclus to lead the Myrmidons in Achilles' armor to save the fleet. Patroclus, moved, left to deliver the message. On his way, he met the wounded Eurypylus and tended to his wound.

**Book XII: The Battle at the Grecian Wall**
While Patroclus tended Eurypylus, the battle raged at the Greek fortifications. The narrator foretold the future destruction of the Greek wall by Neptune and Apollo. Hector led the Trojans, who were eager to cross the trench and wall. Polydamas advised Hector to dismount and attack on foot, which Hector accepted. The Trojans divided into five battalions. Asius, however, disobeyed and drove his chariot to the gates, where he was met by Polypoetes and Leonteus, who defended the gates and killed many Trojans.

An omen appeared: an eagle dropping a bleeding serpent. Polydamas interpreted this as a sign of temporary success but ultimate failure and advised retreat. Hector rejected this, trusting Jove's clear favor. Hector rallied the Trojans, and with Jove's aid, they renewed the assault. The Ajaces rallied the Greeks. Sarpedon, inspired by Jove, led the Lycians, boasting of his leadership. Menestheus called for the Ajaces and Teucer. Ajax the Greater killed Epicles with a stone. Teucer wounded Glaucus with an arrow. Sarpedon killed Alcmaon and then tore down a section of the wall.

The battle raged fiercely at the breach. Teucer and Ajax shot at Sarpedon, but Jove protected him. Sarpedon rallied his Lycians. The fight remained evenly matched until Hector, with Jove's aid, threw a massive stone at the Greek gates, shattering them. Hector burst through, leading the Trojans into the Greek camp. The Greeks trembled and fled towards their ships.

**Book XIII: The Fourth Battle Continued, in which Neptune Assists the Greeks: The Acts of Idomeneus**
Jupiter, having brought Hector to the Greek ships, turned his attention away. Neptune, seeing the Greek distress, rose from the sea, disguised as Calchas, and inspired the Ajaces and other Greek leaders. The Ajaces recognized the divine presence and felt renewed strength. Neptune rallied the routed Greeks, shaming them and urging them to fight. The Greeks formed a phalanx.

Hector led the charge. Merion's spear broke against Deiphobus's shield, and he went for another. Teucer killed Imbrius. Hector's spear missed Teucer and killed Amphimachus (Neptune's grandson). Ajax the Greater killed Imbrius and threw his head at Hector's feet. Neptune, enraged, further inspired the Greeks, particularly Idomeneus. Idomeneus, after tending to a wounded soldier, returned to battle with Merion. Idomeneus killed Othryoneus and Asius. Antilochus killed Asius's charioteer. Deiphobus's spear missed Idomeneus and killed Hypsenor. Idomeneus killed Alcathous.

Æneas, persuaded by Deiphobus, confronted Idomeneus. Idomeneus called for his allies. Æneas's spear missed Idomeneus, who then killed Oenomaus. Idomeneus, heavy with age, slowly withdrew. Deiphobus's spear missed Idomeneus and killed Ascalaphus (son of Mars). Merion wounded Deiphobus. Æneas killed Aphareus. Antilochus killed Thoon. Merion killed Adamas. Helenus wounded Deipyrus. Menelaus wounded Helenus and killed Pisander, boasting of his vengeance. Menelaus killed Harpalion. Paris killed Euchenor.

The Greeks gained ground on the left wing, aided by Neptune. Hector remained in the center. The Locrian archers rained arrows on the Trojans. Polydamas advised Hector to call a council, fearing Achilles' return. Hector, after reproaching Paris, agreed to the council but first went to rally the left wing. Hector and Ajax exchanged boasts, and an eagle omen favored the Greeks.

**Book XIV: Juno Deceives Jupiter by the Girdle of Venus**
Nestor, hearing the battle's clamor, left Machaon to be tended and went to the front, seeing the wall in ruins and Greeks in flight. He met the wounded Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Diomed. Agamemnon proposed abandoning the siege. Ulysses fiercely rebuked him, and Diomed advised them to return to the front to inspire the troops, but to stay out of range. The wounded kings agreed. Neptune, disguised as an old warrior, encouraged Agamemnon.

Juno, seeing Jupiter on Ida favoring the Trojans, decided to deceive him. She adorned herself with great care and obtained Venus's magic girdle of love and desire. She then went to Sleep, on Lemnos, and persuaded him to put Jupiter to sleep, promising him Pasithaë, the youngest Grace, as his wife, and swearing a solemn oath. Sleep and Juno flew to Mount Ida. Juno approached Jupiter, who was immediately enchanted by her beauty and fell into a deep slumber.

Sleep swiftly informed Neptune, who then openly aided the Greeks, rallying them. Hector threw his javelin at Ajax, but it was deflected. Ajax threw a huge stone, striking Hector in the chest and knocking him unconscious. The Greeks rejoiced. Polydamas, Agenor, and Æneas protected Hector, carrying him from the field to Troy. Hector revived by the Xanthus river. The Greeks pressed their attack, killing many Trojans.

**Book XV: The Fifth Battle at the Ships; and the Acts of Ajax**
Jupiter, waking on Ida, saw the Trojans fleeing, Hector in a swoon, and Neptune leading the Greeks. Enraged at Juno's deception, he threatened her. Juno denied involvement, blaming Neptune. Jupiter, appeased, revealed his plan: Iris would command Neptune to withdraw, Apollo would revive Hector and lead the Trojans to drive the Greeks to Achilles' ships. Patroclus would then fight in Achilles' armor, kill Sarpedon, but then be killed by Hector. Only then would Achilles return, and Troy would fall.

Juno flew to Olympus, warned Mars against fighting Jove, and sent Iris and Apollo to Ida. Iris delivered Jove's command to Neptune, who, though angry, reluctantly withdrew. Apollo revived Hector, inspired him, and gave him Jove's aegis. Hector, invigorated, led the Trojans back to battle. Apollo, with the aegis, broke down the Greek wall.

The Trojans rushed into the Greek camp. Hector killed many Greeks and forbade plundering, urging his troops to burn the ships. Apollo pushed down the trench, creating a path. The Trojans poured into the camp, reaching the ships. Nestor prayed to Jove, who sent thunder as a sign. Patroclus, seeing the ships burning, rushed to Achilles.

The battle raged around the ships. Hector and Ajax fought at one ship. Hector killed Clytius. Hector's javelin killed Lycophron, Ajax's servant. Ajax called to Teucer, who shot an arrow, killing Clytus. Teucer aimed at Hector, but Jove broke his bowstring. Ajax told Teucer to use a spear. Hector rallied the Trojans. Ajax rallied the Greeks. Dolops wounded Meges, but Menelaus killed Dolops. Antilochus killed Melanippus. Jove continued to favor the Trojans. Hector, like a lion, killed Periphes. Nestor rallied the Greeks. Minerva cleared the mist from their eyes. Ajax, with a huge mace, defended the ships. Hector seized the stern of Protesilaus's ship and called for fire. Ajax, overwhelmed, retreated slightly but continued to defend, killing twelve Trojans.

**Book XVI: The Sixth Battle, the Acts and Death of Patroclus**
Patroclus, seeing the ships burning, wept before Achilles. He pleaded with Achilles to let him lead the Myrmidons in Achilles' armor to save the fleet. Achilles, though still angry at Agamemnon, agreed, but strictly ordered Patroclus not to pursue the Trojans to the walls of Troy or engage Hector. He wished for all Trojans and Greeks to die, leaving only them to take Troy.

Ajax, his spear broken by Hector, retreated as the Trojans set fire to Protesilaus's ship. Achilles, seeing the flames, urged Patroclus to arm. Patroclus donned Achilles' armor (except for his spear). Automedon harnessed Achilles' immortal horses. Achilles rallied the Myrmidons and made a libation to Jove, praying for Patroclus's success and safe return, but Jove granted only the former.

Patroclus led the Myrmidons. The Trojans, seeing Achilles' armor, panicked and fled from the ships. Patroclus extinguished the fire. Patroclus raged, killing Pyrechmes and many other Trojan chiefs, driving them from the ships. Patroclus pursued the fleeing Trojans. Sarpedon, seeing his Lycians fall, challenged Patroclus. Jove debated saving his son Sarpedon, but Juno persuaded him to let fate take its course.

Patroclus killed Thrasymed. Sarpedon wounded Achilles' mortal horse, Pedasus. Automedon cut Pedasus free. Patroclus then killed Sarpedon with a spear to the heart. Sarpedon, dying, called to Glaucus to defend his body. Glaucus, wounded, prayed to Apollo, who healed him. Glaucus rallied the Trojans and Lycians to defend Sarpedon's body. Hector rushed to the body. A fierce battle ensued over Sarpedon's corpse. The Greeks eventually gained the body and stripped Sarpedon's armor. Jove sent Apollo to retrieve Sarpedon's body, cleanse it, and have Sleep and Death carry it to Lycia for burial.

Patroclus, disregarding Achilles' command, pursued the Trojans to the walls of Troy, killing many. Thrice he attempted to scale the walls, and thrice Apollo repulsed him, warning him to retreat. Hector, urged by Apollo (disguised as Asius), drove his chariot towards Patroclus. Patroclus killed Cebriones, Hector's charioteer, with a stone. A battle raged over Cebriones' body. As the sun set, the Greeks gained the advantage.

Patroclus, with renewed fury, charged the Trojans. Apollo, shrouded in a cloud, struck Patroclus from behind, disarming and stunning him. Euphorbus then wounded Patroclus with a spear. Hector, seeing Patroclus disarmed and wounded, approached and killed him with a spear. Hector boasted over Patroclus's dying body. Patroclus, with his last breath, prophesied Hector's imminent death by Achilles. Patroclus died. Hector pulled his spear from the body. Automedon drove Achilles' immortal horses away.

**Book XVII: The Seventh Battle, for the Body of Patroclus**
Menelaus defended Patroclus's body. Euphorbus challenged him and was killed by Menelaus. Menelaus began to strip Euphorbus's armor. Apollo, disguised as Mentes, urged Hector to retrieve Patroclus's body and Achilles' armor. Hector rushed forward. Menelaus, seeing Hector, retreated, calling for Ajax. Ajax arrived. Hector, who had seized Patroclus's head, retreated with Achilles' armor, which his men carried to Troy. Ajax covered Patroclus's body.

Glaucus reproached Hector for his flight and for abandoning Sarpedon's body. Hector, stung, denied cowardice and put on Achilles' armor. Jove pitied Hector, granting him a day of glory. Hector, filled with divine vigor, rallied the Trojans, promising honors for retrieving Patroclus's body. Ajax called for the bravest Greeks to defend the body. Ajax the Lesser, Idomeneus, and Merion responded. The battle raged over Patroclus's body. Hippothous attempted to drag the body but was killed by Ajax. Hector's spear killed Schedius. Ajax killed Phorcys.

Apollo, disguised as Periphas, urged Æneas to fight. Æneas rallied the Trojans. Leocritus was killed by Æneas. Lycomedes killed Apisaon. The Greeks formed a strong defense around Patroclus's body. Automedon, Achilles' charioteer, mourned Patroclus, and Achilles' immortal horses wept. Jove pitied the horses and gave them new spirit, ensuring Automedon's safe return. Alcimedon took the reins, allowing Automedon to fight. Hector and Æneas attempted to capture Achilles' chariot. Automedon killed Aretus. The Ajaces intervened, forcing Hector and Æneas to retreat.

Minerva, disguised as Phoenix, inspired Menelaus, who then killed Podes. Apollo, disguised as Phaenops, urged Hector to return to the body. Hector rushed back. Jove shook his aegis, terrifying the Greeks. Peneleus and Leitus were wounded. Hector killed Coeranus, Merion's charioteer. Merion and Idomeneus retreated. Ajax, seeing Jove's hand, prayed for light, which Jove granted. Ajax told Menelaus to send Antilochus to Achilles with the news of Patroclus's death. Menelaus found Antilochus, who was overcome with grief, and sent him to Achilles. Menelaus returned to the battle, and he and Merion, aided by the Ajaces, lifted Patroclus's body and began to carry it to the ships, fiercely fighting off the pursuing Trojans.

**Book XVIII: The Grief of Achilles, and New Armour Made Him by Vulcan**
Achilles, by his ships, foresaw Patroclus's death. Antilochus arrived, weeping, and delivered the news of Patroclus's death and Hector's possession of Achilles' armor. Achilles was overwhelmed with grief, covering himself in ashes and tearing his hair. The captive women lamented with him. Thetis, hearing his cries, came with the Nereids to comfort him. Achilles expressed his desire for revenge on Hector, acknowledging his own fated death after Hector's. Thetis promised to bring him new divine armor from Vulcan by dawn.

The battle for Patroclus's body continued. Juno sent Iris to Achilles, urging him to appear at the trench, even unarmed, to scare the Trojans and save the body. Achilles agreed. Pallas threw her aegis over his shoulder and created a golden cloud with a flame above his head. Achilles stood on the rampart and shouted. Minerva amplified his voice, terrifying the Trojans, who dropped their arms and fled. Twelve Trojans were crushed in the panic. The Greeks then retrieved Patroclus's body and carried it to Achilles' tent. Achilles lamented over the body.

Night fell. The Trojans held a council. Polydamas advised retreating into the city, fearing Achilles. Hector rejected this, insisting on camping on the plain to attack the ships at dawn, confident he could face Achilles. Pallas made the Trojans approve Hector's bad advice. The Greeks mourned Patroclus all night. Achilles vowed to sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on Patroclus's pyre and leave Hector's body to dogs.

Thetis arrived at Vulcan's palace on Olympus and requested new armor for Achilles. Vulcan, recounting how Thetis had saved him in the past, agreed to forge magnificent armor. He created a massive, solid shield depicting: earth, heaven, ocean, celestial bodies; two cities (one at peace, one at war); a ploughed field; a harvest field; a vineyard; a herd of oxen attacked by lions; a pasture; and a dancing floor. He also forged a cuirass, greaves, and a helmet. Thetis took the blazing new armor and flew swiftly to Achilles.

**Book XIX: The Reconciliation of Achilles and Agamemnon**
At dawn, Thetis brought the divine armor to Achilles. Achilles was awed by its splendor. He expressed concern about Patroclus's body decaying, but Thetis assured him she would preserve it with nectar and ambrosia. She told him to assemble the Greeks and end his wrath. Achilles obeyed, calling the Greeks to assembly. Diomed, Ulysses, and Agamemnon arrived.

Achilles publicly declared an end to his anger, wishing the quarrel over Briseïs had never happened. He expressed his readiness to fight. The Greeks cheered. Agamemnon, without rising, explained that Jove, Fate, and Ate were responsible for his past error. He reaffirmed his offer of gifts and Briseïs, swearing he had not touched her. Achilles accepted the end of the quarrel but was impatient to fight, refusing to eat until he had avenged Patroclus.

Ulysses advised Achilles to let the army eat and rest to regain strength, and to formally accept the gifts and oath. Agamemnon agreed, ordering the gifts to be brought and the oath to be sworn publicly. Achilles reluctantly agreed to the delay. Ulysses and other chiefs brought the gifts, including Briseïs. Agamemnon publicly swore his oath over a sacrificed boar. Achilles reiterated that Jove caused their strife and urged the Greeks to eat.

The Greeks dispersed to eat. Achilles returned to his tent. Briseïs, seeing Patroclus's body, lamented over him, recalling his kindness. The other captive women joined her. Achilles refused to eat, consumed by grief. Jupiter, seeing Achilles' distress, sent Minerva to infuse ambrosia and nectar into his breast, strengthening him.

The Greek army armed for battle. Achilles donned his new divine armor, his eyes flashing with fire. He addressed his immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, reproaching them for leaving Patroclus. Xanthus, miraculously given voice by Juno, replied that Patroclus's death was due to a god and fate, and prophesied Achilles' own imminent death. Achilles, undaunted, declared he knew his fate and rushed to battle.

**Book XX: The Battle of the Gods, and the Acts of Achilles**
The Greek and Trojan armies prepared for battle. Jupiter called a council of the gods, permitting them to assist either side, fearing Achilles would take Troy against fate. The gods descended: Juno, Neptune, Minerva, Hermes, and Vulcan aided the Greeks; Latona, Apollo, Mars, Diana, and Xanthus aided the Trojans. Their arrival caused immense tumult, shaking earth and heaven, and even Pluto in the underworld trembled.

The gods engaged in their own battles: Apollo against Neptune, Mars against Pallas, Latona against Hermes, Diana against Juno, Vulcan against Xanthus (Scamander). Achilles, seeking Hector, burst through the ranks. Apollo, disguised as Lycaon, urged Æneas to confront Achilles. Æneas, though reluctant, advanced. Juno, seeing this, called a council of the Greek-favoring gods. Neptune suggested they observe unless the Trojan gods intervened.

Æneas and Achilles confronted each other, exchanging boasts. Æneas's spear struck Achilles' shield but did not pierce it. Achilles' spear pierced Æneas's shield. As Achilles rushed Æneas, Neptune intervened, casting darkness over Achilles' eyes, retrieving his spear, and carrying Æneas away, warning him not to fight Achilles again until Achilles' fated death. Neptune then dispelled the mist from Achilles' eyes. Achilles, amazed, realized a god had saved Æneas.

Achilles then unleashed his fury on the rest of the Trojans. Hector rallied the Trojans, but Apollo warned him to avoid single combat with Achilles. Hector obeyed. Achilles killed Iphytion, Demoleon, Hippodamas, and Polydore (Priam's youngest son). Hector, enraged by Polydore's death, confronted Achilles. Hector threw his spear, but Pallas deflected it. Achilles rushed Hector, but Apollo shrouded Hector in a cloud, saving him. Thrice Achilles struck the cloud in vain, raging at Apollo. Achilles then continued his slaughter, killing many more Trojans.

**Book XXI: The Battle in the River Scamander**
The Trojans fled before Achilles, some towards the town (shrouded by Juno), others towards the river Xanthus (Scamander). Achilles drove the latter into the river, where many drowned. He took twelve Trojan youths alive as captives for Patroclus's shade. Achilles then encountered Lycaon, a son of Priam he had previously captured and sold. Lycaon begged for mercy, but Achilles, hardened by Patroclus's death, refused and killed him, casting his body into the river.

The river god Xanthus, enraged by the choked stream, confronted Achilles, telling him to stop. Achilles refused, vowing to continue until Troy and Hector fell. Achilles then killed Asteropeus, a Paeonian leader, boasting of his divine lineage over Asteropeus's river-god lineage. Achilles pursued the Paeonians. Scamander, enraged, rose in human form and confronted Achilles again, then swelled his waters, creating a flood that swept Achilles away.

Achilles struggled against the current, lamenting his ignominious fate. Neptune and Pallas appeared, reassuring him and urging him to continue fighting. Achilles, invigorated, resumed his rampage. Scamander called to Simois for aid, and they combined their floods, threatening to bury Achilles. Juno, fearing for Achilles, called to Vulcan for aid. Vulcan unleashed his fires on the river, consuming the dead, drying the soil, and boiling the water. Scamander, in pain, begged Vulcan to cease, yielding to fate. Juno ordered Vulcan to stop, and the river returned to normal.

The other gods engaged in battle: Minerva struck Mars down with a stone. Venus aided Mars, but Minerva struck her too. Neptune challenged Apollo, but Apollo refused to fight for mortals. Diana upbraided Apollo, and Juno seized Diana, disarming and beating her. Latona collected Diana's arrows. Hermes declined to fight Latona. The gods returned to Olympus. Apollo entered Troy to protect its walls. Achilles continued his slaughter, driving the Trojans towards the city. Priam ordered the gates opened to let the Trojans in, then closed. Apollo covered the Trojans' retreat. Apollo, disguised as Agenor, challenged Achilles, allowing the real Agenor to escape and the remaining Trojans to enter the city. Achilles, realizing the deception, was enraged.

**Book XXII: The Death of Hector**
The Trojans were safe within their walls, except for Hector, who stood alone before the Scaean Gate, resolved to face Achilles. Apollo mocked Achilles for chasing him. Achilles, enraged, advanced towards Troy. Priam and Hecuba, from the walls, pleaded with Hector to come inside, fearing his death and Troy's ruin. Hector, however, remained resolute, debating retreat or parley, but ultimately resolving to fight gloriously.

Achilles approached, blazing like a star. Hector's resolve failed, and he fled in terror. Achilles pursued Hector three times around the walls of Troy. The gods observed. Jupiter weighed their fates; Hector's scale sank. Apollo abandoned Hector. Minerva descended, disguised as Deiphobus, and urged Hector to stand and fight Achilles together. Hector, believing he had an ally, agreed and faced Achilles, proposing an oath for the return of the loser's body. Achilles fiercely rejected any oaths, declaring his sole purpose was vengeance for Patroclus.

Achilles launched his javelin, which Hector dodged. Minerva retrieved the spear and returned it to Achilles, unseen by Hector. Hector, believing he had wounded Achilles and that Deiphobus would give him another spear, called for Deiphobus, but he was not there. Hector realized he had been deceived and accepted his fate, drawing his sword. Achilles, with his spear, found the vulnerable spot in Hector's armor (Patroclus's old armor) at the neck and drove his spear through it, wounding him mortally but allowing him to speak.

Achilles boasted over the dying Hector, refusing his plea for burial and vowing his body to dogs. Hector, with his dying breath, prophesied Achilles' death at the Scaean Gate by Paris and Apollo. Hector died. Achilles stripped his armor. The other Greeks gathered, marveling at Hector, and stabbed his body. Achilles declared victory and, in an act of vengeance, bored Hector's ankles, threaded thongs through them, and bound him to his chariot. He then dragged Hector's body three times around Patroclus's tomb.

Priam and Hecuba, from the walls, witnessed this horror and lamented loudly, joined by the entire city. Priam tried to rush out but was restrained. Andromache, unaware, heard the cries, felt a premonition, and rushed to the walls. She saw Hector's body being dragged, fainted, and then awoke to lament his death, foreseeing Troy's fall and her son Astyanax's suffering and enslavement. She vowed to burn the clothes she had woven for Hector.

**Book XXIII: Funeral Games in Honour of Patroclus**
The Greeks returned to their ships. Achilles gathered the Myrmidons and ordered them to drive their chariots thrice around Patroclus's body. Achilles lamented over Patroclus, reaffirming his promise to give Hector's body to dogs and sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on the pyre. He threw Hector's body before the bier. The Myrmidons then gathered for a funeral feast. Achilles refused to wash until Patroclus was buried. He agreed to eat but requested Agamemnon to prepare the funeral pyre at dawn.

The Greeks feasted and slept. Achilles, sleepless, lay on the shore. Patroclus's ghost appeared to him in a dream, asking for burial rites so his spirit could rest and requesting that their bones be mixed. Achilles tried to embrace the ghost, but it vanished. He awoke, amazed.

At dawn, Agamemnon sent men to Mount Ida to cut timber for the pyre. The timber was brought back and arranged. The Myrmidons, armed, drove their chariots around the pyre. Achilles, supporting Patroclus's head, lamented and cut off a lock of his hair, vowed to Sperchius, placing it on Patroclus's body. Agamemnon dismissed most of the troops. The chiefs built a large pyre. Patroclus's body was placed on top, covered in fat, along with sacrificed sheep, oxen, goats, and four horses. Achilles then sacrificed twelve Trojan captives on the pyre.

Achilles invoked Patroclus's ghost. Venus and Apollo protected Hector's body from dogs and decay. The pyre did not burn, so Achilles prayed to the Winds (Zephyr and Boreas). Iris, sent by Achilles, went to the Winds, who then rushed forth, igniting the pyre. The pyre burned all night. At dawn, the flames subsided. Achilles, exhausted, slept. The Greeks gathered, and Achilles ordered them to quench the embers, collect Patroclus's bones in a golden urn, and bury them in a mound, which would be their common tomb.

Achilles then announced funeral games with various prizes.
1.  **Chariot Race:** Eumelus, Diomed, Menelaus, Antilochus, Merion competed. Apollo hindered Diomed, but Pallas helped him and caused Eumelus to crash. Diomed won first prize. Achilles awarded Eumelus second prize out of pity, but Antilochus protested, having come in second by a clever maneuver against Menelaus. Menelaus challenged Antilochus to an oath, but Antilochus humbly yielded the prize. Achilles gave Antilochus a golden talent and Eumelus a corslet. Nestor received a double bowl as an honorary gift.
2.  **Boxing:** Epeus defeated Euryalus.
3.  **Wrestling:** Ajax the Greater and Ulysses competed to a draw, sharing the prizes.
4.  **Foot-Race:** Oilean Ajax, Ulysses, and Antilochus competed. Pallas tripped Ajax, allowing Ulysses to win. Antilochus came in third.
5.  **Single Combat (Spear and Shield):** Diomed and Ajax the Greater competed. The Greeks stopped the fight, declaring equal honors, but Diomed received a sword as the victor's due.
6.  **Discus Throw:** Polypoetes won the iron quoit.
7.  **Archery:** Teucer cut the cord but missed the dove. Merion, praying to Apollo, shot the dove. Merion won the double-edged axes, Teucer the single-edged.
8.  **Javelin Throw:** Achilles awarded the prize to Agamemnon without contest, and a spear to Merion.

**Book XXIV: The Redemption of the Body of Hector**
After the games, the Greeks slept, but Achilles remained sleepless, mourning Patroclus. Each morning, he dragged Hector's body thrice around Patroclus's tomb. Apollo protected Hector's body from damage and decay. The gods were moved by pity. On the tenth day, Apollo condemned Achilles' cruelty in the council of the gods. Juno defended Achilles. Jupiter intervened, acknowledging Hector's piety, and ordered Thetis to tell Achilles to accept ransom. He then sent Iris to Priam, instructing him to go alone with a herald and gifts to Achilles' tent to ransom Hector's body, promising Hermes' protection.

Iris delivered the message to Thetis, who then went to Achilles, telling him Jove's command. Achilles agreed to obey. Iris delivered Jove's message to Priam in Troy. Priam, despite Hecuba's fears, insisted on going, trusting Jove. He gathered rich gifts. Priam angrily reproached his surviving sons. Priam's sons prepared the car and loaded the gifts. Priam himself harnessed his horses, aided by Idæus. Hecuba offered a libation and asked for an omen. Jove sent an eagle as a favorable sign.

Priam and Idæus set out. Jove sent Hermes, disguised as a young man, to guide and protect them. Hermes met them at a spring, reassured Priam, and revealed that Hector's body was preserved by the gods. Priam offered Hermes a goblet, which Hermes refused. Hermes then took the reins, put the Greek guards to sleep, and led the chariot and wagon through the camp to Achilles' tent. Hermes revealed his divine identity to Priam and told him to enter fearlessly and appeal to Achilles.

Priam entered Achilles' tent, found Achilles at supper, and cast himself at Achilles' feet, embracing his hands, which had killed his sons. Achilles and his attendants were stunned. Priam appealed to Achilles' pity by reminding him of his own aged father, Peleus, and his own immense suffering. Achilles was moved to tears, weeping for his father and Patroclus, and Priam for Hector.

Achilles, composed, raised Priam and spoke gently, reminding him that man is born to bear sorrow and that Jove distributes good and evil. Priam insisted on seeing Hector's body. Achilles, with a flash of anger, told Priam not to provoke him, stating he would return Hector's body by Jove's command. He ordered his handmaids to wash and anoint Hector's body out of Priam's sight. Achilles then lifted Hector's body onto the funeral bed in the wagon, addressing Patroclus's shade and asking forgiveness.

Achilles invited Priam to eat, telling him the story of Niobe to encourage him. Priam and Achilles ate together, marveling at each other. Priam asked to sleep. Achilles prepared a bed for him outside the inner tent and asked how long he needed for Hector's funeral rites. Priam requested twelve days for mourning and burial, which Achilles granted as a truce.

Hermes, concerned for Priam's safety, woke him and urged him to leave before the Greeks discovered him. Priam and Idæus departed with the body and gifts. Hermes guided them past the guards and returned to Olympus. At dawn, Cassandra saw Priam's wagon approaching Troy with Hector's body and alerted the city. The Trojans rushed out, lamenting. Priam ordered them to take the body to the palace.

Hector's body was placed on a bed of state. Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen each lamented over him. Andromache foresaw Troy's fall and Astyanax's suffering. Hecuba praised Hector as heaven's favorite. Helen mourned Hector as her only kind friend in Troy. Priam ordered the Trojans to gather wood for the pyre. For nine days, they gathered wood. On the tenth day, Hector's body was placed on the pyre and burned. On the eleventh day, the Trojans quenched the flames, collected Hector's bones in a golden vase, and buried them in a mound, raising a tomb. Guards watched during the burial. The Trojans then returned to Priam's court for a funeral feast. The book concludes with the peaceful rest of Hector's shade.

The narrative begins with a detailed description of the Custom-House in Salem, Massachusetts, where the unnamed narrator works as a Surveyor. He describes the dilapidated wharf, the federal eagle above the Custom-House entrance, and the general lack of commercial activity. He introduces his elderly, mostly inactive colleagues, particularly the "father of the Custom-House," a permanent Inspector who is eighty years old, robust, and focused solely on physical pleasures, devoid of deep thought or feeling. The narrator also sketches the Collector, a brave old General, whose military past contrasts with his current infirmity and quiet contemplation.

The narrator reflects on his own family's long history in Salem, including a stern Puritan ancestor who was a soldier, legislator, judge, and persecutor of Quakers and witches. He feels a strong, almost fated, attachment to the town despite its uninspiring nature. He describes his own intellectual stagnation and the loss of his imaginative faculty while working at the Custom-House, feeling that his literary talent has dwindled.

One rainy day, while sifting through old documents in an unfinished room in the Custom-House, the narrator discovers a small package wrapped in yellow parchment. Inside, he finds a commission for a former Surveyor named Jonathan Pue, and a small roll of dingy paper. Enveloped by these papers is a piece of fine, worn red cloth, intricately embroidered with gold thread, in the shape of the capital letter "A." Upon placing this scarlet letter on his own breast, the narrator experiences a sensation of burning heat and involuntarily drops it.

He then reads the accompanying manuscript, written by Surveyor Pue, which provides a "reasonably complete explanation of the whole affair." This manuscript details the life and experiences of one Hester Prynne, a "noteworthy personage" from the early days of Massachusetts, between the early settlement and the late seventeenth century. The narrator states that the main facts of the story he is about to tell are authenticated by this document, though he admits to taking liberties with motives and passions. He feels as if the ghost of Surveyor Pue has exhorted him to bring this story to the public, promising profit and warning him of his own impending removal from office.

Indeed, the narrator's political party loses power, and he is "swept out of office" by the "besom of reform." He views this as a fortunate turn of events, as his intellectual faculties were stifled by his Custom-House work. He then dedicates himself to writing, using the materials from Surveyor Pue's manuscript. He describes the resulting tale, "The Scarlet Letter," as stern and somber, reflecting the period of turmoil in which it was conceived. He concludes the Custom-House introduction by noting that Roger Chillingworth, the old Inspector, has since died, and that Hester Prynne's story has become a legend, with her and Pearl disappearing for many years before Hester's eventual return.

The story proper, "The Scarlet Letter," then begins:

**I. The Prison-Door.**
A crowd of stern-faced Puritan men and women gathers outside a gloomy, weather-stained wooden prison in Boston, in June, two centuries ago. The prison door is heavily timbered and studded with iron spikes. Beside the door, a wild rose-bush blooms, offering a symbol of fragile beauty and pity amidst the harshness.

**II. The Market-Place.**
The crowd, including many outspoken women, awaits a public punishment. They discuss the severity of the law and the specific case of Hester Prynne. Some suggest a brand on her forehead, while others, more merciful, note her pastor, Reverend Master Dimmesdale, takes her scandal to heart. The jailer, Master Brackett, opens the door, and Hester Prynne emerges, carrying a three-month-old baby. She is a tall, elegant woman with dark, abundant hair and striking beauty. On her breast, elaborately embroidered with gold thread on fine red cloth, is the letter "A." This scarlet letter, intended as a mark of shame, is so artistically crafted that it appears as a decoration. Hester, with a burning blush but a haughty smile, surveys the crowd. She is led to a scaffold in the market-place, a platform for public shame, but is spared the head-confining pillory. Standing on the scaffold, Hester endures the public gaze, her mind replaying memories of her past life in Old England, her parents, and a pale, deformed, scholar-like man—her husband—before returning to the harsh reality of her present ignominy.

**III. The Recognition.**
As Hester stands on the scaffold, she notices a deformed white man in the crowd, accompanied by an Indian. His features show remarkable intelligence, and he has one shoulder higher than the other. Upon seeing him, Hester clutches her baby convulsively. The stranger, in turn, fixes his gaze on Hester, a look of horror twisting his features before he controls it. He makes a gesture of silence to Hester and then asks a townsman about her. The townsman explains that Hester Prynne is a married woman whose husband, Master Prynne, a learned man from Amsterdam, was supposed to join her in Boston but has been missing for two years. Hester, left to her "misguidance," has given birth to a child, but refuses to name the father. The stranger, who identifies himself as a wanderer recently redeemed from Indian captivity, remarks on the "wise sentence" that dooms Hester to wear the scarlet letter for life, but expresses a desire for the "partner of her iniquity" to be known. He then bows and departs with the Indian. Hester, though dreading a face-to-face encounter, feels a strange shelter in the presence of the multitude. Governor Bellingham, Mr. Wilson, and Mr. Dimmesdale are present in a balcony. Mr. Wilson urges Mr. Dimmesdale, Hester's pastor, to compel her to confess the father's name. Dimmesdale, pale and tremulous, appeals to Hester to reveal the name for her soul's peace and his own. Hester firmly refuses, stating the letter is too deeply branded and her child must seek a heavenly father. Another voice from the crowd demands she "give her child a father," but Hester remains silent. Dimmesdale, with a long respiration, acknowledges her "wondrous strength and generosity." Mr. Wilson then preaches a long sermon on sin, while Hester endures with stony insensibility. She is then led back to prison, her scarlet letter reportedly casting a lurid gleam in the dark passage.

**IV. The Interview.**
In prison, Hester is in a state of nervous excitement, and the jailer introduces a physician, Roger Chillingworth, the same deformed man from the market-place. Chillingworth, who has learned medicinal properties from the "savage people," calms Pearl with a draught. He then offers Hester a calming medicine, which she initially fears is poison. He reassures her it is for good, saying, "Live, therefore, and bear about thy doom with thee, in the eyes of men and women,—in the eyes of him whom thou didst call thy husband,—in the eyes of yonder child!" He then reveals himself as her long-lost husband, Master Prynne, who has taken the name Chillingworth. He acknowledges his folly in marrying her, an old, misshapen scholar, to her youth and beauty. Hester admits she felt no love for him. Chillingworth declares he seeks no vengeance on her, as they have wronged each other, but vows to find Pearl's father. He states that he will read the sin on the man's heart and torment him, but will not betray him to human law or harm his life or fame. He extracts a solemn oath from Hester that she will never reveal his true identity. Hester, troubled, asks if he is the "Black Man" who haunts the forest, but he denies it, saying his vengeance is not for her soul.

**V. Hester at Her Needle.**
Hester is released from prison. Despite being free to leave the Puritan settlement, she chooses to remain, feeling an irresistible compulsion to stay where her sin and ignominy are rooted. She establishes herself in a small, isolated thatched cottage on the outskirts of town. She supports herself and Pearl through her exquisite needlework, which becomes highly sought after for public ceremonies, official garments, and even funeral attire, though never for a bride's veil. Hester dresses herself in coarse, somber clothes, with only the scarlet letter as an ornament, but she adorns Pearl in rich, fanciful, gold-embroidered garments, which seem to embody the scarlet letter itself. Hester gives her surplus earnings to charity but receives only scorn. She endures social isolation, feeling like a ghost. Children mock her, and strangers stare at the scarlet letter, branding it afresh into her soul. Sometimes, she feels a sympathetic eye on her letter, only to realize it's a shared sin. She begins to believe the scarlet letter gives her a "sympathetic knowledge of the hidden sin in other hearts," making her question the outward purity of others.

**VI. Pearl.**
Pearl is described as a beautiful, vigorous, and intelligent child, but with a wild, defiant nature that reflects Hester's own impassioned state during her birth. Hester struggles to discipline Pearl, who seems to be swayed only by her own impulses and often appears more like an "airy sprite" than a human child. Pearl is an outcast among other children, who scorn her, and she retaliates fiercely. At home, she creates imaginary worlds and enemies. Hester is tormented by Pearl's wildness and her constant fascination with the scarlet letter. Pearl's first conscious observation was the scarlet letter on Hester's bosom, and she often touches it or arranges burrs on it. Pearl repeatedly asks Hester about the meaning of the scarlet letter and why the Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale always keeps his hand over his heart. Hester, unable to answer truthfully, tells Pearl she wears it for the gold thread, and becomes exasperated by Pearl's persistent questioning.

**VII. The Governor’s Hall.**
Hester goes to Governor Bellingham's mansion to deliver embroidered gloves and, more importantly, to plead against a plan by some leading inhabitants to take Pearl from her, believing Pearl is a "demon offspring" or would be better raised by others. Pearl, dressed in a crimson velvet tunic embroidered with gold, is a "brightest little jet of flame." As they approach the mansion, Puritan children mock them, but Pearl frightens them off. Inside the Governor's hall, Pearl is fascinated by a suit of burnished armor, in which Hester sees her own reflection distorted, with the scarlet letter appearing in "exaggerated and gigantic proportions," seeming to hide her entirely. Pearl then demands a red rose from the garden.

**VIII. The Elf-Child and the Minister.**
Governor Bellingham enters with Mr. Wilson, Mr. Dimmesdale, and Roger Chillingworth. The Governor questions Hester's fitness as a mother, citing Pearl's elaborate attire and her inability to answer Mr. Wilson's catechism question about who made her (Pearl claims she was plucked from a rose bush by the prison door). Hester vehemently defends her right to keep Pearl, arguing that Pearl is her happiness and her torture, a constant reminder and punishment for her sin. She appeals to Mr. Dimmesdale, reminding him of his pastoral charge over her soul. Dimmesdale, looking pale and emaciated, supports Hester, arguing that God gave Pearl to Hester as both a blessing and a retribution, to keep her mother's soul alive and prevent her from deeper sin. Chillingworth smiles at Dimmesdale's earnestness. The magistrates decide to let Hester keep Pearl, but require Pearl to be catechized. Pearl, in a rare moment of tenderness, takes Dimmesdale's hand and kisses his brow. Mistress Hibbins, the Governor's sister (later executed as a witch), then appears and invites Hester to join her in the forest to meet the "Black Man." Hester refuses, saying Pearl saved her from Satan's snare. Chillingworth remarks on Pearl's wildness and wonders if a philosopher could guess the father from her nature.

**IX. The Leech.**
Roger Chillingworth, Hester's secret husband, settles in Boston as a physician, using his knowledge of European medicine and Indian herbs. He becomes Mr. Dimmesdale's medical adviser, as the young minister's health is failing due to intense study, pastoral duties, and self-imposed fasts and vigils. The community is divided: some believe Dimmesdale is too holy for this world, others that his decline is due to unworthiness. A rumor spreads that Chillingworth, with his mysterious past and increasingly evil appearance, is Satan's emissary, tormenting Dimmesdale. Chillingworth, who was once a kind and upright man, is now consumed by a "terrible fascination" for revenge, delving into Dimmesdale's heart like a miner for gold.

**X. The Leech and His Patient.**
Chillingworth relentlessly probes Dimmesdale's soul, seeking the hidden sin he suspects. Dimmesdale, with his sensitive nerves, vaguely perceives an inimical influence but, being suspicious of all mankind, cannot recognize his enemy in his trusted physician. One day, while discussing herbs gathered from a nameless grave, Chillingworth suggests the weeds symbolize a hideous secret buried with the dead man, which he should have confessed. Dimmesdale argues that some secrets are meant to be held until Judgment Day, and that public confession is not always part of divine retribution. Chillingworth presses him, asking why guilty ones don't seek solace by revealing their sins. Dimmesdale, clutching his heart, admits that many confess to him, finding relief, but that some men bury their secrets to preserve their reputation and continue doing good. Chillingworth dismisses this, saying such men deceive themselves and that a "false show" cannot be better than God's truth. Pearl and Hester pass by the window. Pearl, in a mischievous mood, dances on a tombstone and arranges burrs on Hester's scarlet letter. Chillingworth remarks on Pearl's lawless nature. Pearl throws a burr at Dimmesdale, who shrinks from it, and Pearl laughs, shouting that the "old Black Man" has already caught the minister. Dimmesdale, agitated, asks Chillingworth if he has profited from his care. Chillingworth implies that Dimmesdale's bodily illness stems from a "sore place" in his spirit, which he must reveal to be healed. Dimmesdale passionately refuses to confess to an "earthly physician," committing himself to God. He rushes out. Chillingworth, with a grave smile, notes that Dimmesdale's passion reveals his "wild thing erenow." Later, Dimmesdale apologizes, and their intimacy is re-established. Some time after, Dimmesdale falls asleep in his chair. Chillingworth approaches him, lays his hand on his bosom, and thrusts aside his vestment, revealing something on Dimmesdale's chest. Chillingworth then turns away with a "wild look of wonder, joy, and horror," an "ecstasy" that reveals his diabolical triumph.

**XI. The Interior of a Heart.**
After Chillingworth's discovery, his torment of Dimmesdale becomes more intimate and subtle. He plays upon Dimmesdale's fears and remorse, raising "a thousand phantoms" of shame. Dimmesdale, though dimly aware of an evil influence, cannot discern its true nature. He loathes Chillingworth's deformed figure but attributes his feelings to his own morbid state. Despite his internal suffering, Dimmesdale achieves brilliant popularity as a minister, his anguish fueling his eloquence. He is revered as a saint, but this public veneration tortures him, as he longs to confess his pollution and lie. He repeatedly attempts to confess his vileness from the pulpit, but his vague words are misinterpreted by the congregation as evidence of his profound holiness. In secret, Dimmesdale practices self-scourging, fasting, and vigils, during which he experiences visions of devils, angels, his dead parents, and Hester and Pearl pointing at his breast. He realizes the "unspeakable misery of a life so false as his." One night, a new thought strikes him, and he steals out of his house.

**XII. The Minister’s Vigil.**
Dimmesdale goes to the scaffold where Hester was publicly shamed seven years prior. In the darkness of an early May night, he stands there, tormented by remorse and cowardice. He lets out a shriek, which startles Governor Bellingham and Mistress Hibbins, who look out their windows. Mr. Wilson passes by, but does not see Dimmesdale. Hester and Pearl, returning from Governor Winthrop's deathbed, also come upon the scaffold. Dimmesdale calls them up, and the three stand together, forming an "electric chain." Pearl asks if he will stand with them at noontide tomorrow, but Dimmesdale refuses, promising to do so only at the "great judgment day." A meteor then illuminates the sky, forming a dull red letter "A." Dimmesdale interprets it as a sign of his guilt, but Pearl points to Chillingworth, who is watching nearby. Dimmesdale, terrified, asks Hester who Chillingworth is, but she remains silent, bound by her oath. Pearl whispers something unintelligible to Dimmesdale about the "Black Man." Chillingworth approaches, feigning concern, and leads Dimmesdale home. The next day, Dimmesdale preaches his most powerful sermon, but the sexton finds Dimmesdale's glove on the scaffold and mentions the meteor, interpreting the "A" as "Angel" for the deceased Governor Winthrop.

**XIII. Another View of Hester.**
Seven years have passed, and Pearl is now seven years old. Hester's public image has softened. Her constant helpfulness and charity during times of calamity have led many to reinterpret the scarlet letter, now saying it means "Able." She has become a "Sister of Mercy." However, her character has become more austere, her beauty diminished, and her heart has turned from passion to thought. She engages in bold speculation about society and the role of women, thoughts considered heretical by the Puritans. She realizes that Pearl, by her very existence, has kept her from becoming a prophetess or a radical. Hester, observing Dimmesdale's suffering during his vigil, feels a renewed responsibility towards him. She realizes Chillingworth's torment is driving Dimmesdale to ruin and resolves to reveal Chillingworth's true identity to the minister.

**XIV. Hester and the Physician.**
Hester sends Pearl to play by the water and confronts Roger Chillingworth in the forest. Chillingworth informs her that the magistrates have considered removing her scarlet letter, but Hester calmly replies that it will fall away only when she is worthy. Hester observes Chillingworth's transformation; his former intellectual calm has been replaced by a fierce, guarded look and a "glare of red light" in his eyes, making him appear devilish. She accuses him of tormenting Dimmesdale, saying he has become a fiend. Chillingworth admits his transformation is due to his seven years of revenge, which he has "wasted" on the minister. He claims Dimmesdale would have died sooner without his aid. Hester retorts that it would have been better for Dimmesdale to die. Chillingworth, with a "lurid fire" in his heart, confesses that he has made Dimmesdale suffer more than any mortal, and that he has become a fiend for this purpose. Hester, appalled, asks if he has not tortured Dimmesdale enough. Chillingworth replies that Dimmesdale has only increased his debt. Hester then declares she must reveal Chillingworth's true character to Dimmesdale, accepting whatever consequences may follow. Chillingworth, with a mix of admiration and gloom, says it is their "fate" and that he cannot pardon. He then waves his hand and returns to gathering herbs.

**XV. Hester and Pearl.**
Hester reflects on her hatred for Chillingworth, realizing she now hates him more than she repents her sin. Pearl returns from playing, having made a green "A" from eel-grass on her own bosom. She again asks Hester what the scarlet letter means and why the minister keeps his hand over his heart. Hester, distressed, tells Pearl that the letter is for the "sake of its gold-thread," a lie she has never told before. Pearl persists in her questions, making Hester realize the child might be seeking a deeper connection. Hester contemplates Pearl's precocity and the possibility of confiding in her. Pearl's persistent questioning about the minister's hand over his heart deeply troubles Hester.

**XVI. A Forest Walk.**
Hester seeks an opportunity to speak with Dimmesdale alone, away from Chillingworth's influence. She learns he will be returning from visiting Apostle Eliot. The next day, she takes Pearl to a secluded part of the forest. Pearl observes that the sunshine avoids Hester because of the scarlet letter. Pearl then tells Hester the local superstition about the "Black Man" who haunts the forest, making people sign his book with their blood and marking them on their bosoms. Pearl asks if the scarlet letter is the Black Man's mark on Hester, and if Hester meets him. Hester, after some hesitation, admits she once met the Black Man and that the scarlet letter is his mark. Pearl then spots Dimmesdale approaching, noting he has his hand over his heart, and asks if that is where the Black Man marked him.

**XVII. The Pastor and His Parishioner.**
Hester calls out to Dimmesdale, who is walking feebly and haggardly. They meet in the dim forest, like ghosts from another world. They sit together, discussing their shared misery. Dimmesdale confesses his despair, the torment of his public veneration, and his longing for someone to know his true sinful self. Hester reveals that Roger Chillingworth is her husband and that he has been tormenting Dimmesdale for seven years. Dimmesdale is initially furious with Hester, blaming her for his suffering, but she pleads for his forgiveness. He eventually forgives her, declaring Chillingworth's revenge a greater sin than their own. Hester urges Dimmesdale to leave Boston and escape Chillingworth's influence. She proposes they flee together to the Old World, where they can start a new life.

**XVIII. A Flood of Sunshine.**
Dimmesdale, filled with a mix of hope, joy, and fear, agrees to flee with Hester. He feels a sudden exhilaration, as if released from a dungeon. Hester, with a sense of triumph, unclasps the scarlet letter from her bosom and throws it away into the withered leaves near the brook. She also removes her cap, letting her rich, dark hair fall. Her beauty, youth, and radiant smile return, and the forest is suddenly flooded with sunshine, reflecting their newfound hope. Hester tells Dimmesdale he must know Pearl, who is not far off.

**XIX. The Child at the Brook-Side.**
Hester calls Pearl, who is playing by the brook. Pearl, seeing her mother without the scarlet letter and with her hair unbound, is hesitant and refuses to cross the brook. She fixes her gaze on Hester and Dimmesdale, and then points at Hester's breast, where the letter should be. Dimmesdale, feeling uneasy, notes that children often distrust him. Hester realizes Pearl misses the scarlet letter. She retrieves the letter from the leaves and fastens it back onto her bosom, and confines her hair under her cap. As she does so, her beauty and warmth fade, and the sunshine vanishes. Pearl then bounds across the brook, embraces Hester, and kisses the scarlet letter. Pearl still refuses to kiss Dimmesdale and washes his previous kiss off her forehead in the brook. She asks if he will walk hand-in-hand with them into town, but Hester says not now, but in the future. Pearl remains aloof from Dimmesdale.

**XX. The Minister in a Maze.**
Dimmesdale leaves Hester and Pearl, returning to town with an unaccustomed physical energy, but also a sense of profound internal change. He and Hester have planned to escape to Bristol on a ship in three days, after he delivers his Election Sermon. As he walks, he is assailed by strange, wicked impulses: to utter blasphemies to a deacon, to suggest arguments against the soul's immortality to an old woman, to teach wicked words to children, and to exchange jests with a drunken sailor. He encounters Mistress Hibbins, who hints at his secret forest meeting and his connection to the "Black Man." Dimmesdale realizes he has made a bargain with sin, and that its poison has spread through his moral system. He returns to his study, throws his unfinished Election Sermon into the fire, and writes a new, inspired sermon with intense fervor throughout the night.

**XXI. The New England Holiday.**
On Election Day, Hester and Pearl are in the market-place, which is thronged with townspeople, Indians, and mariners. Hester wears her coarse gray garment and the scarlet letter, appearing outwardly calm but inwardly preparing for her freedom. Pearl is exuberantly dressed. Pearl notices Dimmesdale will not greet them publicly. Hester tells her he will not greet them today, but will walk with them another time. Pearl expresses her confusion about the minister's public aloofness versus his private interactions in the forest. A shipmaster, who has spoken with Hester about passage to Bristol, tells her that Roger Chillingworth has also booked passage on the same ship, intending to accompany Dimmesdale. Hester is shocked, realizing Chillingworth has discovered their plan. She sees Chillingworth in the market-place, smiling a "secret and fearful meaning" at her.

**XXII. The Procession.**
The procession begins with music and a military escort, followed by magistrates and then Mr. Dimmesdale. He walks with an unaccustomed energy and strength, his hand no longer over his heart, but his face is abstracted. Hester watches him, feeling a sense of remoteness and doubt about their shared bond. Pearl asks if he is the same minister who kissed her by the brook. Mistress Hibbins approaches Hester, again hinting at Dimmesdale's secret connection to the "Black Man" and predicting his mark will be revealed. Dimmesdale delivers his Election Sermon from the meeting-house, his voice filled with passion, pathos, and a deep undertone of pain that Hester alone perceives. The sermon moves the entire community, who believe him to be a miracle of holiness. Pearl, meanwhile, plays in the market-place, interacting with Indians and mariners. The shipmaster attempts to kiss Pearl, but she eludes him. He then gives her a gold chain and tells her that Chillingworth has arranged to bring Dimmesdale aboard the ship. Hester's spirit almost sinks, realizing Chillingworth has thwarted their escape. The crowd, including those who have heard rumors of the scarlet letter, gathers around Hester, making her feel the shame of the letter more acutely than ever.

**XXIII. The Revelation of the Scarlet Letter.**
After his sermon, Dimmesdale appears feeble and pale. He rejects Mr. Wilson's support and, to the astonishment of the crowd, calls Hester and Pearl to the scaffold. Roger Chillingworth rushes forward, attempting to stop him, whispering, "Madman, hold! what is your purpose?" Dimmesdale, however, declares Chillingworth's power is broken and, with God's help, he will escape him. He extends his hand to Hester, asking her to support him. Leaning on Hester and holding Pearl's hand, Dimmesdale ascends the scaffold. Chillingworth follows, remarking that this scaffold was the only place Dimmesdale could not escape him. Dimmesdale, trembling, asks Hester if this is not "better than what we dreamed of in the forest." Hester replies she doesn't know, fearing they will all die. Dimmesdale then addresses the people, confessing his sin and revealing that he is the "one sinner of the world." With a convulsive motion, he tears away his ministerial band, revealing a scarlet letter (or similar mark) imprinted on his own breast. The horror-stricken multitude gazes at this "ghastly miracle." Dimmesdale falls, and Hester supports his head. Chillingworth kneels beside him, repeating, "Thou hast escaped me!" Dimmesdale, dying, forgives Chillingworth, saying he too has deeply sinned. He asks Pearl for a kiss, which she gives him, breaking a "spell" and signifying her entry into human sympathy. Hester asks if they will meet in eternal life, but Dimmesdale expresses doubt, saying their broken law and revealed sin may prevent a "pure reunion." With a final "Farewell!" Dimmesdale expires.

**XXIV. Conclusion.**
After Dimmesdale's death, various theories circulate regarding the mark on his breast: some believe he inflicted it himself as penance, others that Chillingworth used magic and poison, and still others that it was the physical manifestation of his remorse. Some witnesses deny any mark existed, interpreting his death as a parable about human righteousness. The narrator, however, states his manuscript source confirms the mark. Roger Chillingworth, deprived of his object of revenge, withers away and dies within a year, leaving a substantial inheritance to Pearl. Pearl, now a rich heiress, disappears from Boston with Hester. For many years, there are no authentic tidings of them. Eventually, Hester Prynne returns alone to her old cottage, still wearing the scarlet letter. The letter has lost its stigma and become a symbol of reverence. Hester, having no selfish ends, becomes a counselor to troubled women, offering comfort and believing in a future "new truth" that will establish a surer relation between man and woman. She is buried next to Dimmesdale, but with a space between their graves, sharing a single tombstone inscribed: "On a field, sable, the letter A, gules."

book_title: Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea-Jules Verne
summary_llm:
The year 1866 was marked by a mysterious phenomenon: an enormous, spindle-shaped, occasionally phosphorescent object, much larger and faster than any known whale, was sighted by vessels across the globe. Initial reports from ships like the *Governor Higginson* and the *Columbus* in the Pacific, and later the *Helvetia* and *Shannon* in the Atlantic, described its surprising speed and power. These sightings, along with a collision involving the *Etna*, led to widespread public agitation and scientific debate.
